reviewText:
Early Access Review

At the moment this game has great atmosphere, great art, and a good narrorator.

This might be thought of as me ♥♥♥♥♥ing, bit the fact of the matter is that the game's combat system is hilariously flawed.

The game is difficult, but not because of lack of planning on the player's part, or poor choices. No, it is hard because of RNG, like most roguelike games. In combat, there is nothing to tell you who is going first. Sure, you could look at every party member's speed rating and every enemy's speed rating, but wouldn't it be easier to tell the player so he can plan, and not rely on RNG?

The game has extreme difficulty spikes, often wiping your entire party out even when they enter a boss battle with full health / no stress because of.. reasons. Enemies get two or three turns per round, and can often wipe your whole party in the FIRST TURN. Losing characters is a part of roguelikes, but this game has far too many cheap deaths to make their deaths feel as though you did something wrong.

The hunger mechanic is broken. I just fed each of my party members to recover some health, WHY are they hungry, and why is the only option to starve?  Why can I not chose who starves, and instead feed the party members who I want?

The game prevents you from having any veterans, as those who get to the higher levels are often loaded with disproportionate amounts of negative quirks, making it so it would be more cost effective to toss them out than to heal their injuries. There is no out-of-combat healing system aside from food, and for some reason bandages don't heal your wounds?

Ranting aside, the game has a lot of potential and is already really fun. I don't recommend it because by it's nature it is the pure embodiment of blind RNG. When you finish a level, it does not feel rewarding because you feel as though you've gotten lucky. When you fail a level, or lose all your party members, it is often because you feel cheated by the game.

Also there are some critical glitches that absolutely destroy your save. Since the game autosaves after each action, if you are stuck in a loop where you can't get back to town / it crashes during certain stages of combat, you are forced to watch as hours of your time are thrown away. Pretty terrible, but it's early access and I guess they'll fix it.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nLet me begin with saying I do enjoy the concept of this game. I wanted to be someone who enjoyed it despite all the critisms I read before buying it. The randomness isn't my problem, really- it's the game being able to completely ruin you without any input on your part. Too many times I've set out to a dungeon and the first battle someone is killed before I even have a chance to react. The gold system is frustrating, and some of the currency seems pointless because it needs the same amount of another currency always. Why can't you keep the items you don't use each week? That makes little to no sense to me. I love the hero classes, the art, the voices, the abilities, the items- but the game is just far too cruel in some ways. Watching a hero die before I even get to make any choices or actions is really frustrating, and ruins a whole game week- because 3 heroes is a massive handicap and you're doomed to retreat or die soon into the dungeon. Another thing that was frustrating is finally getting to camp, and then being attacked for it so you lose all the health, stress reduction, and other benefits of camping. A couple times I've ended up worse for camping. I really like what I see from the devs of this game, I've gone back and read a lot of the updates and such- so I'm sure they'll iron it out they seem very committed but honestly, at the moment, I don't recommend this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Darkest Dungeon, are the extremly good example of how modern roguelike games supposed to be, without giving up principles of old days, and turning in rouglite.
Deep, complex and unforgiving game mechanics only benefits from good graphic, clear interface and simple controls (all you need is mouse), making gaming experience only stronger.
Every step in dungeon will make you feel a deep thrill of danger and hostility. Every battle feels like it could by the last for some of characters, no metter how good they are, and simple monsters can turn to by a stronger then a whole party. All of this quickly clears out, that characters are not usual gaming godlike-immortal-safeloaders, but are the natural part of the world, and it is so rare in modern games :(
The victories comes from carefull planning and understanding of game, and overconfidence lead to permadeath. And this is what a true roguelike is and loved for.


Despite being in the early access, game fills finished and fine, although there is only 2/3 of planed content. I encounter zero bugs for 5 hours of playing.

reviewText:
I was never good at this game. I got it because I loved watching livestreams of it, and on my first day, neither of my starting characters made it to town, and my new party wiped on their third mission. After that, I didn't really play anymore, but I still paid attention to its development and still loved to watch the streams. But over time, I noticed that the game was getting worse and worse as it got longer. In the state where I first took interest, with just the Ruins, Warrens, and Weald, the amount of content and difficulty scale overall seemed ideal. The introduction of the Cove seemed to stretch things a little thin, but I was still willing to overlook that because as a work of art, this game is beyond outstanding. The art, the atmosphere, the voice work, the character and enemy design, it's all pretty close to perfect.

And then... the Darkest Dungeon came out, with that more than quadrupling the amount of grind present in the game - starting with quadruple because of the dungeon's unique mechanic: having to be beaten four times with completely different parties, and actually being much worse because RNG at Darkest difficulty level is *horribly* stacked, virtually guaranteeing a huge number of failed runs and deaths for each actual success. And at that point, this game went from cruelly hard to virtually unplayable.

Oh, it wasn't all the Darkest Dungeon's fault. To some extent, it just seems that every new feature added to this game only serves to make it more punishing, the most notable example being the horrible disease system that doubles the number of debilitating penalties a hero can suffer from, but that was the final nail in the coffin. This used to be one of the games I was most proud to have in my library, even if I was too much of a chicken to play it much myself. But these days... you need to ask yourself, is it worth trying to play a game that requires dozens of hours playing through the same content over and over, getting continually screwed by the RNG in the process? This game isn't 'random' in the usual sense of the word - you don't get a streak of good rolls and win, because luck only carries so far before its benefits are removed or canceled out. We're not talking about beating a hard mission once, we're talking about farming them to truly gain ground. The only randomness here? Whether or not you'll make it through each grinding session without having your progress completely set back again.

As a work of art, this game deserves a spot in a museum, and to have classes of college students studying it and writing papers on it. As a game... it's not a game, it's just grim, soul-crushing, uphill toil. I suppose, considering its subject matter and intended effect on the player, that this is only fitting.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Simply put, the games stress mechanic works great, and is an amazing example of gameplay story integration. As a reality ensues version of a dungeon crawler, it succeeds amazingly. Alot of minor things may not be explained at first, and some things that work you may not even try because of thinking about what you can do, because you think of it as a game and dont try something you would do irl (see using bandages as handwraps for investigating a kniferack).

The heros are varied and never seem to be just carbon copies of eachother, and the position based strategy like combat is fun and interesting. But be careful that the stress doesnt get to even you, rushing your judgement and making mistakes as a consequence of stress, again, that stress based mechanic is well implemented, an amazingly interesting theme, and adds alot to the gameplay. Though some might find the RNG a bit too powerful.

The game leaves an impression when you just look at it that it will be overcomplicated but really its not, its the same effect as FTL, a cursory glance at the variety of features gives an illusion of overcomplication. Certain moves work in certain positions, and you remember them reasonably well, and some are more suited for the front or back of your lineup due to being a tanking melee or a healer/ranged for instance. The stress makes you go insane at first and eventually a heart attack, but camping, jesters, critical hits, disarming traps and sometimes kills heal it, with a bit of skill its not that bad. They can get negative traits to debuff them that cost a bit of money to remove, and you take them to buildings to upgrade armor and moves and relieve stress. Even the trinkets I found to be relatively intuitive, upsides and downsides use them to buff or compensate, try not to leave to big a weakness, at the very least stuff like the blight stones and archers rings are easily understood.

The game doesnt ever tell you what you feel, despite what some may think, it tells you what they feel, and they can get stressed, go mad and have heart attacks. Stress can feel like more of a danger than the health, as its alot harder to cure. Death functions a bit differently, if someone loses all their health they go onto Death's Door"

reviewText: What a punishingly cruel and fantastic game. I'm on my third attempt at a play through without having used any guides or anything of the sort so far and I can't break myself away from this game. My first few attempts were heartbreaking and miserable at best, and I mean that in the best way possible. If you're looking for a game that will challenge you and beat you down into the ground for little mistakes, look no further. I hear a lot that it's entirely luck based, and there is a great deal of luck to it as with any rpg game with random modifiers. However, proper planning and well thought out tactics can save you from the most perilous of unlucky occurrences. This game is strictly 100% based on how well you can manage a team and make good decisions based on very bad circumstances. If you hate games that will stress you out, please don't play this game. But if you revel in triumph through great trial and tribulation, definitely pick this game up. It's worth every penny.

reviewText:
I'm a big fan of hard games, but Darkest Dungeon is just oppressive.  You barely make enough gold on a success to heal off the stress and unsustainable quirks from your last run, effectively breaking even.  A failure may cause you to lose several heroes you have invested many hours into.  I spent significant time learning the game's mechanics and increasing my chances, but it still just takes a few bad rolls of the RNG to burn it all down.  It's easy to party wipe in the final stages leading to a loss of 30+ hours, often out of your control due to the random factor.

It's inexcusable that Darkest Dungeon does not have an easier setting for players just starting to learn the mechanics.  Early mistakes will put you in the hole and often force you to abandon those heroes.

Even though many parts of the game are phenomenal, like the art, music and combat system, I cannot recommend it due to the oppressive chance-based difficulty.  It's ultimately an excercise in frustration.

reviewText:
Less than the sum of its parts
The game tries to mix tactical, management, roguelike and RPG elements, but the actual gameplay design is quite incoherent, irregular and ultimately not very enjoyable. It fails to live up to its potential as an interesting roguelike, or RPG. The shallow gameplay simply doesn't provide the entertainment and replayability, that other, good games of these genres offer:

- Dungeon-crawling and the tactical combat quickly become repetitive.
- There is no real story, interactions, or meaningful choices. The world" feels very static.
- Leveling up and managing your characters is not fun.

- Superb art style and audio.

The single good thing about this game is the excellent art and presentation. It captures the depressing

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is very fun, features a cool art style, and a dark souls-like experience, featuring permadeath and learning to manage stress, as well as your own health.

Do you continue venturing forward, despite all adversity? Do you decide to end the mission early and count your losses? You will be asking these questions a lot as you play.

You can also use items you recover from dungeons to upgrade and improve your town, which all is necessary to unlock more features, or create new weapons and armor, and better stress relief with the church and the tavern.

Overall, I find this game very fun, difficult, and a great story. The voice narrator is amazing and really sells the game as well!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is utterly fantastic, and I am super happy that I backed it when it came out. Let me start off by saying the devs are extremely responsive and constantly show up in the forums. Which is a huge plus, especially for an early access game. They listen to our feedback, and are quick to fix issues within the game. Just wanted throw a kudos to Red Hook. Y'all are awesome.

On to the game now. The game is extremely high risk/high reward. Your team is low, but you've got one room left and you'll finish the quest. Do you risk it and attempt to see if the room is clear/fight the battle, or do you haul it back to town with your team in-tact and the treasure you've collected so far? There are interactable objects that can also save your run, or set you back which adds a lot to do while crawling through the dungeons. The game is extremely difficult, but in the best possible way.

Starting off you're going to die, a lot. Until you learn the mechanics, learn how to build a balanced team for each dungeon. Learn how the abilities work and function. You will die, but that's ok. In Darkest Dungeon every death is a new lesson. The variety of heroes we've been given is pretty vast so far including the Grave Robber, Vestal, Occultist, Crusader, Highwayman, Hellion, Jester, and Leper. All of them work differentlky and do their jobs well.

A tag you won't see on this game that is a major part of it is, Puzzle. Every fight is a puzzle of sorts, especially boss fights. They all have weaknesses and different attacks/combinations that mess up the enemies momentum and attacks. Got a dude sniping you from the back? Use Eldritch Pull to yank him to the front and knock him out. Got a Plague Doctor? Use Flash Powder to stun the back line while you eat their beefy front line leaving them open.

There is so many to go through a dungeon and it's just an all-around fantastic game. The community is very helpful and we're all learning and helping each out. If you're into difficult, but rewarding games with a dark atmosphere, and Cthulhu/Eldritch creatures, then Darkest Dungeon is the game for you.
voteText: 15 of 24 people (63%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is one of the few early access indie titles that I didn't hesitate to purchase after doing some research and it does not dissapoint.  Although it is still early access, Darkest Dungeon is well into development, has plenty of content, and is more then worth the asking price of $20.

As for the gameplay itself, it is just as described:  A roguelike turn-based dungeon crawler rpg.  There is a good amount of depth and strategy involved, both in and out of battles.  Choosing how to spend your money and resources on upgrades and provisions, deciding which of your heroes to bring and which of their abilities to equip,  and choosing how to act during battles and other random events, etc...

The art style is absolutely gorgeous, in a gritty, atmospheric kind of way.  The art and music come together perfectly to set a dark undertone.

Oh, by the way, this game is hard.  You will always be struggling in one way or another while exploring a dungeon, and very rarely does a situation play out as planned, forcing you to change tactics and make decisions one turn at a time.  Although difficult and random (as expected from a roguelike) Darkest Dungeon never feels unfair.

Overall this game is super dank and earns 8/10 bomb nuggets.  The final product will likely be a 9 or 10.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nWelp, I will start by saying I've been on the fence about this game for a while. Truthfully, unlike a lot of people I didn't start this game when it was considered its golden days, I started after corpses and heart attacks were allowed to be disabled, which I did from the get go and never looked back. That being said, I really enjoyed this game, and I still do to some extent. But every recent patch has just made the game more and more unbearable, with enemy crit chance being so damn high, prot being frickin ridiculous, and enemies in general having too much dodge. I could live with enemies in champion level dungeons having 40+ base dodge if my characters could get that much. When they do, it's with trinkets and it rarely seems to help. Enemies also have perfect skills, which pretty much make move skills only good for them. If your arbalest or healer, or plague doctor gets pulled to rank 1, well, unless you work fast they will die fast. What happens if I pull one of their ranged rank 4 units? He starts using close range moves, that, while weaker, still allow him to do something all while those who were moved back use moves pushing them forward/don't give a single crap about the rules and continue using their moves from back rows. I understand they don't want move to be op, but if my leper gets to rank 4 what does he do? Slowly walk his way up? Champion level dungeons right now are the biggest chore, with enemies having so much life/dodge/prot it takes forever to kill things. Oh, and disregard the tooltip telling you to use blight on high prot enemies, 9/10 times good classes can just do a melee swing and apply a bleed totalling to way more than the blight. The only time I would recommend blight is against the formless flesh in champion. Class balance; I haven't gotten to try the abomination out yet, but when I saw my cousin using him in apprentice dungeons he seemed really good. Whether or not that will last into champion who knows. But unfortunately, for class balance in general, it's not that good. In normal dungeon crawling scenarios, I'd argue it's ok. Any class can manage on normal runs. Hell, until champion, I'd even argue most classes can do most bosses. But unfortunately, even with that being said, there will always be classes better. My top pick would easily be Hellion, as this class has enough hp and dodge to function as a tank while easily outdamaging any other class in the game and even being able to hit further ranks of enemies, which is very important on bosses in champion level dungeons. Lepers, crusaders, a load of classes just won't cut it in champion. Also, most bosses cheat in champion dungeons too - the swine god still managed to do damage to my party when his damage was debuffed to -160%. So, in conclusion, I think this game had potential. It was fun, and to some extent now it's still fun. It's a lot more unique than the cookie cutter crafting games on steam early access, but unfortunately, these devs disregarded fun at one point and tried to make it as gimmicky and hars" as possible. Take it from me

reviewText:
Darkest Dungeon is a brilliant turn based game loosely based off of lovecraftian lore. You are summoned to your ancestor's home that has fallen in disrepair and corruption to a force that is revealed as you progress through the storyline and fight bosses.

With stunning graphical design and amazing voice acting by Wayne June you'll be instantly drawn in... however.

From the very beginning the player is warned that this game is extremely hard, you will be forced to make tough decisions and not to grow overly attached to characters, THEY WILL DIE. Normally this is not an issue but...

The game mechanics are flawed in many aspects. Your characters have an HP meter and a Stress meter. Once your stress meter reaches 100 out of 200, your characters can and will most of the time develop some sort of side effect from the horrors witnessed throughout combat. Too many times have I witnessed my healer become paranoid and refuse to act all together, and whenever a stressful event happens, ANYTHING at all stress related, all your other companions will get more stress aswell, quickly developing into a failscade, and many times these happen outside of your control. At 200 stress your character has a heartattack and immediately hits 0 HP. This also stresses out the party. I have on multiple occasions seen one character hit 200, heartattack, stressing out everyone else into a heartattack, while all four where under some sort of bleed or poison and watched 4 party members die in one go.

RNG rules this game and will create nightmarish situations for you to witness. The ability for your team to failscade due to bad RNG is all too present, Heals are underwhelming and in no way will keep up with the ludicrous damage monsters put out. Debuffs and buffs dont last long enough, turn order is badly calculated and gives the House" the advantage

Once a character hits lvl 3 Resolve he cannot ever go back to doing apprentice level missions (Resolve 0-2) which means you can't grind an A-team and go back to do bosses you left so you could grind

reviewText:
This is one of those love it or hate it games.  Your characters will die, a lot.  You will grind, a lot.  Battles will turn on you without warning, a lot.

In the end - just wasn't for me.  This is a punishing game, and just when you think you're getting the hang of it, you lose 4 of your most developed characters to a boss battle that turned bad in a couple turns.  It's a brutal game - if you're into that, you'll probably love it.  It just wasn't for me.

If you're thinking of buying it, make sure to read a selection of the most recent reviews.  Some recent patches changed up some play mechanics and also impacted endgame economy and advancement.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My review after playing 6 hours:

One of the best things about it is the setting. I really love how dark and hopeless the game feels, the available classes, skills and status effects. I also like the way you need to manage your team with 2 different health bars (hp and stress), taking care of resource management (torch, food and gold) and a big amount of status effects in battles.

However, there are some issues with the current build, most notably the amount of grind required. Since you can't keep using the same heroes over and over (firstly because you need to let them rest to recover stress, and secondly because you can outlevel the content and not be able to use them anymore!), you need to train other squards, which takes a huge amount of time. If a hero dies, you also lose it forever, meaning a bunch of hours training him were tossed out of the window.

I feel like a few of these mechanincs were created to make you care more about your characters and decisions, but they accomplish the opposite of what was intended. After the first time your character dies and you recruit a substitute you treat them as disposable thrash. You know that if the worst happens and a character dies you only need a few more hours playing to replace him, so he isn't unique" in a true sense. There's also some squad compositions which are clearly supperior to others

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game was enjoyable at first. Mostly because of unlockables and trying new abilities and character types. Once the initial discoveries have been made only a semi-insane completionist like myself would consider continuing to play. The battles are not really anything special or different from an old super nintendo turn based jrpg and the quests your characters go on don't actually vary much.

I got to the point where I had four level 5 characters and took them on a veteran mission (level 6 is the max, veteran level missions are the hardest). I took a few risks because my armor and weapons weren't at max level. It was tough but no one was dying. Then I faced a fat ectoplasm with 70 health and 2 of the smaller ones. I killed the big one. A smaller one spawned another big one with 70 more health. I killed that one. More small ectoplasms were spawned since I couldn't one hit them or stun them. I also couldn't run away from the battle. After killing 3 fat ectoplasms and about 7 small ones my characters were given death blows and all died by about round 20. I suppose I should have known better and played it safe by taking other characters on another 3 - 6 quests to get the money and artifacts to max out my armor, levels, and skills.

It may seem like I am giving the game a negative review out of frustration, I had done well up to that point, but losing my highest level characters and having no money left made me realize that a game that will set you back 4 - 6 hours while asking you to continue the same repetitive tasks over and over just to level is just poorly designed. Unfortunately I compulsively play games and want to see them through even if they aren't offering anything new. I thank the game for breaking its hold on me but would not recommend playing it for more than 5 - 10 hours. Why do so many games nowadays want you to keep playing them long after they have stopped being enjoyable? Is it a requirement that every game have 30 – 60 hours of playtime to create the illusion that you’re getting your money’s worth?

Think of a game where you have like 12 different pokemon. At first it's interesting to test them out and get new abilities and make them stronger. Now imagine you have to level all those pokemon to progress as well as level a few duplicates since survival without a healer is unlikely. Now imagine some of those pokemon just die and you have to start leveling them from level 0 again. Aside from level 0 to 1, it takes 2 - 4 quests to gain a level. If repeating 50 - 80 mostly monotonous quests for 16 - 20 pokemon (since some will die) to complete this game sound like fun to you, then I highly recommend it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If I had given a review after one hour I would have given this a thumb's up.  There are things about this game I really like and I hope this review will help the developers add some things (this is still in early release) to really make this game special.  I'll list various pros and cons.

Positive - Combat positioning: Your characters and the enemy characters stand in a line (1-4).  Certain skills can only be used from certain positions and skills can only target certain enemy positions.  Some skills attempt to move an enemy to a new position.  This adds a nice strategic element to traditional turn-based RPG combat.

Positive - Overall Graphics: Generally rather nice.  Game has a good feel to it graphically.

Negative - Hero Uniqueness:  You basically recruit random heroes of a certain class.  These heroes stay with you until they die (very possible) or you dismiss them (can be a good idea at times).  These heroes start with a random assortment of skills and gain random quirks (both positive and negative) that separate them from other heroes of the same class.  The problem is several-fold: (1) Heroes don't have random base stats (e.g., strength) that allows separation; (2) All heroes of the same class can learn the same skills if you spend gold to upgrade them, leading heroes to be less unique; (3) Quirks don't do a great job of separation.  Sometimes a quirk is so bad you won't want to use the hero until its removed but other than that the most important thing is class composition on a dungeon run.

Negative - Equipment:  The equipment system is about as rudimentary as you can get.  You don't find weapons and armor but improve it through town upgrades (requiring relics) and then spending gold.  All equipment for a certain class is the exact same, the only difference is the upgrade level (upgrading adds no random stats).  The only room for variation in equipment is two trinket slots.  While you find trinkets in dungeons and there appear to be a good number of them, the problem is that trinkets always have one positive effect and one negative effect.  While the positive effect tends to outweigh the negative effect, often I find myself not using trinkets because I don't want the negative effect.  Trinkets essentially boil down to knowing the dungeons and choosing a trinket whose positive effect will be valuable against those monsters and whose negative effect won't matter much.

reviewText:
You remember our venerable house? Opulent and imperial, gazing proudly down.......


I hear this in my sleep.

We plummed the depths....

I alone returned....I dare not return.

Lost companions. Suffered afflictions. Lingering gold, trinkets and baubles; now remains the task of carrying it home. If you live for adventure, by all means, bring few torches.....you remember our venerable house? Opulent and imperial, gazing proudly.....

+_+_+_+_+_+_+_+_+_+_+_+_+_+_+_+_+_+_+_+_+_+_+

Turn-based combat, complex leveling system [town, heroes, abilities, gear], punishing as f**k....this is not a game for the casual gamer. If you long for the days of Megaman [NES] difficulty, but with modern complexity, an RPG element and Lovecraftian greatness....you probably already own this game.
If you fall into such a category and don't...your wallet is probably open with CC in-hand to throw money at Red Hook for this game.


disclaimer: I had a relatively negative [albeit truthful] review of this game for early-access, but deleted it because the complaints were entirely rectified by the implementation of the Antiquarian class.

reviewText:
TL;DR I imagine Darkest Dungeon is Dark Souls the RPG.
Man, this game is not meant for me. I don't know how people like TotalBiscet or NorthernLion make it look so fun. Maybe it's because I'm not the one playing. Maybe it is because they make it look easy. I don't know.
I just start a game and I'm already having a salty time. Getting constistently hit by crits and consistently missing attacks makes combat feel very unnatural, despite the fact you're combating supernatural beings but that is not the point. It doesn't feel like I'm being slowly whittled down bit by bit like a #2 pencil in a hand-cranked sharpener, but more like I'm a #2 pencil being snapped in half for funsies.
I feel no sense of escalation. Like instead of throwing monster fodder at me at the beginning like most RPGs do, it's more like every fight is a mini-boss, which means that one team of skeletons at the beginning of a mission will end you if RNGesus doesn't particularly like you that day.
I can't settle in on one save file because I can't trust the game on anything, like gambling since my luck is about as reliable as getting kicked in the groin. I know there are options in the setting menu that will decrease the risk, but I'm afraid that will decrease the authenticity of the experience of what the game is suppose to provide. Which is a delema to me. Do I want to enjoy PLAYING the game, or enjoy playing the GAME? I'll probably just leave it in my Steam library and leave it alone ad infinium.
Darkest Dungeon is a game about making the best out of a bad situation. But if the best I can make out of a bad situation is effectively nothing (poor roster selection, essentially no gold, bad luck with RNG) or worse, what is the point in trying?

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is painfully unrewarding. I have spent hours learning how to play it from walkthroughs and forums.... Hours and hours completely wasted.

Ive completed darksouls so I'm not shy of a challenging game but at least Dark souls made you feel like you were achieving something, even when taking 1 step back for every 2 steps forward, But Darkest dungeon is just irritatingly hard, obnoxiously difficult, it makes me want to smash my own face in.

I couldnt pass the first 3 rooms on the first level for the entire first day that I owned the game and thats not due to lack of skill, because this game doesnt require much skill to play, after all its completely luck based. Everything that happens is based off of luck and the odds are stacked against you.

I can not recommend this game to anyone simply because if they buy it, then they will be new to the game, and darkest dungeon HATES new players, absolutely wants to qiss and zhit all over new players faces and just expects them to learn all the tricks off everyone else via youtube and wiki's instead of in game advice/turorials/help/hints that should be there to help out new players but isnt.

This is an unforgiving, unrewarding game that can ruin your entire day if you waste too much time on it.

reviewText:
[ EDIT ]  As you can see below, I recommended this game prior to reaching the level 5 dungeons. After equipping my characters to maximum efforts, the nightmare of what many have described this game as 'unbalanced' has finally rung true, sadly. All time and effort battling with my characters, the last of hard earned gold purchasing much needed upgrades to venture the 5th level dungeons.. All.. for.. null. I have changed my tune and am no longer recommending Darkest Dungeon. I will put DD away until I find there is a much needed update to balance the 5th and 6th level dungeons. I can't imagine why anyone would continue playing this game. What's most upsetting is that I truly wanted to believe the negative reviews wrong..sigh

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

What feels to be a dark side-scrolling dungeon crawler - bringing to mind games of past that I enjoyed, gathering them into one tough ultra strategic D&D RPG of sorts.

I've found Darkest Dungeon (through trial and error) to be very tough on the unprepared. The game is brutal to both seasoned and unseasoned player who dive in with set goal in mind to conquer with a 'record time' mindset. If you do find yourself wanting to give this game a go, then you must know that your characters will die, every time, as long as they aren't developed enough through the lower stages while finding and equipping proper trinkets, leveling, and simply understanding correct placement in the line.

Placement in the line is probably the most important factor to survive and thrive in Darkest Dungeon, as there are 4 spots front to back where you will place your characters, each placement tailored specifically for different characters to maximize their individual strengths. Patience is needed to enjoy this title. If you don't have patience I suggest not purchasing this game as you will have a very difficult and stressful experience. You must study the characters and discover each of their strengths over time, while simultaneously learning by trial and error - dying, and starting over again - until you understand each characters abilities, placements and weaknesses.

The game is fun, I'm sincerely having a blast, and knowing there is permadeath keeps the intensity very high.

I cannot stress enough that Patience, once again, is key to enjoying this game. You cannot rush a game of chess, in Darkest Dungeon you must understand your pieces and respect the unspoken rules of the game first before gaining any glimpse of an advantage. Take it slow and enjoy the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Good
Something different.  Immersion is top notch. (great voiceover).  Really could have been something awesome.

The Bad
Extremly difficult game to the point the AI is totally unfair.  Instead of building up difficulty as you advance its just difficult all the time.  Stress in the game is too strong a mechanic that ruins the game. It should not be so prevalent.  One battle in and the AI can have got you down to slivers of health with crits etc,,  Food usage (hunger) can happen when it does not make sense,  it actually pays to also not to examine most items due to stress impacts.  Limited loot slots etc..  So it can end up being frustrating.  9 hours in I have enjoyed it but it just doesnt have the payoff for the time invested  and probably wont continue much further.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nRandom everything generation makes this game ridiculously hard. The concept and gameplay is great, but you will die...alot...and never have any control over those deaths at all. Everything from your character access to whether or not your skills work is random. Its very much like watching someone get struck by lightning 30 times in a row, or hit the lottery everytime they play only to always get hit by a meteor when they pick up their ticket. Lots of potential here, but doesn't quite make it to being playable...unless masochism is what the devs were going for. In which case they hit the bullseye.

Early Access Review

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This just isn't what I expected it would be. Games are supposed to give you control, but this game just makes you feel like everything is beyond your control. Every time something good happens, I can't enjoy it because right around the corner, something twice as bad happens. I feel like no matter the effort I put into the game, it will still screw me in the end. And that's just no fun. Dark Souls is hard, but it's a satisfying kind of hard because you are in full control of your actions.

A lot of people seem to like the punishment of Darkest Dungeon, but I only accept punishment when I've made an informed mistake. This game is just sadistic for the sake of being sadistic. Only buy if you don't like being in control of your games.

And yeah, I'm super disappointed. I wanted to like this game and have a great time with it so I could validate my purchase, but it's just no good for me.

(Edit:  Please understand that I am not unimpressed by the quality of the game. The sound design and artwork were both very exceptional. I merely can't recommend the game because for me, it is a miserable and unenjoyable experience.)

reviewText:
I know people will just vote this down without reading it, but I really don't care.

Darkest Dungeon is not a game I can bring myself to recommend, but I still find it to be an incredibly earnest videogame on the merit of how much effort went into making it -- at least as far as general production goes. The visual polish is incredible, even though it lacks variety. The core ideas are very interesting and some choices were good, such as the ability to leave a dungeon at any time to prevent loss of recruits, at a cost. The narrator is amazing and the addition of a section in the options menu which lets the player toggle certain systems such as corpses was a very good decision.

That said, while this breaks my heart to say, this is easily one of the most disappointing games I've ever played.

As it stands, progression-wise, Darkest Dungeon's design is very akin to your standard mobile game. Perform task, then perform task again, then perform same task again. As you do this, your funds may rise and you may inch yourself closer to... Whatever objectives the game throws at you. At its core, the game asks you to pick a party, throw the party into a dungeon where they'll hopefully succeed. After this, the player will receive funds in return for a good performance, promptly wasting said funds recovering party members from basically unavoidable mental injury and funding the next expedition's quasi-mandatory set of supplies. This will / may leave the player with a very, very small margin of profit. Since money is so important to progress, half of the game will feel like a constant grind to stay just above debt. Losing out will often imply a huge scuffle just to recover from debt. Running out of funds will almost always mean the player will be losing recruits or a great deal of time just to get back on the treadmill, let alone back to progressing.

The core design doesn't help this. I love turn-based RPGs and I particularly love tough ones. My favourite RPG series ever is Shin Megami Tensei, for example. The difference is that, in those games, the player has more going on that they don't feel like all they're doing is fighting. That's more or less what I felt while playing this. I fight, then I fight some more, and then I fight a little bit more, and in the end I hope that I made slightly more money than I wasted.

I'd also like to add that for a game whose narrative is based around eldritch horror, it certainly is pretty safe with its monster designs.

Combat-wise, each and every enemy encounter feels designed specifically to kill or maim the player's progression as fast as possible. Some enemies are dedicated solely to inflicting large amounts of stress damage and they're often protected by beasts with over-inflated health bars and sometimes even spells to protect other members from direct harm. On paper this might sound alright, but in practice, since practically every move a player makes is subject to RNG, it's hard for the player to feel like they can control their fate.

The game is too reliant on dice rolls and that's fine, in theory. However, the enemies are not under the same pressure that the player is, so they can easily form all-out attack parties and stack debuffs on your recruits because losing their ranks doesn't matter. They are more-or-less subject to the same kind of dice roll the player is, so to some players that might feel fair. But since the AI has no sense of self-preservation, they can easily throw themselves at your party until it breaks.

This would also be okay, would it not be for the overwhelming odds. The developer has gone on record to state that they wish this game to feel like the player is constantly in a bad spot. I understand this mentality, but I think it didn't work out for them.

The game becomes grueling to the point of frustration and tedium -- where things happen completely outside of your control and you're somehow being asked to feel responsible for something you couldn't possibly prevent. It's like saying you worked hard to win the lottery.This is one example of a new genre I call Badge of Honour" games. Games which live and die through unfairly punishing design and are extremely contingent on clicking with the audience -- being able to say you've "beaten" Darkest Dungeon will become a badge of honour and very few people want to admit they won because they got lucky

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Alright, the fights are in theory kind of fun. But there is so much in this game that makes no sense and annoys the heck out of me:

1. To much luck, to much randomness:
You have no indicator at all what will await you in a dungeon and what items you might need. No idea at all if the box you look into will be good or bad. The quirks your heroes get on every corner are also something you cannot control, doesn't matter if it's a good or negative one, no idea what enemies will await you. No idea or control about who the enemy will attack in your group. Pure frustration

2. Slow & Repetitive:
The battles, the animations, everything is so slow. A fight could be over in 3 minutes, but thanks to the slow animations you need 15!!! Also you will want to strangle the voice who tells me the 50th time in a dungeon that my luck might be turning. Less frequent please or more tracks.

3. Makes no sense:
So much makes 0 sense in this game: You buy items to go into a dungeon but if you don't use them they are magically gone afterwards. And the money you paid for them with it. And because you have no idea what awaits you in a dungeon it's a pure lucky guess if you buy the right items or not. Your heroes feel more like civilians than warriors. 50% of the game consists of sending them into overpriced bars/hospitals/churches to tend to their breakdowns. And you should spend a ton of your time to look into which hero likes what best and remembering it.

I'm sorry, but this game must be made by SEO, because it's formula is to frustrate and punish the player on every single corner. Not because it's hard, but because you can also let a monkey play it as there is so much luck and crap involved. Haven't played such a really really bad game in a long time.

I've played it very early and did hope that after almost a year it got better, but if something it only got worse.

reviewText:
Too hard? Probably not. Too random and time consuming? Yes. 100% yes.

I love RNG based games, especially Isaac, Nuclear Throne and XCOM, but this is plain annoying and unfair. I went into it having read the disclaimers and after seeing lots of gameplay, but unless you're into early Gygax style killing off of characters you will NOT enjoy this, the rebuilding takes sooo long and is all about grinding.

That is the only reason for the negative review, but it was enough for me.

Artwork, the other mechanics, sound, style are top notch, which makes me even madder at the difficulty.
I'll continue watching Let's Plays and streams for Darkest Dungeon, but that will only be to see people suffer...

reviewText: This was a very promising game but the recent changes have pushed it from a challenge to a tedious grind fest. Even if you succeed in the grind, the RNG will kill you. For a game that was advertised by hyping the strategy required to beat it and the brutality that came with it, it worked in the beginning. The brutality is still there but now that skill requirement has been stripped in favor of the RNG kneecapping you at every opportunity. Can this game recover? Absolutely, if the devs take the game back to a skill focus rather than a randomization focus. For now, stay away, very far away.\n\n*edit-Well the game is here and while many things have change the RNG kneecapping is still in the mix. It is better but I still cannot reccomend this game. Maybe things will change with the continued support but it is highly doubtful.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Great game when I first bought it, but a recent patch having introduced a frankly inconvenient and unfun mechanic (corpses) in a game that's already dangerously RNG and frustration prone makes me have to change my review. If you hate yourself or play nothing but difficult and frustrating games that function off high risk low reward, you'll still love this game, but if you're a casual gamer or generally don't enjoy RNG-driven difficulty spikes then avoid this for now.

This IS a fun game, but it could really use a difficulty toggle that doesn't penalize your gains so much that playing on easy actually makes you suck more in the long run, since you gain less loot and gold, for only a small decrease in difficulty.

The game would greatly benefit from letting you play on easy for the first few dungeons you run and clear, and then gradually ramping up the reward curve for playing on hard so as to incite you to get comfortable and increase difficulty at your own pace. But also, it would benefit from easy being easier. As it is right now it really is just a self-imposed penalty on gains for only a tiny decrease in difficulty, and RNG can still totally screw you over anyway.

TL;DR: Easy mode not easy enough, imposes huge penalty for almost no gain, especially combined with RNG. Latest patches have been pandering to the vocal minority asking for a harder more tedious game, alienating casual players. Game desperately in need of a game mode to separate players.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has A LOT of potential, but falls very short of the mark. Let me give a quick synopsis of it.

You are trying to reclaim your family's estate from dark forces. You recruit adventurers from the town to perform various quests, all involving adventuring in dungeons. You will have the ability to upgrade your party's skills and equipment, in addition to equip them with trinkets that can help or hinder them. There is a very diverse spectrum of character classes and builds that you can recruit, along with both positive and negative traits.

Building a party of 4 adventurers whose skills benefit and support each other is key to adventuring successfully. While you adventure you will find treasure, trinkets, and heirlooms". The latter of which you can use to upgrade the resources in the town to better support your adventurers. During your adventures your characters will not only take health damage
date: they will also gain STRESS. Varying factors can cause stress

reviewText: From every harsh review I've seen, I felt like I had to do a review on my own. So here it is.\n\nDarkest Dungeon. Bought it from ♥♥♥ for like 15$ a year ago. Definitely worth it. People are saying that the game's ruined because of the patch. I decided to play the game again after some break, 3 months maybe. It didn't impress me, I don't know what people are being so mad about, moreover, I'd even say the game is easier than it was. More classes = more choices in the dungeons, more compositions. It's not a surprise that you are losing in every dungeon if you don't upgrade your armor or abilities, God damn. Im still loving the game, it still annoys me when my enemy is dodging my attacks like crazy, but nothing has changed in that because of the patch. Im still rating the game 9/10. The perfect ten will happen if the final dungeon will give me a challenge. Peace.

reviewText:
Pretty graphics, amazing atmosphere, decent soundtrack but imo bad game.

It is more Grindan Dungeon than Darkest. Repeat the very same dungeon again and again and again like you are living Groundhog Day. The enemies just scale with you, so the game stay the same at level 2 with 4 hours played and at level 6 with 20.

The mechanics of the combat are simplistic even if you have dozens of perks, abilities or attacks. At the end  you just see that almost all of them are gimmicks and that you can crush the game with a very limited set of them using just 4 cloned teams focusing on damage and a lot of time to expend on a game.

I would like to give the game a neutral recommendation as a lot of people like the grinding and this is not as bad as other JRPG games, but if you are looking for a complex game that will make you think what are you doing and why (classic x-com, JA2, Silent Storm, Invisible inc), try others because this  pretty game is not going to offer you that kind of gameplay.

If you like *grinding mechanics = buy it
Don't = Avoid like the plague

*Grinding means trivial and repetitive -cloned- tasks

reviewText:
Early Access Review

EDIT 6/21/15

Keep in mind this review is from Early Access.

With 50+ hours into the game, I have experienced most of the content the game has had to offer. Personally, I had to restart a save file two seperate times to get the ball rolling right. If you like games that punish you when you take the easy way, but reward you if you can adapt to the curve and dwell in the darkness, then this is the game for you.

Here are my thoughts, the good and the bad:

Pros:
- Harsh gameplay mechanics (for those who like a challenge)
- The art style and gritty aspects of the dungeons
- The classes and the strategic combos you can set up with the various skill sets
- High risk, high reward (generally)

Cons:
- RNG can definitely kill a good run and be frustrating at times
- End game content is non-existent (early access)
- Repetitive grind to advance your characters (Randomly generated dungeons get to a point of just being giant checker boards of doom)
X The inability to sell relic trinkets, the inability to sell base upgrade resources (They have added the ability to sell trinkets)

Overall this is a great game with great potential, hoping to see more updates soon! Personally, I only recommend the game as I have enjoyed my time playing it, but if you are looking for a title with more content to dig into you may want to pass until a beta stage, or final release.

reviewText:
You meet a woman named Vesper Lynd on a train to Montenegro. She has been sent to protect the British government's $10 million buy-in for a high stakes poker game.

You start the tournament that night. Playing against the only other person in the room who can match you, a French financier of terrorism named Le Chiffre.

You feel confident, you are sure you know your opponent's tell. After the first break, you follow your opponent only to be attacked with your partner Vesper by a Ugandan freedom fighter. You barely escape his machete and kill him with your bare hands.

Vesper is traumatized, but you are here to comfort her and her prickly exterior gives way to your manliness. But then you lose all of your money when Le Chiffre tricks you and takes you all in.

Not only do you lose your money, but you lose Vesper's trust and she refuses to fund you in the game. Luckily a CIA agent is willing to spot you as long as you promise to let the US bring Le Chiffre in.

After coming back into the game, you quickly build up your losses. Le Chiffre, not willing to lose, poisions your drink and you are literally on Death's Door, before Vesper brings you back.

After recovering" from the poison and despite the debuffs

just before you break you are saved by Mr. White who comes in and shoots Le Chiffre.

Because of everything you've been through Vesper has clearly fallen in love with you and you with her. You resign from MI6 because you've finally found something worth living for.

You travel with your new love to Venice. Soon after

reviewText: This game is amazing... -ly difficult. It's actually not difficult, it's unfair. The game is a bit of grind and plays like a dungeons and dragons style RPG. The art and gameplay are awesome. The music also creates some horrific ambience, although it gets repetitive. The leap in difficulty in the later dungeons is just stupid; for example, I walk my group (ready for a fight, healthy, upgraded, and eqquipped) into an encounter and watch my entire group get wiped without even having a chance to respond. The game makes all of your previous efforts a giant, demoralizing, punch line. THE GAME IS FUN, BUT it just gets ridiculously difficult and not in a way that feels challenging, it is completely unfair and I stopped playing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have to say that this game is one of my favorites. 9.3/10

You will face hard-♥♥♥ enemies, you will fail probably even more than win, you will get frustrated because you let your higher level, well-equiped and fully upgraded hero die. But in the end, when you complete a dungeon alive a smile will pop in you face.

The game is all about grinding. The more dungeons you complete, the more gold you have to spend in upgrades and trinkets (equipments for your heroes). Each dungeon has a reward, and there are three kinds of dungeons: you have a short dungeon - it has fewer rooms - and its easier to complete, you also have medium dungeons - it has an considerable amount of rooms - and you get a campfire, with you can set a camp and rest/buff you heroes mid-quest, and last but no least you have long dungeons - it has a lot of rooms - you will have to go through a huge amount of rooms in order to complete those kind of dungeons.

You also have to set a strategy before going into an adventure. In certain areas of the game, monster will be more resistent as certain kind of DoT (damage over time) than others. Keep it in mind when you`re think in bring a Plague Doctor to the Weald, or remember to have a Crusader in you party when you`re going to the cursed Ruins.

You will also have to manage resources before going to an adventure. You can buy torches, food, antivenom, bandages etc. Everything to raise the chances of your crew to return alive to the town. I`d say that is still possible to complete a dungeon without bringing anything, but you`ll have to retreat 99% of the time.

Well, if world isn`t perfect, why should this game be?

After about 100 hours I`ve reached the max level with every class in the game, killed all the bosses, collected all the ancestral items and my town was fully upgraded. Well, there was anything more to do. You still have dungeons to complete, but as I said the fun part is the grinding, and when you finish grinding you don`t have much to do. You definitely can still have fun, challenging yourself to do a dark run (without torches) and so on, but that`s up to you.

I`d highly recommend this game for everyone who enjoy play RPG, turn-based like games. This game is totally worth the $15 you have to pay.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is not for everyone, or really most people. You'll like this game if:

1) You like having to replace party members due to death or them not being able to function
2) You like misleading probabilities; 70% misses much more than you would think
3) You like having to contstantly manage your group's inability to function after a few encounters
4) You prefer debuffs to buffs. Every enemy gives you a debuff with almost every attack.
5) You like failing missions or having a high chance to fail every mission
6) You like very slow progress which can even--and does--go backwards
7) You like being punished investigating your environment
8) You like having to frequently and involuntarily rearrange your group order; group order determines what skills you can use
9) You don't like using high level characters on all content. Level 3's can not do level 1 and 2 areas. Level cap is 6.
10) You like playing games that feel stacked against you in every part of the game
11) You like every item to have a negative stat to balance the positive stat it grants


Basically, play this game if you don't care if you succeed and want a hard game that is hard because it is unfair. You will be frequently punished, and it will be completely unavoidable and random. The game mechanics are interesting, but they beat you down so much that it makes it really hard to stay motivated to play.

reviewText:
Since I am a massive XCOM fan I assumed I would absolutely love Darkest Dungeon and for the first few hours I did.

The combat seemed deep and varied. There are so many character classes such that I have not used them all let alone try all possible permutations of a four adventurer party. Managing your hamlet is just as stressful as combat when deciding where to spend your hard earned resources. I opted to boost the strength of my party by focusing on the guild and blacksmith but every so often I had to throw some resources to help my adventures recover from all the horrors they had seen.

It felt like I had a rich game that I was going to lose myself in for days.

But after those first few hours I realized that I felt I wasn't making any real progress. Sure I had a few adventures at level two but I wasn't really making enough money to actually upgrade their skills and equipment. I also never seemed to be sending out the same party composition more than once. The stress would be too great or some malady was would afflict an adventure and they would have to miss a week of adventuring while I spent some gold healing them up. The caravan never really seemed to bring me much variety (could I please have more than one Arbalst?) so it forced me to put together so many patchwork party compositions because I just didn't have the ones I wanted to try. Also, every time I came back from a quest I didn't really have enough money to do any major upgrades to my characters such that I felt I was ready for the next challenge.

It was at this time that I had realized I had already entered the grind of the game. I had only been doing lvl 1 short quests (either complete every room battle or explore 90% of rooms) and I was already at a point where I felt like I needed to grind for hours to make enough progress to even attempt the first boss of the game.

But OK this is a hardcore game right? Maybe I'm just playing it wrong. I set myself a goal of attempting one of the first bosses, the Swine Prince, and I picked out a party that I thought would work well and aimed to get them to level two with level one skills and armor (since my guild or blacksmith was not upgraded enough to get everything to level two). I grinded for four more hours and got exactly what I wanted and equiped my party with the best trinkets I had, provisioned them to the gills and out I went. I explored the dungeon and didn't even need to camp before I scouted the boss's lair. It was at this point where things went completely sideways. I managed to kill the boss but I lost three of my four party members. All of that time and energy was gone without much to show for it. All the gold I got for beating the boss was essentially a moot point because I would need to spend it all again to upgrade new adventurers to have that same level of skill and equipment. With respect to the boss battle I felt like I could have retreated and gone back to the hamlet with my spoils. But I would have to spend a lot of gold to reduce the stress and afflictions they had acrued on the quest so it feels like it would have been a moot point.

But again this is a hardcore game! I just gotta git gud! I mean I made progress right? Killing one of those first bosses means something does it not? Let's pick out a second boss and try again. So I picked out the Wizened Hag, put together a team, grinded for two hours to get them where they needed to be (some this time had level two armor because I finally got enough freakin' deeds) and set out into the dungeon. It went every much like the first where I got to the boss without needing to camp and I made my attempt. This time only two of my four adventurers died, although the other two came back with such high stress that they won't ever been quite the same.

And so I am back again to where I was before I decided it was time to attempt my first boss. I have a stable of adventurers that are in no shape to make any attempt on the next boss let alone an attempt at a level three dungeon. None of my healers are above level zero since they've all died so I'll need to grind them up again. But I could do it. I could pick a boss, pick a party composition, grind 2-4 more hours doing the level one dungeons and make another attempt. Odds are I'll lose some adventurers again but thats a point of the game. How does a player deal with such great loss? To me though the grind is just far too obvious that it makes it much easier to just put down the mouse and keyboard and walk away. Its far too clear that I'll have to just grind the same dungeons over and over again, kill the same creatures and then go into another boss battle completely blind where I am likely to come away with some heavy losses. And after I kill all four of the starting bosses I'll be essentially in the same position as I was before with the exception of my hamlet being a little more upgraded. But at that point I'll have to do all of this over again for level three dungeons and I think that I need something else to pull me throught his grind.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This 2D turn based RPG is one of the best surprises to come out of early access in a very long time. The fact that it came out already a good game is something of a godsend in the sea of unfinished products that we seem to be getting more and more off lately. Having your heroes and a town you slowly upgrade and bring into their own is a very good feeling, as you always feel like you are doing some amount of good at least.

However a game is not without its flaws as the game doesn't really progress all that much, though it takes a heck of a long time to feel it since you need to constantly have the same heroes. Another problem I found is a slight lack of attachment to the heroes, as they may all have their own drives and wants, but... They hardly ever stick around long enough for you to attach to them and soon you become appthetic to their deaths Oh well another one for the corpse pile" And that just shouldn't be in my opinion

Overall a lovely game and well worth the money."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I wrote up a big review but apparently 16000 character is more than Steam will allow. Here's a link.
http://pastebin.com/WwDbZ4AC

An outtake to sum up my review:

Here is what I expected when I purchased Darkest Dungeon: a modern take on roguelikes with interesting attrition-based mechanics that require clever tactics to overcome, a variety of hero classes which can be combined into parties that capitalize on different ways of playing the game, and a challenge which was meaningful and fulfilling to overcome.

I did not get these things. What I got was a sub-standard dungeon crawler with masochistic tendencies and a design philosophy that discourages strategic and tactical thinking. Alongside this is a meaningless progression grind that would make any mobile tower defense game proud.

It's an exercise in rolling dice that requires a large investment of time for little to no satisfaction.You will grind for hours to kit out a team to take on the end bosses but your victory rarely feels earned - careful planning and team structure will not win the day, lucky crits and blasting everything with all the ♥♥♥♥ you can muster will.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Simple adventurer management paired with rough roguelike dungeon crawling wrapped in amazing atmosphere sums up as Darkest Dungeon!

It is a fascinating, even hypnotic game to play. From UI to gameplay everything transfers swiftly, yet without breaking the immersion or atmosphere. The story is simple and goes well with the gameplay. Enviromental design, art style, narrator voice and the choice of words paint an awesome, yet grim, Warhammer Fantasy-style feeling in the canvas of your mind. Several times, I have found myself sitting in front of my screen playing one more dungeon" and doing "little more management".

In it's core Darkest Dungeon is a hardcore gaming experience that needs time and dedication to learn and master. More I learn
date: more I realize the outcome is in my hands. There is surprisingly little weight on RNG when compared on many other roguelikes. At times things have felt unfair but later the realization of mistakes has stroke me. For a singleplayer game
hoursPlayed: the feelings of victory and defeat are strong and enjoyable. They remind me of Dark Souls
voteText: Faster Than Light and This War of Mine.\n\nPS. I recommend renaming or adding nicknames to  your subjects whenever you feel like so. It creates a nice bond between You and your lackeys. However

reviewText:
The Short of It:

If you like permadeath, RPGs that have much tactical depth without a steep learning curve, and gorgeous, if slightly static, art, Darkest Dungeon will not disappoint you. It's punishing and difficult, but these nightmarish creatures can be felled, they can be beaten.


The Long of It:

Throughout Early Access, people's opinions on the game have shifted harder than a Cultist being bombarded by a Bounty Hunter's Flash Bang, which is the main reason you'll still see negative reviews, but the solution the developers finally settled on has been the absolute best one, and people not updating their reviews to reflect this is the main reason some reviews are still negative.

Darkest Dungeon is a dark dungeon crawler (heh), where you lead a party of four heroes and the items you provide for them into the depths, time and again, hoping every time they'll make it out alive, knowing the possibility is very real that they won't - and if they do, they might be so traumatized and mentally scarred that you decide to let them spend the rest of their lives wandering, impoverished and unhinged.

The entire game balances on the question, 'what are your heroes worth'? Given the constant influx of new hopefuls, it'll be very tempting to dismiss heroes or send them on a suicide mission to recover as much loot as possible, simply because you can't afford to take care of them. Because while wounds of the body heal, wounds of the mind do not, at least not without a sizeable cost in gold.

That is not to say all your heroes are doomed. They can win fights and clear dungeons, grow stronger and become Heroes worthy of a capital 'H', champions honed and trained for one purpose: to brave the depths of the eponymous Darkest Dungeon.

When your characters aren't delving in the depths of the Dankest Dungeon, you have 'free' time to upgrade the hamlet, adding some modest but interesting base building to the mix. With the heirlooms your heroes collect from the dungeons, you can upgrade buildings, whose functions range from upgrading weapons and armour to curing stress and disease or selling trinkets. Unless of course, the heirlooms remain forever in the dark, clutched in the dead hands of your adventurers.


The Right of It

You will get attached to your heroes, and the threat of them dying when they set out into the depths is always very real, but good preparation can minimize that risk. Darkest Dungeon uses a Random Number God who may throw a wrench in even the best-laid plans, but with the game's immensely clever and dynamic combat system, good planning and calculated responses to unexpected circumstances will do much to win the day.

So no, you have no direct control over the numbers, but yes, you can make a very significant difference as the player without success or failure hinging on die rolls. Character classes are so diverse (and individually customizable) that the possibilities of combining them are endless, and a good combination and positioning of characters is a fun challenge every time you assemble a team, as is a clear-headed response when enemies mess up your formation and heroes start having to fight in positions they're not accustomed to.

The base building aspect, while slightly grindy, is a streamlined but functional and efficient element, and seeing your hamlet get restored from a ruined ghost town to a thriving community is a joy to watch - even though the graveyards are packed with heroes who died to make it happen.

All this takes place in a world full of gothic, dark beauty, with an art style that never bores, even though the game consists mostly of still images, animated and moved to reflect what happens. This isn't to say that the game is a boring slideshow - the camera moves and pans, visual effects splatter off the screen, and thanks to good animation, the entire world is moving and alive.

Add a highly evocative narrator, Wayne June, who provides tons of atmosphere while hamming it up to just the right levels, and you've got a gripping experience that'll keep you engaged during every moment.


The Wrong of It

If you like high-poly 3D-models, motion capped animations and lighting that makes your 980TI Titan chug, then you'll probably want to pass on this. But it would be your loss, since the amazing art style and execution is more efficient and powerful than any amount of realism could ever be. The animators did a wonderful job too, making the still images come alive as the action unfolds.

Also, be aware that Darkest Dungeon is difficult. You'll need to stay focused if you wish to survive, because even trash mobs (and there aren't many of those) can devastate a party if the player's concentration lapses. Because of this, heroes will die. If you get attached to your heroes, like I do, this can be difficult to deal with. All players so far consider Darkest Dungeon's difficulty to be a plus, but if you want to just play a game and have fun without thinking too much, you might consider the difficulty a stumbling block.

Be aware that you can - and probably should - turn off many difficulty options introduced by the devs in Early Access to discourage certain tactics or make the game more hardcore, and that's a good thing. Some of those options were, with good reason, seriously disliked by most EA players, including myself, for making the game unfairly difficult.


The Last of It

Darkest Dungeon is a must have for any role player, save-scum hater, tactics fan, or really anyone who likes a solid challenge (s)he can overcome with clever and tactical thinking. In fact, I can recommend it to everyone except people who play video games purely as a relaxing distraction after a hard work day, because it does require concentration and active thinking.

Seriously, people, Red Hook created a masterpiece.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A very pretty game, however ultimately hostile towards fun.

I love the fact the developers wrote their own engine since most general ones (Unity, Unreal) are not so great for 2D-only games. The 2D animations, instant load times and nice UI effects make for a pretty sight.

However, as hard as I tried, I haven't really had any fun playing. The game is difficult, in a way where you don't really get to feel angry about your decisions and in the end learn from your mistakes. Rather, you end up feeling like you're constantly out of luck.

There are 2 phases in the game : exploring dungeons, and managing your party back in the town between adventures.

In the dungeon is where the luck element gets into play, and that could be fine. But unfortunately, the state of your party degrades exponentially rapidly. So you need to be in excellent shape for more than half of the dungeon in order to have a chance at finishing it. It rarely feels like you barely make it out alive; you either die far from the end, or you clearly had incredible luck / too powerful a party for that dungeon's level of difficuly.

Also, there are so many events and animations that I felt I was watching the game play against itself in fights. When it's finally your turn to do something, out of the 4 abilities each of your character has, there was rarely the feeling that some tactical thinking was in order. I would more or less select the offensive ones one by one, then hover above a monster to get an idea of the hit probability, then cross my fingers. There is not really any worthwile build-up of buffs, as they are not that good, and losing a turn buffing yourself is dangerous. Fights were not very exciting to me.

Finally, when your party is surprised by enemies, your order is basically shuffled, which means some characters won't be able to act at all. You then need to spend one or more turn rearranging your positions, which is madenning since you don't know in which order your characters will act, and since they cannot always move to any given position in one go. All the while getting attacked, and not retaliating. Not very fun all in all.

Meanwhile, in town, some design decisions made me wonder about the developer's intentions. For example, if you need to send a couple party member to the church or tavern for stress relief, you basically have to go in each building, figure out first which slots will be available to each character, which is not really fun. But then once you commit to a slot and pay, you won't get your money back if you need change your assignments. Since stress relief can easily cost more than 50% of your income, this is kinda frustrating. Please, just let me select heroes that I want to have a relaxing time, and show me options, instead of the manual, error prone and unfun assignment.

Also, when preparing to delve into a dungeon, you need to buy supplies, but anything you don't use is not refunded or kept for another go. I do not really see the point in this; there is enough reliance on the random number generator in this game without having us wild guessing how much money should be wasted on items. This just leads to grinding for more money.

Pros:
Great engine, great UI, pretty as hell
Great writing supported by even greater voice acting
Cons:
Difficulty stems from luck rather than tactics; I'm not sure I could get much better at the game
Frustrating design choices in the Town phase
Fun is not something I would describe this game as being. Not really frustrating either, just kinda boring :(

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The immersion of this game is friggin' fantastic.

Everything in this game fits together so well: the music, the atmosphere, the action... It all works together. That cinematic trailer for Darkest Dungeon? It really captures exactly how the game feels.

In combat, the music is tense, and the camera zooms into attacks for effect. It's very quick, so no time is wasted, but it makes every attack feel exciting and apprehensive. There is a narrator that really pumps up the excitement as well, commending a crit or a kill... or a loss. When your stress limit hits 100%, the hero's resolve is tested... and there's a brief pause... will he become Courageous and rally his comrades? Or will he become Hopeless and become the doom of everyone?

Town mechanics are pretty neat too. You upgrade the town facilities using these items you collect from your adventures, but you upgrade/fix your heroes using the gold you have accrued. This separation of resources is nice, because it lets you focus your gold on party management.

Party management is pretty nifty but simple. Between adventures in dungeons, you can put various party members in the tavern or abbey to relieve the stress they have added up through adventuring. You can also slowly eliminate negative afflictions that your heroes have.

The game's main gimmick is Stress". As your heroes fight in the dungeons
