reviewText:
There's not that many negative reviews, so I'll give it go.  I'll sing some praise first, since the game is ok.

I won't list everything that's good about Darkest Dungeon (DD), but it does have a lot of goodness tucked away inside.  I really love the artistic style, and turn based combat for example.  These two things drew me to DD.  Stress is a gimicky mechanic, I could take or leave.  It works and adds something to the game play, even though there are times I wish it didn't.

The real problems for me is game pacing, variety, and length.

I've found that pacing is one of those things that rpg's in general have a poor time getting just right.  DD over complicates it by using five different currencies, and then in a rather miserly fashion not giving them out in any quantity.  To add to the worries, bag space is extremely limited, so even if you find some great hoard you might not profit by it.  Oddly enough, the exp gains might be spot on, but without the other resources your party will quickly be outmatched so there's no way I can tell for sure.  Essentially, you'll be forced to start over at some point and rebuild a team with fewer flaws, and hopefully higher earning potential.

The rebuilding of a team isn't bad in itself.  I think it fits the atmosphere the game is going for.  This does lead to problems though.  All of the heroes are rather cookie cutter.  That's not bad presuming that you'll be burning through a lot of expendable characters.  On the downside, there's no reason to be invested in any of them either.  Additionally, every dungeon run is more or less exactly the same.  There are, I don't know, three, four different quest objectives?  Each zone a handful of unique mobs, plus a handful that could appear in any zone.  It leads to dungeon runs where the only objective is to smash and grab while min/maxing the curios and bag space as best you can.  It's too expensive to take stress damage, or risk a negative quirk.  So you find your little strategy, and more or less do the same things in dungeons you could hardly tell apart.

If this game clocked in at 20 hours from start to finish, I'd feel better about it.  It's not.  There are eight bosses, each of which requires some number of zone specific dungeon grinds to open, and has to be killed three times, at slightly more difficult levels.  Why?  just because. . . I'm almost through now, and I like the game enough to finish, and possibly restart it, but come on.  Have some respect for my time.  I've also read some spoilers about the ending.  All I can say is for real?

DD is a good game mired in poor design.  Everything seems to work, which is a big plus.  Guess it's suppose to be hardcore?  There are times it just feels like a hardbore, or a hardchore.  It's not at all bad, it just isn't that great once you get your teeth into it.

Overall, I'd recommend a pass on this one, unless you can get it on sale.  There are some neat things to see, but once you've seen them, you'll see them again and again, and again.

reviewText:
The problems with the Darkest Dungeon since it got its full release is not that it's harder. Or that the RNG is against you. For me, the problem is if you don't look up youtube videos and read the wiki cover to cover, the gameplay sucks. There's no trial and error, because your party will be wiped out, your gold reserves emptied and you'll have to start again and go through the painfully long tutorial. There are so many times where I've found a boss, tried to fight them only to realise that they endlessly summon. By the time you've worked out that this is indeed a bossfight, you've lost. I'm all for no hand holding, but DD seems to delibrately deny you any clues on what the hell is going on until it's too late.

EDIT: I wrote this review quite late and upon looking at it again, see I've left off the end. There IS a good game, once you get past the ridiculous learning wall. The aesthetic is brilliant, the difficulty, once you've thoroughly read the wiki, is just right to be always challenging. The gear upgrade is a bit pointless, as are the skill levels. However, it's rather made up for by the plethora of trinkets you can equip to tweak your characters' stats.
Overall, this is a good game if you have the patience to persevere, but I couldn't recommend it as it is with so much vital information witheld from the player.

reviewText:
EDITS AT BOTTOM
Darkest Dungeon is a fantastic game, however I cannot recommend it to everybody. To truly play Darkest Dungeon you must be prepared to be flogged, punished and beaten to a pulp by the game and it's harsh rules. I cannot recommend Darkest Dungeon to everybody, because not everybody is a flagellant who revels in abuse and hardship, who can withstand the stress and push on with their resolve tested and steadfast but be wary, as your great ancestor says triumphant pride precipitates a dizzying fall.

A big part of Darkest Dungeon, and another reason why I cannot recommend it to everybody, is that you must learn harshly from your mistakes and correct them in future endeavors. Not everybody has the stubbornness, not everybody can get over a setback, because after all failure tests the mettle of heart, brain and body but heart most of all. I consider myself masochistic enough to enjoy this game but even I have had moments of quiet contemplation wondering whether it really was worth it to continue.

There is another component of Darkest Dungeon which will shy a lot of weaker-willed people away. Luck. I don't consider myself a gambler, and I don't get thrills from playing the numbers, so personally, I'm not a huge fan of the way that luck is used in Darkest Dungeon. If you are not prepared to take risks, to compromise for chance and to expect the worst Darkest Dungeon is going to walk all over you. Almost literally every factor in the entire game is dictated by a roll of the dice and dice being the fickle ivory cuboids that they are, have no allegiance. One dungeon you might roll full sixes with a great layout and constant critical hits but in another, snake eyes.

Now that I have outlined what makes this game challenging I would like to address the other reviews for Darkest Dungeon. You may be confused when you see the amount of negative reviews in the helpful section. I don't want to say that they're salty and that the people who vote them as helpful are salty, but what I will say is that many of them call for a rebalance patch, quite often on the grounds that the game used to be easier, now it's harder or it's just difficult or unreasonable or a grindfest and therefore not fun. Personally I don't believe that darkest dungeon is meant to be fun, at least not to everybody. Darkest Dungeon is meant to be a challenge, an obstacle to overcome something to work at. The game is far from impossible and if you lack the mettle, courage and perserverance to withstand the effort to triumph, you need to try harder and learn from your mistakes before slapping a boo-hoo I failed and had to restart but I refuse to learn from my mistakes and improve" negative review on it
TLDR: The game isn't meant to be fun for everybody get over yourself and realize not every game is tailor made to your preferred difficulty cap before you post a heavily opinionated review that doesn't help anybody understand jack.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When I saw Darkest Dungeon I felt in love !
And I rarely buy a game at first sight...

But let me explain what is Darkest Dungeon. [Long Review]



Plot:

After his suicide, an old relative in his last will reveals that you will inherit of an estate cursed by an old evil dungeon.
You decided to claim your property and bring back order to this land.
But on the way your coach is attacked. Leaving you and your body guards surrounded by cutthroats and bandits. After having dealt with them, you arrive at the miserable and gloomy village that belongs to you.
Now starts your adventure, you will bring back the old stability of the village and purify the land and, maybe, put an end to the terror lying in the nearby ...  Darkest Dungeon.


Layout:

Darkest Dungeon is a dark and mature rpg. You mission is clear, get rid of monsters that threaten your estate with the help of warriors and the village that belongs to you. The ultimate goal is to reach the guardian of the Darkest Dungeon to put to an end the madness that curses the land.

The main aspect of the game is psychology. Indeed, every character is affected by its environment, especially in the dungeons. The light in corridors, actions like opening a chest or triggering a trap, resting and even fighting can stress your warriors and make them weaker with debuffs called: Quirks.
Of course you have many ways to reduce it, the most important is the village where you can unlock and upgrade buildings dedicated to relax your characters.

But beware, death is inevitable and permanent. And it's a part of the game to create teams of 4 characters with different   set of skills/ classes and be able to cycle between them to explore and accomplish quests effectively

Venturing into dungeons needs planning, you can select characters, their skills (4 max per warrior), equipment and supplies because into dungeon they need to eat, to light their way and use items to counters bad events such as debuffs after fights or random encounters like when you are stuck in front of rubbles and you need a shovel to go through with ease... but the shovel is expensive and takes place in your inventory like loot.
Even loot is a problem because money takes precious slots in your inventory!
To move in the dungeon you can use a little map to choose your direction or even see what you may encounter if you had the chance to scout the sector (random event), and after to progress in corridors using movement keys or mouse. Your group  walk in order until they find something and you will need to select one of them to activate an item that in general trigger a dice roll influenced by the skill of the character, the item you used with it or maybe the both.


The game is set around few phases:
Recruiting and management of your characters, Management of the village, Planning quests where you have to buy supplies/gear for your team, Exploring Dungeons and be back alive to take another team while the last one needs to go to the bar, brothel, abbey, sanitarium... to recover from the horrors they lived.



Gameplay:

Darkest Dungeon works around a good fighting system. Each party has 4 characters, they are ordered in a straight line where placement is important. Even skills depend of this placement. In general close combat fighters are in front line, slots 1 and 2. And healers and range units are in slots 3 and 4. This system is great especially in front of stress which is one of the most dangerous attacks your warriors will receive. Indeed some enemy units stay behind their buddies and send attacks that fill stress quickly. So even if you have a nice combat team with good damages and restorative effects, you will need someone capable to manage the placement of the enemy. By talking of the enemy, this is a real devil capable to focus on the weak ones, ambush you or even flush your team composition, leaving you in chaos and hurry to find the best formation to endure the fight.
The feeling during fights is extraordinary. At the beginning you will have problems to grasp the subtleties, like for the plague Doctor who is a marvelous crowd control that will save you if you use him correctly.
But when you get the overall idea, you will enjoy counter attacks or even some fights where the enemy is just unable to reach you. By the way it's a part of the game to stun enemy and use this moment to heal your team and go further.
Even light is important. It's a bar that shows the light you produce. The fact is, the more light you have, the better you heroes will be (less stress, less enemies). The funny thing is some items are related to this light meter" and even spawn rate of monsters. You want more challenge and money ? Try your luck into the darkness!

It's one of the many funny events this game has
date: like when you can camp in average and long dungeons to recover some health and reduce your stress and debuffs. During camping you use a completely different set of skills for each character that you can modify and upgrade like regular combat skills. The moral feature of the game is really funny especially when your team is totally exhausted and one of you characters (it depends of the class
recommended: Hellion is my favorite for that!) is inspired and during battle brings back his comrades moral and give them strength to win.\nAnd when your team is mad it can be the contrary
hoursPlayed: like when one of your guys does little damages or misses and one of his buddies humiliates him. Even passing the turn of a character makes him angry and increase his stress ! Consider that everything I said can be applied when things are right but in a weaker mesure

reviewText:
I'm really torn on whether to recommend this game or not. But for the reasons very well articulated in the top negative reviews, I can't do so in good faith.

Which is really too bad. This could be one of my favorite games. I'm not turned off by the difficulty, the RNG, or the  lack of gameplay variety (I'm a big fan of rogue-likes though). It's the grind that makes this game painful to play after the first (awesome) dozen hours. With just a handful of small changes, this could be a phenomenal 30-40 hour game. Instead, it's about an 80 hour game where the last 50 of those are grinding away to level up enough heroes to play the last level and collect enough money and relics to buy upgrades.

I checked out some past and current discussions, and the developers do look like good guys that are trying to make the best game that they can. I just don't agree with some of the high level design decisions. That's okay. They've produced a beautiful, smart game that unfortunately overstays its welcome with mechanics that turn it into a grindfest.
voteText: 27 of 49 people (55%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Out of the hundreds of games I played for the last 20-25 years few games made me feel the thrill and rush of experiencing something new, and yet here this game accomplishes the same sensation after all these years. But there is a catch, you will surely have lots of fun for the first 10 to 20 hours and after a while as you progress in the game your fun will diminish slowly and convert to frustration as you reach end game content. The game mechanics for the last dungeon (Darkest Dungeon) are what gamers has been complaining about. I have to admit that they are right, the game turns to be an absolute grinding cycle in the end.

I have started new games several times just to fiddle with different team compositions, different trinkets and different sets of skills. After all this hours of deep playing into the game I can surely say; Yes there are balance issues, and surely the end game grinding kills the fun out of it but if you ignore the last dungeon (at least until the devs decide to rebalance or change it) you are definitely looking at a gem.

Ps: The narration (although it gets repetitive after a while) is simply astonishing. I have to admit that I may have watched the intro at least a dozen times and started at least half a dozen new games just to watch the beginning cinematic :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The darkest dungeon is not fun and rewarding. Visually and Aurally it's flawless. - the dark reds and blacks perfectly complementing the endlessly grim atmosphere. As someone that collects rougelikes, I can handle random turn of events and sudden death - yet in this game there is a constant elongation of that death. You are slowly losing. Slowly being eaten away like a bunch of flies digesting a almost dead warrior with no eyes on a empty battlefield. Even in dark souls, a game known for its punishment - there is some degree of immediacy. This is quite literally - torture.

I admire that. I admire that some team of indie developers went out there, made a game so far departed from the norm. There is no game that quite feels like the darkest dungeon. And for that uniqueness, combined with the flawless presentation - This review is uniformly positive. However subjectively, I don't often want to actually play the damned thing. Because my time spent will involve slowly becoming as stressed as the protaganists as I am torn apart until there is nothing but an empty husk hobbling along a worn path of nothingness. While enemies point and laugh at my feeble attempts at carrying on. And in the end, that's what you do. Even if you win. You carry on. You don't come out powerful. Or even slightly enhanced. You survive another day of stress and hate.

Sounds a bit too much like my life.

reviewText:
Great, inspired game that falls short due to too much unexplained randomness.

Edit: I gave this game another shot and am having much more luck and fun, but problems still exist. Currently at week 30-40. I will say the randomness is not as much an issue as much as a lack of agency and the fact that the game does not give the player enough info to learn how to get better. In addition many of the challenges are simply asanine. Playing with higher level characters becomes unmangeable because it costs more to do even essential things such as treating for stress. Most of the time I see challenges being shoe-horned in just to be challenging rather than being clever, thematically relevant, logical, fun, etc....

Other examples:
-How is hunger processed? I had to eat twice on one run in the first 5 rooms, while in other runs with same team I ate once after many more rooms. If I spend 8 food in camp and then 1-2 rooms later have to eat again, this seems very illogical. It just doesn't make sense at all.
-Why does my character with 50+ dodge get hit several times in a row when my character with 5 dodge succeed 3/4 times?

You can get many hours of fun from this, but be warned that at a certain point it starts to feel like a time waster rather than a engaging challenge.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is violence porn for accountants.

Sadly, with the recent patches this games was turned from a difficult game which made you take tough decisions based on a careful risk/return analysis into a masochistic grindfest based on luck. All too often you see your carefully groomed, max-equiped level 5/6 chars killed in a single round of combat. From full health a hit/crit combo takes the character to death's door, leaving a nasty ticking damage on the character killing the character off as soon as his/her turn is up.
One has to understand that the death of such a character is an enormous setback because you have to grind a replacement through several lower level dungeon runs. The loss of gold and time is substantial. Basically, most of the time you grind through content you have already done ad nauseam in order to have another shot at a dungeon you actually want to play. And did I mention that the loss of a character early in a fight means that you have to quit the fight leaving all that hard-earned gear behind?

This isn't a game anymore. It is an experiment on how much frustration, pain and tedious time sinks people can suffer through in order to MAYBE achieve a particular goal. If that is your jam then by all means come and join the club!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When I fist got this game I found it amazingly fun. I would summerize the game as a rogue like party based dungeon crawl with some city building aspects. This game introduces a stress system that acts as a second bar of life. As the bar raises party memeber resolve is tested and can lead to some nasty effects. When the bar mexes out the character dies from a heart attack. Characters gain stress from going to dungeons and relieve stress through services in the city. Services take take time and force you to leave them behind to recover. I started enjoying this mechanic as it forced me to diversify my party, level up multiple people, and continually experience different class combinations. The dungeons are difficult and various mob and boss fights can easily get our of hand. A lot of the game turn into managment of city service slots, money for services, money for upgrades, money for dungeon supplies (these are important), and character stress.

I did really enjoy all the management aspects of the game until I finally was able to start leveling my pary members to level 3. Once a character reaches level 3 they can no longer run level the starter dungeons to help raise other party memebers. This ruined the game for me. The game is difficult and stress can kill characters of any level fairly easily if things get our of hand in an ambush. I did not ming struggling to unlock new tiers of content in the game but being forced to struggle in the lower level dungeons to attempt to level a new party memener to replace a higher level party memeber that died in the higher tier dungeon ruined all the fun I had in the game. Gaining levels in this game did not make a large difference in survival and allowing higher levels characters to shepherd lower level party members through dungeons for no XP gain would not be game breaking. It would not have been much easier but it would at least make the catchup process muchless stressful. The highest unlocked content would have been no easier by allowing this. This restriction just turned the game into an annoyingly grindy and unfun game in what appears to have been an attempt to make the game continually difficult and stressful. I am ok with diffiuclty but I think that it is ok for lower tier content to become easier as you progess the game.

reviewText: Not a bad game but the main opponent is the RNG.  There is a warning screen which tells you that your party will die throughout the game.  The problem is that most of it is out of your control.  In combat there is no active role, you pick what your people do and they do it, which means any damage you take and whether or not you hit is completely up to the computer. Taking too much stress damage? Your character isn't high enough level.  Not dealing enough damage?  Your weapons aren't upgraded enough.  Trying to do some easy missions for money to upgrade your characters?  Too bad.  They leveled and will only do harder missions.  All in all it's not a BAD game but there is too little control over the mechanics to make it feel worthwhile.  Go play Paper Mario or Fire Emblem.  Maybe buy this on sale.

reviewText:
Video review for people that prefer the format:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ndPw7SlVHOs

(This is a first impressions look at the game, i have not completed it yet)

Darkest Dungeon kicks so much ♥♥♥! It's a turn-based, dark RPG with a lot of depth. One thing I absolutely love about this game is that despite being a complex RPG, it's relatively easy to get into and it doesn't bombard you with popups and tutorials. You do have 1 quick tutorialish area at the beginning which tells you the basics. When something is about to happen in the game that is a key mechanic, the game gives a window with a brief explanation of how it works. it doesn't give you a 5 paragraphic essay that you have to read through with tons of examples you don't need. It does a good job of explaining these things within a paragraph or two, and that's great because this game is HARD. However, it's also fair for the most part.

What makes this game special compared to most turn-based RPGs is how placement works. Most games might have a few usable abilities like a cleave that will affect a few people in the front, an aoe that affects everyone and that's usually it. Darkest Dungeon takes a leap forward with mechanics such as switching, large enemy types and corpses. Certain characters work best at certain positions and while it would be nice to see enemy unit move tables, it feel it would make the game much easier but still add depth. Certain abilities used by your characters can only be used while that character is at a certain position (far left, left, right, far right) and those abilities can sometimes only be used on enemies in certain positions (far left, left, right, etc). The game does a great job of telling you where characters would prefer to fight. These are always shown in the character menus which you can view by clicking on portraits or hitting the 'C' key when a portrait is highlighted. The switching mechanic also plays into this. You can switch the placements of characters in and otuside of battle, but in battle costs a character turn. Attacks can also switch people around (both on your side and on the enemy team's side). This adds a new level of depth, you could plow your way from the front to the back but there could be a annoying stress-damage ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ in the back who might be super week to a sword attack your knight might use because it's good again'st unhoy enemies.

That's another thing I should mention. There are a lot of modifiers in this game. From the debufs you get from playing (like getting stressed) to all your character abiltiies with various mods that can cause conditions like bleeding or blight. There are so many variables and team compositions to play around with adding so much customization for how you move out your party. God, we haven't even talked about the item system or the weapon/armor/spell upgrade system. THERE IS SO MUCH IN THIS GAME TO TALK ABOUT!

Animation, sound and art quality are outstanding. This game sucks you in to its dark and depressing world hard. Every completion of a dungeon feels stressful, as it should as stress is the main mechanic of the game. Stress can afflict debuffs to your party or even buffs at rare times. Your companions are not only battling monsters but also battling thier own psyche. You can relieve stress in the town but you have to still do dungeons if you want their stress to go down. They only lose stress when they are treated for a full in-game week, so it's a desperate struggle where you sometimes have to throw green-as-grass new characters at high level dungeons. Thankfully, new recruits are free and you can upgrade your roster. THAT'S ANOTHER THING, SO MUCH HNGGGGGG. You can upgrade buildings in town (treating more characters at a time in one area, better upgrades, etc) and you are still not even safe in towns. Stuff can happen when you are trying to relieve stress. Sending one of your guys off to gamble to relieve the pain of losing a comrad? Well he gambled away a rare item GG.

Overall, this is a great value at 20USD. You are totally getting your moneys work. If games stress you out easily, stay clear because you will die of a heart attack faster than your characters will.

If you are the type of person that needs a score, I'd give the game a 9/10. Extra information in my video review.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was initially unsure of whether to get this game or not.  I was excited and nervous based on the reviews.  I'll summarize the important aspects of the reviews that I found positive or negative.

Positive:
1. The game is hard
2. Your choices have permanent consequences (no redos)
3. The game mechanics offer depth and a variety of play styles
4. The atmosphere is awesome.

Negatives:
1. The game isn't so much hard as unfair (RNG) and tedious
2. The changes that led to Corpses and Heart Attacks made it even more tedious without enhancing gameplay.

Obviously, bought the game in spite of my fears.  I don't like tedium, so I figured I might turn off the most offending bits (corpses and heart attacks) but I'd try it with them first.

Almost immediately, I lost a character to a Heart Attack and found the corpses annoying.  I recognized the heart attack was my fault and could be easily avoided, so I left it on, but turned off corpses.  Played for awhile, until I had level 3 heroes, went into a level 3 dungeon and got owned.  I realized at that point, however, that I had made a lot of mistakes, had learned a lot about the game, and generally (aside from that dungeon) had found combat kind of easy and tedious.  I was using the same skills over and over and didn't think I was playing the game very well (which was confirmed for me by that level 3 dungeon).

I decided to start from scratch, w/ corpses on, and I like the game better as a result.  My heroes are happier and healthier, and I have more treasure.  A couple tips for enjoying the game:

1. Corpses don't need to be destroyed.  If you have ranged weapons, sometimes you want to keep the enemy further away.  I would say it's about 50-50 on whether corpses make a battle easier or harder.  Sometimes they ♥♥♥♥ me off, but sometimes I'm glad they're there.  They certain helped push me toward utilizing more skills, which honestly helps you be better prepared for when your characters are knocked out of order (btw, prepare for that!)

2. You either need to do one of the following
a) Read some guides.  Read up on the things you can interact with, what items you can use with them, etc.  Your heroes will be far less stressed and you'll get more loot.
b) Figure it all out yourself.  You'll need to treat some excursions as scouting missions (which they are...), interact in all sorts of ways with different objects, record the results, and don't hesitate to dispense with the broken husks of heroes who return to you, rather than wasting money repairing them.  This way takes longer, but can be fun.  This is true really for any new situation in the game....boss fights, etc.  If you don't read the scouting reports (guides) of others, you'll need to do your own scouting,  Your scouts will pay for your ignorance.

Is the game perfect?  Of course not.  Is the corpse mechanic kind of silly?  Sure.  With or without corpses, there are silly aspects to the combat.  The combat is stylized, so it's going to be weird at times, you just need to learn the rules.  My biggest complaint, actually, is that the system of skills and characters is actually too flexible.  It would be cool if there were missions that required certain characters (4 Crusaders, for instance).  Well, maybe there are or will be...I have a lot more game to play.  However, if you're like I was and sitting on the fence, worried about tedium, then I recommend buying the game and giving it a shot.

reviewText:
Having played this for some time now I could not recommend it in good taste. There is simply too many times where the games major mechanics are shown to be shallow and unfinished, or enemy types bland and uninteresting. The stress system seems interesting at first but quickly devolves into a second health bar that you can't reliably heal back to acceptable levels, combined with every other enemy having massive stress damage attacks makes progression painful and unrewarding.

Another issue is player control. In one of Valves in game commentaries for Half-Life 2 they stated that the best thing a developer can do is to never take control away from the player, even if they aren't actually in control they should at least feel as if they have some say in what happens in a situation. Darkest Dungeon takes player control away so often that it's bordering on absurdity. Randomly given quirks randomly cause your character to make random arbitrary choices in combat and at town, making it seem like you have no say at all in what happens in your party. Even if you complete a hard dungeon with 0 stress across the board theres still a hefty chance of your characters gaining up to two character destroying traits that make them dead weight and functionally dead to you.

The next issue is the diversity and balance of each of the dungeons. There's a forest, a ruin, a cove, and a city for the main dungeons. Each of these supposedly has a diverse set of enemies and challenges to face, but if you examine them closely they are nearly carbon copies of one another. The ruins has skeletons that act the same as the coves fish people, the cultists have a spellcaster that has nearly the same spells as the coves fish spellcaster, the pigs have the same support abilities as the fungal growths in the forest.

The main cause of all this sameness stems from the games shallow combat system, there are only two DOT's, one stun type, forced movement attacks and then normal damage with crits. This is not a recipe for replayability at all. There are simply too few ways for the enemy to fight the player, leading to stagnation. The game tries to add another layer of complexity in its stress system, but it falls flat, with it being a near unmanagable mess of too much stress and too few ways to mitigate it within the dungeon itself. The few characters that can mend stress heal it for so little as to not be worth it, why waste turns stress healing when you could be killing the enemy to stop the stress from being placed to begin with? The stress system is also very bottom heavy, it mostly affects newer characters and seems to dissappear by level 2-3, mostly serving to kill off fresh characters by having a skeleton splash wine on them for 10 rounds.

The stat system is also very oddly designed. Dodge works like in most games, by serving as a way to completely mitigate damage in echange for reliability, but most characters will not high high enough dodge stats to take advantage of it, and will instead opt in for the much more realiable and plentiful PROT stat which functions as a flat damage reduction. Most enemies also seems to have either 100% accuracy attacks, or attacks that hit so hard that even taking the chance of focusing on dodge and having it fail makes prot all the more worth while. Why even have the chance of taking a 20 damage attack on a 22 Health character when you can always reduce that 20 damage to 10 or less?

Sadly Darkest Dungeon is a trainwreck of balance issues and poorly implemented game mechanics overlaid with amazing art and stellar sound and voice work. It simply isn't worth the $20 in its current state, and likely never will be.

reviewText:
Darkest Dungeon is a party based dungeon crawler experience with a twist in its core setting: Stress.
Not every game puts on such an important topic in to a game as a core mechanic, and Darkest Dungeon shows it is an interesting mechanic that gets along with the whole game very well. The sad part is this game is not for everyone, especially for people who cannot take randomness or prone to making mistakes. Every action you do is permanent, and overcoming the RNG is the major part in Darkest Dungeon. Though these elements really do make the game way harder, it is very satisfying to see yourself overcome the Darkest Dungeon.
Artwork is unique and fits the game perfectly. The soundtrack is intense and makes you think twice before pulling a trigger. As far as I know, there is only one voice actor, and he does his job so well. Every comment he makes, in battle or in town, gives you goosebumps.
Darkest Dungeon may not be for everyone, but if you have a little bit of courage to make the best of the worst situations, you should buy this game.

reviewText:
Disclaimer: I'm a relatively casual gamer. I don't like to invest loads of time into a game if I can help it, so bear that in mind with my review, which I'll keep pretty short.

There's a lot about this game, visually and conceptually, that is amazing. The art is fantastic, the voice acting and music and overall sound design are loveable, character designs are nice, etc. There's a lot that, on the surface, makes this game seem like it's cream of the crop material. The turn based ascept is nice, and the concept of sanity and stress are good elements in this game. The story isn't all that bad either, and I like the idea of having adventurers going out to collect resources in order to improve a town over time.

That said, it's unforgiving. A lot of suffering in this game isn't a result of player mishaps like in other brutal games like Dark Souls or Bloodborne. Rather, combat is mostly RNG in terms of who is and isn't being beaten up on, and the sanity mechanics are demanding in management. It's frustrating for someone who doesn't want to invest a lot of time into a game, because getting a feeling of accomplishment in this game is difficult. More often that not, you'll be losing heroes left and right due to circumstances out of your control, which left me feeling like this game's an exercise in futility.

For anyone who's looking for a game to casually enjoy or feel a sense of accomplishment, I can't recommend it.

reviewText:
Dang-♥♥♥ Dungeon is a gritty dungeon crawler thats appealed to a person that usually doesn't like turn based games. The artwork is talented and disturbing, the music fits the atmosphere (I love how daunting and 'uphill battle' the combat music sounds) and the game design is clever in its own unique ways.

As a game dev myself I especially enjoyed the clever game design to keep the player challenged. The game clearly has an agenda to break any sort of easy routine and strategy in managing your roster and money, and makes sure the player knows this through mechanics. For example, in the game you are forced to send a party out each week to advance time. However to prevent the player from endlessly farming easy quests with the same heroes, to prevent them from advancing a week with no effort, your heroes will eventually grow bored of the apprentice quests and refuse to take part, so you will have to spend resources to send out rookies which won't be able to easily roll those quests as much as your vets.

While the game has a lot going for it for game design, there are still a few flaws. It feels like the game's difficulty agenda gets ahead of itself, and bad stuff can happen to you for seemingly no reason just to throw you for a loop. This would be fine if the game would outright state its trying to ♥♥♥♥ you, but instead it does it in ways that seem to resist its own rules. For example, for no reason at all, even without being Marked, the 4-creature party will continually focus one of your squishier heroes into the ground. You can try using a Man-At-Arms or Crusader to mark themselves, but when this is happening it usually doesn't help and they'll continue to slaughter the one character. You have all of these abilities but occasionally the game refuses to listen and will throw any advantages you have from those abilities out the window.

Despite the negative reviews, a frustrating set back once in a while should not really overshadow the game's polish, well thought out game play and clear love the developers have for it. A game is not bad because you can't beat it.

I haven't been too far along yet but I'll definitely play more, however I've seen some complaints about the end-game and it sounds incredibly unpleasant, so unless something REALLY clicks I only really see myself playing this until I succeed in my first assault.

A fan of lovecraft, roguelikes, and rpgs I was really excited for this game.  I was sold on the solid art style and the neat idea that mental stress is a serious factor from all the crazy-scary lovecraftian stuff your party is putting up with.  Unfortunately, how it plays out has major flaws that are just killing any existing fun for me.

First off, the stress thing just becomes a random feeling annoyance most of the time.  It is like playing a turn based RPG where you are managing all the usual stuff, health, upgrades, gear, spells etc, BUT additonally someone is slapping your head often and usually for an unknown reason.  When it works and it is clear why stress is happening it can be interesting and part of the fun -- like when your party gets critted hard, they all do an underwear check and the narrator says witnessing a killing blow bends the mind

Sometimes they will all of a sudden have a huge stress bubble, when nothing happened at all.  75% of the time it seems totally arbitrary and you won't even know why they are gaining stress.\n\nSecond, not being able to heal (health or stress) outside of combat is terrible, horrible game design.  It makes no sense whatsoever -- hey healer help me out

reviewText:
Darkest Dungeon was a game that came to my attention almost as soon as it came into steam. The concept seemed interesting to me and I indulged in watching a few streams and YouTube videos of the game. Turned off by the early access label I decided to withhold my purchase and buy it some other time.
Recently it came to my attention that the game had been finished." I had seen numinous glowing reviews from critics I trust and I was convinced to make the purchase. To me the game looked like Xcom: the RPG with a dark graphic novel H.P. Lovecraft aesthetic.
I am a fan of HP's stories and the narrative to me is clearly inspired by 'The statement of Randolph Carter' and of course the classic 'The call of Cthulhu.' I even encountered a rather on the nose reference to HP's work as my rambling arbalest asked my crusader "have you ever seen a colour out of space?" Referencing the HP Lovercraft story of the same name.
I didn't even have any truck with the controversial ending (that I spoiled for myself
date: more on that later) it's as hopeless and grim as many a Lovecaftian tale.\nThe visual and sound design are excellent
recommended: The character sprites are very graphic novel-ly and well-drawn
hoursPlayed: the music is well composed and the disheartening ambiance that gets louder the darker the torch gets is a nice atmospheric touch.\nThese well done aspects of the game added to the exclusively positive media i had heard up to that point convinced me to buy the game. While this did not cross my mind when i first made my purchase I now remember a certain youtuber saying something along the lines of 'those people who played for 300 hours and hate it.'\nThis should have sent off warning signs in my head but sadly I did not research enough. I made my purchase and began playing. I did well (I think) initially and had a good time. I only lost 3 party members in 15 hours and I managed to beat 4 bosses and both the encounter bosses. I'm not exactly sure if I did anything wrong or if I was just unlucky but I started lousing

I had named each hero after someone I know in real life and had upgraded all my heroes as much as possible in an attempt for them to stop dying. This caused my string of losses to be quite costly both emotionally and financially

At this point my friend linked a video showing why he wouldn’t be purchasing the game after I had stated I had a good time with the first 10 to 15 hours and I realised why I would not be revisiting this game until it is significantly patched.\nThe game is SUPER grind focused. Not only that but the core gameplay loop is repetitive. The same missions: scout(search almost all rooms)

and an item mission where you must find 3 'curios' and interact with them with 3 provided items repeat over and over.
For some reason Red Hook have padded out the game with completely unnecessary repetition and a slow progression system that will set you back HOURS of grinding a replacement hero if you are unlucky and lose even one or 2 party members.
Boss fights are repeated 2 more times at harder difficulties for seemingly no reason and the final straw was seeing what was in store for me in the final missions of the game.
One your party beats an incredibly hard level in the Darkest Dungeon they will all refuse to ever go there again forcing you to grind even more on easier levels to produce max level and well equipped heroes in order to stand a chance.

I'll go ahead and put my biggest problem with this game as my review.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

At first this game seems great, it is difficult but managable. However, after the first two hours it starts showing all of the things I hate about games made artificially difficult. You can have best team ever with combos and skills all mastered and some random dungeon encounter with a skeleton will kill half of them with cheap tricks like constant crits and dodges of the enemy. I guess when I got the game I was hoping that it would be difficult but in a way that is ment to motivate the player to get better, not as one of those meat boy style games where the game is frustrating just because it can. My biggest regret is that I actually spent over two hours in game so I cant get my money back, definitelly dont recommend if you dont like getting frustrated over cheap tricks the developers used to make the game harder than it really is.
Lastly it becomes a grindfeast pretty quick as you need higher level heroes for later quests but those heroes tend to die at random, so now you have to get new ones and grind lower quests over and over again...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I don't review many games, but I came here after a fit of almost punching my computer screen.  This game has so much potential.  Stunning mood, artwork, and gameplay concepts.  But it is HARD.  I don't mind difficulty, I think only difficulty can bring a truly rewarding play experience.  But this is randomly unfair, keyboard-throwingly hard.  You can work for hours to build up a killer party grinding easy missions and buying tons of gear, only to get to a very small, easy fight where one mob crits your whole party and they all go insane and die.  You lose everything you worked for in an instant because of a fluke of bad luck.  You can put a hero out of comission for a week to cure one mental illness, only to pick up 5 more illnesses every single week on every character that participates.  You upgrade your town to make it better, but what's the point?  Nothing seems to make it any easier or less grindy.

Or, there are a couple interface hiccups, like what just happened to me: Find an object which you can use a shovel on, and the interface LOOKS like you're going to use the shovel, but no, it's slightly greyed out and you messed up.  Your party digs through the thing barehanded, and (yes) goes insane and dies.

I want to like this game, I kickstarted it many months ago and I've really been looking forward to it.  But the sheer sense of constantly losing an impossible battle is really too much for me.  I want to have at least some kind of fun playing videogames.  This is just this overwhelming downhill slide of frustration and failure.  I feel like I'm one of the poor ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s inside the game, trapped and doomed.  I'm really sad that I'm not enjoying it at all.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I could think of a million good things to say about this game. Everything from the visuals to the sound design to the gameplay is stunningly wonderful, and accomplishes its goals with ease. This is certainly one of the few early access games that more than earns its somewhat inflated price, and which you should play if you enjoy hard core RPGs.

I see a lot of people posting negative reviews for this game who have less than 10 hours on record, complaining that they've just lost their best heroes or that a boss totally destroyed them, and so the game isn't recommended. I find it bemusingly appropriate that the game, which sets out to create an oppressive and worrisome atmosphere even for the player themself, appears to be doing its job well; the Dungeon is defeating many with its steep difficulty curve. The game warns you up front that heroes will die, and that bad things will happen no matter what. If you play this game, indeed prepare for the worst, but don't throw in the towel the first time it happens!

Don't listen to them, and become Hopeless! Instead become Stalwart, roll up your sleeves, mourn your dead, and push harder through the Darkest Dungeon!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This as yet unreleased game received some of the most glowing reviews from the gaming press that I have seen in quite some time.  I have to disagree.

The game has a great atmosphere and wonderful graphics and sounds that perfectly fit the mood, however, the core elements of class skills, combat, and leveling are lacking.

Class skills are simple and generic leading to few relatively simple strategies for each class, which makes combat mostly about RNG, not player choices.  Since skills are cast from certain positions and hit pre-determined enemy positions, another element of player control is lost.  Accordingly, you could probably write a fairly simplistic algorithm to replace the decision making involved in fighting and not lose anything in the process.

Considering that you have do a very considerable amount of grinding to create a party capable of higher level zones, and considering that those higher level party members can no longer help in lower level zones, what you end up with is excessive repetition of tedious content where success is mostly up to the RNG gods.

No amount of chanting 'hardcore' or 'permadeath' or 'roguelike' will do anything to help with flaws like this.  To me, a good rpg requires that in game challenges be responsive to player decisions more than they are to random rolls.  In old 'roguelike' games such as Nethack, player knowledge contributed to victory at least as much as RNG factors.  A good player was one who knew the options and the capabilities of the creatures they encountered.  They were not simply lucky. RNG was a factor to overcome by foresight, preparation, and knowledge.

I hope that as the game develops, this issue can be addressed.  I would happily grind away if I felt like my choices in battle made much of a difference, but, as it stands, I'd be better off placing bets with myself and rolling a d20.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When I first hired Reynauld, a wet behind the ears crusader, and his highwayman Dismas, I had my doubts if we would even make it to The Estate.  On the road, though, they quickly proved capable - dispatching a small company of bandits who camped on the only road to my isolated inheritance.  Our arrival was met with little fanfare - I heard the tavern keeper remind Dismas that he was not allowed at the gambling tables.  Reynauld refused to leave the transept of the church while in town.  While drinking at the tavern Dismas made friends with an old man at arms named Machel, a man who spends as much time in the brothels as Reynauld does in the transept.  I asked Reynauld if he and his misfortunate band of three might be ready to start excavating and clearing out some of the old ruins beneath the manor, to which he responded that they would if they had a fourth, someone to help keep them in good health.  I told him I knew of just the soul and sent for my old wrestling partner Bretel the vestal.  An old injury that had ended her career in the ring had left her with a weak grip and a torn rotator cuff, but she could still raise the spirits of any soul, bless her heart.

With a full company, the small band set out to explore a small section of the ruin.  To this day Reynauld and Dismas refuse to give account of how their first encounter with the occult and undead went.  All three of them had to spend weeks in isolation, drink, and prayer before they would speak.  Bretel will not be in the same room as either of them, calling them selfish and masochists.  None of them will tell me what happened to Machel.

(x . x)

This is a great game, especially for being in Alpha.  It might be a little on the expensive side, but it's a very well balanced and playable game at this point.  It's challenging, especially at the very beginning or when starting with fresh characters.  As they level up and you unlock higher levels for your characters abilities and gear, and as you get a better sense of what classes go well together, the difficulty eases off a bit.  A lot of the mechanics which seem to be unfair and do nothing but punish you in the beginning do so much less as you learn how to mitigate them (basically, stick in there if you're having trouble, it gets better!).

I'd recommend this to anyone who likes dungeon crawls, rogue-like games, and/or D&D players.
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Darkest Dungeon is a lot like Rogue Legacy where you have a constant influx of adventurers and a randomized dungeon ahead of you. If you're lucky, your runs will yield a tonne of gold, but if you are not then you'll drive your party insane or dead.

The game is about pushing your luck, and managing wear on your party members. There is fun in building a very competent team and taking longer embarkations as you build up.

Buy this game if you enjoy:

1) turn based combat
2) character progression and customization
3) pushing your luck
4) discovering new combinations and interactions (try not to read too many in-depth guides)

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAn excellent game that's well on its way to a successful release after early access.  Its roster and party based gameplay, with the macro game of upgrading the town to improve your squads, is akin to XCOM, and you may find yourself getting attached to specific characters!  Its turn-based combat is deep, with many customization choices of skills and character positioning.  The game's difficulty level can be intimidating at first, but the fact that it's easy to continue with new party members means you will learn for your mistakes and your hard-fought victories will be all the sweeter.  Overall, I highly recommend this game if you're looking for a strategic turn-based game, especially at its current 14.99 sale price.
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nOkay, so this game is only about 25-50% complete, and there is a lot of missing content (early access OFC), but it still packs a good 40+ hours of questing, looting and burying fallen comrades. This game is INTENSE, and it will make you feel things. Some of those things are frustration and anguish. -- a lot of those things are, but you feel them in a good way. Just when you think you have this game figured out, and you have a clear path to victory, it rolls back the curtain and shows you how utterly doomed your characters are.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is full of artificial difficulty, meaning the game is not hard, but only frustrating.
Everything in the game is rolled randomly and often with large discrepancy between numbers, (an enemy could hit you normally for 3, but crit for 20) making combat largely random. Generally the whole game is about you not having real
impact on the outcome. Often the game even completely restricts you from doing actions, which is very frustrating
in a round-based game. (You often wait a long time to have your turn to attack, only for the character to refuse action, wasting your turn and time)
The high chance to dodge of enemies (which is getting greater the further to progress, 30% dodgechances etc)
is very infuriating, and made further frustrating by your characters having high base chance to miss, always wasting your turns for that you waited quite some time and feels terrible frustrating. The order your characters can attack are also internally rolled based on speed, so you have no impact again on the selection of which character you want to use at the moment, making a miss even worse.

The game is full of waiting and you having little impact to the outcome of things.

The outgame progression / leveling is completely redundant, you get boring linear upgrades (+2 damage, +2 armor and dodge) while enemies get stronger in the same fashion, making only damage numbers grow but unaffect gameplay.
Leveling splits your party and artificially locks out parts of your party from various dungeons for again no reason, the whole leveling system is tacked on and adds very little to the game as it stands.

After 1-2 hours of playsessions I always had to take a break as it was too frustrating always waiting on things only to have their actions denied by refusals and dodges which just feels like wasting your time, also there is hardly enough content as of yet. The visuals are amazing and there are some unique things, but most of the games uniqueness comes from mechanics that make the game purely frustrating without adding other values or real difficulty.

reviewText:
*150+ Hours later, love the game even more!*

Dark Dungeons? Check!
Characters can go Insane? Check!
Fun rogue like with turnbased combat? Check!
Is the game a Challenge? Yes it will punish you, Check!
Epic voice work from the narrator? Check!
Will it Shatter the dreams you have as a hero and hold you're balls in a vice? Check!
Is the game addicting? 88 hours since Xmas would tell me...Check!

If you like rogue like games with good atmosphere and turnbased combat, check this out, it will punish you over and over again. I have 88 hours on the game so far and I have had fun with it and can tell I will be restarting this over and over trying to do better each time, like a rogue like does! Feel like some fun punishment? (You sick ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ mate!) This game is for you!

So far I am really liking it, I will post some more thoughts at a later time when I get more time with it and more updates are out. As far as early access games go though, this is a great 88 hours of gaming on darkest dungeon so far. Also one more thing, I have not had any crashes or big bugs so far, pretty stable for an early access game!

The Full game is now out and I am in love with the game, have over 30 hours on it now since xmas and boy, what a joy! After about 20 hours I really started to get the mechanics down and have a huge, well done up party, but I know death could be right around the corner for any of them.

Great art design, awesome atmosphere, gameplay is a blast, wonderful voice work and it is very addicting! I love the stress mechanic and all the quirks and diseases, just a wonderful game indie rpg that is a very nice challenge! I use to love a game caleld Vandal hearts years back, this reminds me of that in some ways but so much better, with alot more depth and much much more challenging.

Go pick up this wonderful game, early contention for Game of the year. I have not been able to put this game down! Got it around Christmas and I have already put in 88 hours!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The level of art is very high and graphical design of the user interface is as intuitive as it is appealing. The narration and sound effects are simply awesome, and the narrator encourages you with quotes of wisdom with his deep resonating and enchanting voice as you go along. This is one of the most enjoyable and best aspect of the game, which really distinguishes it and compensates for the negative aspects. If the negative aspects are sorted, the devs are looking at a block buster.

What I didn't like is there is no difficulty setting, just an radio button option to switch corpses and heart attacks off. This makes the game a lot easier and you don't seem to be penalised for switching these off, nor is there a reward for enabling them, so there is no incentive to switch em back on.

Combat is one of the main aspects of the game but a lot of luck is involved, and this will get you cursing and shouting at times. A lot of people have already reviewed this aspect so, briefly, the computer has been made to cheat to increase difficulty. But I would rather fight a tougher enemy i.e with more HP, rather than a weaker enemy who cheats. So enough from me on luck. But the silliest aspect of the game IMHO is time wasted during combat. In between in each character turn there is upto a 10 second of animations starting with a loud drum beat, then the character gets blessed, stressed, buffed or debuffed, bleeds, blighted or resists and then he/she says something which you expect given the stress/quirk e.g. I... this...can't". Given 8 characters must play each round that is 80 seconds per round
recommended: then 60 sec as you kill the enemy etc. Given you could play 20-30 rounds per combat (especially if you take your time to kill the last rogue to heal your characters) that's typically 15 - 20 minutes of time wasted per battle. Given you play a battle almost every other room you are looking at typically an hour upto 2-3 hours of pure-time-waste per mission
hoursPlayed: just to watch some animations. I haven't even counted the time while the characters are actually attacking/defending let alone the time travelling in between rooms. There is no option to speed up combat and cut the faff. Playing one mission enables you to heal your resting heroes

reviewText:
I'll start with a warning: If you dislike RNG and it making a big difference, you might wanna skip this game. Even with the right tactics, some well-geared characters and a lot of experience, some encounters might still get your favorite adventurers killed. You should be aware of this, and if you hate having some very unhappy rolls on attacks, then this might be very frustrating.

Now... I at first wasn't very interest in DD, but a review and stream by TB made me change my mind and try it. And I was captivated quickly. The game is a LOT of fun.
The graphics and animations are very simple, but also, very stylish, so they have character and are nice to look at.
The atmosphere is great. There is a certain Lovecraftian vibe to things (not only because madness can become a real problem for your adventurers), and the narrator does SUCH a great job (BTW, check out his readings of HPL-stories, such a cool experience).

Even with a lot of training, these dungeons will be risky for your guys. Bad RNG on heals (instead of, say, 8 points, you get 0 or 1 points, which means you kinda lost a turn) or damage (sometimes, you are THAT close to killing a mob, but then, 2-3 of your guys actually MISS, and you actually end up losing), debuffs like selfishness (your character might snag loot for himself), or paranoia (he or she might actually REFUSE to be healed) etc.

I did like the darkness-mechanic. There are advantages and disadvantages to letting the light go dim or using torches to get to 100 light. With this mechanic, you kinda pick how you wanna approach the dungeon, a little bit like controlling the difficulty level yourself (not that it is a cakewalk if you spam torches, mind you!), and the increased rewards you get for fights at low light levels come with increased risks too.

So, you may ask, why do people play this? Are we all out for punishment? No! The game is just very addictive in that Come on

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It started out well BUT shrtly after getting into the game I found some serious problems. The game doesn't seem to allow for mission selection (meaning you have no control over where you go or the difficulty of the missions being undertaken). This wouldn't be a problem if you could aviod more senior members of the team dying but you can't, leaving you with rookies getting smashed on missions far to hard for them and your coffers quickly empty. Once this happens you cant get back into the game and the repetition of start well, get smashed, everyone dies, fail dungeon, return to town, rinse, repeat... it just gets old quickly.

I like the game, I like the design, I like the ideas and the spooky voice over, the commentary and the captions from characters, the psychological and medical quirks, ALL GREAT... but the difficulty curve and the risk reward are totally out of whack diminishing the playability and amping up the frustration way beyond fun into simply annoying.

This could be a really good game, but alas it falls short on playability, where it excels is in the exceptional design, sound, visuals (all top notch)... if you don't mind the overwhelming urge to smash your machine, this may be a good game for you. I was left feeling hollow and teary... I want to love this, I really do... it's SO COOL, but I just can't... perhaps I'm playing wrong... but I dont know if I'll come back

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So Darkest Dungeon....

So far I have truly enjoyed this game. It is difficult and unique enough to want to continue. It feels very close to the difficulty of 1st Edition Advanced Dungeons and Dragons. However, there are a few key aspects that make this game actually impossible.

1) Most enemies have attacks that target the entire party. No one in your party has any attack that can hit more than two people except the highwayman. He can hit three. Also, some of the party wipers that are multi unit hits have afflictions (I.E. Blight, and bleeding.) The highwayman hits people, that is all. You have single unit to two unit afflictions at best.
2) The Bosses are unreasonably difficult. The level one boss in the ruins, against the Mad Priest hiding behind pews is too difficult for a party that was level 4, with level 2 equiptment and rank 2 abilities. He is a level one rated boss.
3) The loss of sanity is like taking a bottle of water, taking off the cap, and draining the bottle to 7/8 emptiness and then complaining that you're thirsty and it isnt enough. If anyone in your party is sane after a dungeon, you should probably go to a casino immediately to capitalize on the new found super luck you have acquired.

Aside from horrible balance issues, literally impossible boss fights, and god awful suicidal standards of heroes...

It isn't a bad game. It is in early access, and there is room for improvement. That does not mean i do not love this game. Totally worth it if you hate yourself or enjoy watching guinea pigs (cough, i mean adventurers) wander aimlessly into suicide and failure, or want to have PTSD like flashbacks of Dark Souls moments.

8/10 so far.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I am very excited to see where this game is going.  I would highly recommend it to anyone who enjoys classic tabletop, dark themes, and testing their luck against difficult odds.

Atmopshere / Theme / Art:

I love the non-traditional art style of the game - the character and background art is cartoonish but it manages somehow to add to the charm of the game, not take away from it.  The narration is spot-on and well-done and I found it to be an enhancement to the game.  The atmosphere is consistent and nicely executed.

Gameplay:

I found gameplay to be enjoyable, personally.  I love the simple but effective UI - it plays like a casual game but there's much more to it under the surface and you can really feel that.  It has all the pros of a point-and-click and none of the cons.  There's no twitch, which I like, and I absolutely love that your decisions are well and truly final.  There's no save-game trickery, no way to go back on a bad choice.  You live with what you do no matter what.

I find the game to be a great diversion and will be playing the heck out of it :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is not about playing to win, or even developing characters. It is about setting you up for a frustrating exercise in futility and leaving you with absolutely no hope. The items that bestow stat boosts also carry penalties. The money and resources spent developing your hamlet will leave you without resources to purchase items for quests. You will experience random deaths and afflictions of characters, which you will be unable to cure because you lack money needed from finishing dungeons. In other words, this game has been overweighted to such an extent that it is designed to cause you to fail at every turn. And not matter how careful you are, you will lose.

The worst part is that you will be unable to level any characters up high enough to advance in the game, because they will likely gain so much stress and affliction they will die of a heart attack before reaching level 2.

I appreciate the lovecraftian elements of this game. However, the developers have weighted the game to such an extent against the player, that it isn't even enjoyable to play.

That said, if you simply want to play to see how long you can go before all your characters die, then this game will provide at the least a lot of entertainment value because of the narrator commentary and creepy graphics. To be fair, I think the developers have a decent basis for what could be a very versatile game to the broader gaming community. But at this point, it is purely designed for graphic visual value, because it isn't even challenging - it's hopeless.

If anyone in the company or development actually reads this review, I would urge you to consider programming some variability into the in terms of challenge levels. It would probably have a broader appeal to the larger gaming community. As it stands now, I think it is likely a very small niche group of folks that would actually enjoy the gameplay.

Examples of in-game issues: Want to heal outside of combat? Nope. Healer skils are only available during combat. And food only heals one lifepoint at a time outside of combat - while penalties like bleeding and plague continue to linger outside of combat. You can cure them with items, but if you don't have the money, you don't have the items. You can only camp to restore life in certain dungeons, so if it's a single-shot playthrough dungeon with no camping option, you have no heal ability outside of combat. Treasure drops in the dungeons are so random and rare as to be not worth it. And healing abilities in combat are somewhat random in the amount they restore. The game is designed to kill your heroes. Period.

You can leave a dungeon at any time. But if you do, it may disappear, which means you lose out on the item rewards for completion. Further, you don't get to keep provisions purchased but not used for the next dungeon. And the costs to remove and heal heros who are likely crapping themselves when they return to the hamlet means you have little resources for provisions in the next dungeon.

I like the concepts in the game. And I appreciate the developers really aren't going for a game that's playable to win - it's more about sacrifice and how far you will push to complete. The problem is, if you do push then your heroes will likely die and you won't finish the dungeon anyway - and you can't advance in the game if your characters don't have higher levels, which require money and resources gained from dungeons, which cycles back to the basic problem.

Psychologically, there's very little positive reinforcement in this game, and a whole lot of discouragement and negative reinforcement such that if you are attached to your characters or advancing in the game, you are in for an excercise in frustration. This type of psychological situation doesn't affect everyone negatively, so if that isn't a consideration for you, you may very well enjoy this game.

I don't recommend this game to the broader gaming community. However, if you are the kind of gamer that appreciates the dark, twisted, and impossible to win kind of game that leaves you breathless and frustrated (and I know there are gamers out there like this), then you are in for a treat. This game won't disappoint.

Improvements that could help this game are healing abilities being active outside of combat, or having food restore far more health. But then, I suppose that would mean your heroes might not die as quickly, which would defeat the whole purpose of the game probably. At the least, it would be good to have variable levels of challenge settings in the game in order to help players at all levels truly enjoy and appreciate the dark storyline and potentially awesome gameplay. Right now, however, it just isn't there outside of a niche group.

On another note - I spent hours investing time carefully cultivating characters to be able to take on the first boss (the hag). The turn system in this game is so random, that the hag ended up having multiple turns before I even got a shot off, and she wiped out my whole party with her pot (which she puts your heros into to cook them). The whole battle was a joke. To say that I think the game developers have a tremendous amount of work to do on this game is an understatement. The part that upsets me the most is that I cannot get my money back. But certainly, it is the last time I will ever buy a game from this company.

reviewText:
A lot of reviewers have already said what needs to be said.

The voice acting, the game's story, the game theme, all of it is very high quality. However, the game artificially lengthens its playtime by throwing too many punishing mechanics against you, with too many random elements.

As one example of a problematic random element, nailing a critical hit is massively damaging, and while it can feel satisfying for your group to instant kill a target from a lucky dice roll (along with cool narrative from the narrator), the enemy can do the same to your characters (especially with chained criticals), which strips you of any tactical defensive options you'd want to employ. For this reason, it's not really a question of if" a character will die
date: but "when" the character will die. You can't get too attached to your characters like you do in X-Com in Ironman mode
hoursPlayed: thinking there's a chance they might survive. You actually have to grind parties to their death over and over and over and over again until you amass enough gold to upgrade your town to the point that you can then begin creating an endgame group (or try to) after another long grind of amassing wealth with suicide runs.\n"

Early Access Review

Simply put, this game is too difficult. Now, before you skip me and move on let me explain what I mean. Games like Dark Souls, they're very difficult but in a way that where the difficult parts are still fun and engaging, and not left up to mere chance. This game however, has simple combat enacted by mindlessly clicking buttons and characters, which is only understandable for any turn based game, but the sheer difficulty and cheapness that occurs in it leaves me to not want to play again. The game never makes you feel rewarded, or that what you did was worthwhile. The overall depressing theme and the constant sullen narrations just put me and all my friends in a bad and agitated mood after just minutes.
Not to mention it's possible to completely screw yourself over to the point where you have to create a new save file, seriously, just give the ability to wait a week.

Early Access Review

The game schematic is nice but badly developed. It requires a lot of thinking for preparing a mission, but then random generation throws in completely inadequate items that make your preparation useless (like needing 3 shovels for a short mission, if I have to buy 3 every time I can never save money).
There is a too large gap between missions at lv1 and lv3 (there is lv2). At lv1 you easily win, at lv3 you loose too much even with well equipped lv3 characters.
The worst thing of all is the navigation through the menus. Although the game requires you to read every detail of the charactersm, you have to click hundreds of times and opens tens of different windows just to get an idea of simple things. They should put more information available in every window. The player ability should not be the patience to open 15 different windows in order to understand how to develop a character.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'll be honest I am not really a fan of hard games, sometimes I like a good challenge
I love Dark souls and XCOM for instance but I have never been a fan of roguelikes, I keep trying them but they never stick,
I saw (and heard) Darkest Dungeon (DD for short) and instantly fell in love, the character art has so much charm and my god the narrator and his script is excellent, the Cthullu dungeon setting is really cool and the misfit murder hobo heroes are fun,
it really does have a ton of character.

Sadly this game suffers from the strong vision of its creators, they wanna make a game true to the Cthullu mythos
and that means, everybody is gonna go insane and die and well they kinda nailed it.
A lot is said about the pro's and con's of RNG in games and in something like XCOM it's not so bad because you can stack things in your favor with strategy and careful play, DD doesn't really let you do that
all the planning in the world wont stop your whole team getting wiped out in single turn.
and before I am told I suck and my opinion is dismissed, this did not happen to me for a fair while
my graveyard was empty (though corpses and heart attacks went of right away, ♥♥♥♥ corpses are dumb) (even surviving an encounter with the Hag boss and finding that my team composition was totally unable to harm her, which felt like ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t to me, I should be able to use the combinations I enjoy)
right up until today when I first entered the cove I sent my strongest team on the apprentice lvl 0 mission, the first fight was a lil rough but nothing too bad, but the second fight, holy ♥♥♥♥ the second fight
I quickly suffered my first casualty and things are looking real bad, then an enemy exploded and put my whole team at deaths door facing enemies with 100% damage buffs,
I ran and thats when I realised I did not have any bloody money
and the meager progress I had made (I never felt like I was making much progress while playing, despite building what I thought were some strong heroes) seemed pretty much gone

I think this game needs a difficulty select
an easy mode where you can actually feel like you are making progress and doing well.
A normal mode which can be their original vision, untainted.
And finally a super hard nightmare mode for all the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s who always say every game is too easy and they 100% it on the hardest difficulty in one day because its so pathetically easy (I don't know why these people even play games, they never seem to enjoy them)

Also I will say that the art was actually kind of a let down, the opening intro is so freaking amazing but honestly most of the enviroments and the enemies are pretty lame, mushroom people, pig people, skeletons, fish people and just plain old people, a few designs aside they are mostly kinda dull and not very scary at all, I had expected more to be honest.

TL:DR I wanted to like this game but I never actually had any fun, even while winning.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThere's hard and there's frustrating.  Darkest Dungeon gives the illusion of difficulty while actually being frustrating and rigged.  The concept for the game is top notch.  A Cthulhu-madness-Dungeon-And-Dragons crossover!  The execution; however, will leave you wanting a refund of both your money and time.  There are three enormous issues that the gameplay can not overcome.  First, corpses.  Google it.  Incredibly poor game design.  Second, the weakness of each character's will makes their death a sigh of relief.  When your Brothel-diving-table-cheating-irrational-rabid Grave Robber finally kicks the bucket you're going to cheer... a lot.  Don't waste your hard earned money on a title that you want to hate to love but end up just hating.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

DO NOT BUY THIS GAME!!

At one time I heard that this was a fun game .... BUT not ANYMORE!
At this time I can’t recommend this game, the developers have totally screwed it up to a point where it is no longer a challenging rpg game. Instead it is now a time sink and grind fest game.

Game mechanics are...

Level up heroes to farm gear and what little gold you can.

Then delete them when upkeep gets too expensive or before they hit the next difficulty level.

Hire new heroes and equip them with your better gear to farm just that much better at low levels.

Rinse and repeat until you can get best gear and money. Ending up with a conga line of characters entering and leaving your roster.

GG enjoy playing Darkest Dungeon (football team roster simulator)
