reviewText:
Early Access Review

On a positive note, I love the concept of this game, I like the art, the rogue-like elements, and in large part the execution is fantastic. It hooks you in with the progression of the town and your heroes and I genuinely felt excitement and nervousness at attempting a quest because you never know whats going to happen!

Now on the more neutral side of things, but ultimately the downfall of the game, is the difficulty, which is ridiculously hard... and believe me when I say I enjoy really hard games.
It took me about 2 dead heroes and 4 failed attempts at runs before I even finished my first run at the first basic quest. While I personally didn't mind this, I don't think this is a good way to bring new players into the game and it is going to turn a lot of people away very quickly.

Despite the tough learning curve I began to piece together how things worked, I began developing my town and upgrading and recruiting a variety of heroes to put strategic compositions together to take town tough quests.

It felt good.

I was absolutely loving it... then, I attempted the Wisened Hag quest for the first time... with obviously no idea of what she did or what I needed to prepare for. Fortunately, everything was going swimmingly. I breezed my way through the dungeon and headed into the boss room on full health with practically no stress... Perfect!

At which point, the boss randomly captured and reordered my units, with basically no way to stop it because they were all permanently moved into the one position they could not attack. If I tried to move one into the position it needed to be in, she just moved it back. So I completely helplessly lost my 4 best heroes at once, with no way to retreat or counter what was happening...

Frustrating... to say the least.

Don't get me wrong, I understand you're going to lose heroes, it's part of the game. And, as bad as it was, that wasn't the real issue.
The zero option and severity of that fight just felt hollow. I could have done nothing about what happened because I had no idea what I was in for, I just clicked that button to enter the room and lost everything.
But the really aggravating and ultimately insurmountable problem was that I now had nothing. No money, and therefore zero way to buy provisions for another quest; or de-stress heroes; or upgrade heroes; or in fact actually attempt to get back into the game at all.

That was it: 9-10 hours of gameplay down the toilet.

So lesson learnt, I suppose? All I need to do now is make sure I keep a buffer of gold in case things go bad right?
Sure, but  do I want to start over and build my town up from scratch?

Nope, do I heck. I'm done.

I had a great time with it, but it just ended all my motivation to keep playing right there and then and I can't bring myself to spend the time starting over, only to hit the next boss I haven't seen before and I get set back another 10 hours.
I'm confused why they thought this was sensible game design and what outcome something like this would have with anyone other than just feeling like you've been duped into wasting your time.

So just like the heroes in the game, my resolve was tested:
Did I become Focused? Stalwart? Courageous?

No.

At best, they might hope that someone becomes Masochistic and starts over. But, frankly, it just left me feeling Hopeless.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I started playing DD on this last patch and I for one like the game. I cannot recommend it unfortunately. Echoing many of the other reviews that have been written recently, DD has a myriad of wonderful features, including excellent voice acting and mechanical rpg enhancements, the concept of stress, the artwork, and the music all serve to make Darkest Dungeon a joy to play to a point. That point is reached fairly quickly in the game due to the compounding effects of stress and the costs to combat stress and improve your crew. None of the provisions like torches and food you purchase for a given expedition that you don't use are lost upon return. Oversupply yourself and you lose a significant amount of coin. Underprovision yourself and you risk failing the expedition and really getting behind on your coffers. With the high costs of stress reduction and improvement opportunities, and expedition costs, I am starting to see a challenge in making any progress to the higher levels in this game. Recruiting newer characters that are too weak to explore your only choice of dungeons and being unable to use your higher level characters much due to the effects of stress or the many negative quirks they aquire that cost too much to remove means you end up playing only the very beginning portions of a given dungeon and make barely any progress.

Bottom line, a really great game ruined by too high of a challenge level. You will find yourself getting frustrated playing it now so I would wait until another patch comes through that addresses the difficulty issues.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm sorry, guys. I need to gush.
Look, I'm not a big fan of RPGs. I have no patience to play through a Final Fantasy or Mass Effect game.
And yet this has easily landed in my top 3 favorite games I've ever played.

Let's start with my pet peeve in RPGs (or any game for that matter): lengthy story. This factor is non-existent in Darkest Dungeon.
The intro to the game and opening to a new playthrough both have cutscenes that last roughly 4 minutes altogether. I can easily live with that. From here, a lore is sprinkled throughout the game by a wonderfully gritty narrator that speaks during gameplay. That being said, more is revealed about the enviroment just by the interaction in the game. Interacting with objects and seeing enemies allows the player to imagine what happened (or is happening) to the dungeons they're fighting in. I adore this. There's no lengthy dialogues or other cutscenes to keep you from playing the game, let alone have a story. Granted, it's not a masterpiece novel; however, with all due respect, I gladly take this over an Assassin's Creed game where there's almost as much cuscene as gameplay (yes, I have played an Assassin's Creed game, and this is merely an opinion).
Let's get to another great factor of this game: it's sure challenging. Overall, it's a challenge. It's not I Wanna Be the Boshy difficult, but it's harder than your average game.
I say Overall
date: because the difficulty changes throughout your playthrough. First-time players to this game will find it BRUTAL (I did). Enemies could do as much damage as you (if not more), dungeons are filled with events and hazards that greatly influence for units for that current dungeon and possibly even for the rest of their lives. What do I mean by rest of their lives?" Well
hoursPlayed: and death is permanent in this game. Your level 3 Highwayman is gone; go pick up a level 0 at the stagecoach. Throw in some financial issues
voteText:
and you got yourself into quite a pickle buying this game.

And yet you will learn.

You will learn what the best combination of units are. You will learn what hazards are in each dungeon and how to resist them. You will learn that not all the equipment in the game is bad and ultimately use it. You will learn how to manage your units' stress (I'll explain later) inside and outside of battle. Eventually
helpfulPercent:
you will find yourself with a roster of decently-leveled units and some gold to spare on some supplies and neat-o upgrades.

And yet you will learn (about bosses).

Regardless of your units' levels and skills

reviewText:
Thought I'd make a quick edit to the review now that the game has come out of Early Access.

Darkest Dungeon lets you assemble a roster of dungeon adventurers and send them into dungeons in order to defeat pestilent creatures that have plagued the land in order to fully restore a hamlet back to its former glory. The game is not so much a pure dungeon crawler, but more of a dungeon crawl management simulator (for lack of a better word). You do not only navigate the heroes through a dungeon. You also take full responsibility for their wellbeing. As heroes go through dungeons, they accumulate stress and could even get diseases, and you have to make sure you bring them back to top shape in between your dungeon runs. You do not just control a single party of heroes. You have to rotate several different heroes around and pick the ones most suitable for the job at hand.

There are 4 areas where you can take your expedition: Ruins, Warrens, Weald, and Cove, and each one has its own dangers and challenges, what means that you need to prepare your team accordingly. The dungeons also come in different lengths (Short, Medium, and Long) and of different difficulty (Apprentice, Veteran, and Champion). As of the final release, the final dungeon has been added too (have not yet had the bravery to try it out).

The combat is really fun and in my opinion has a lot of tactical depth to it. It's not just a simple turn-based battle system, but each position within your party setup is important. Some hero classes prefer frontal positions in the squad (like the melee tanks), others prefer to hang back (like healers or ranged attackers).

The game has been balanced around loads during Early Access, and though some aspects of it might feel unfair still, overall the gameplay feels pretty solid and requires a lot of strategising and adjusting to the situation when bad things start to happen. The game can be pretty punishing towards those who do not take caution. And even if you do everything right, things can still go wrong at times, and part of the gameplay is also having to deal with that. The game encourages tip-top preparation and contingency planning. That means that the game is easily not for everyone, but those who do enjoy that sort of thing will be up for a real treat.

Art, music, and voice acting are also superb. Easily a cherry on an already delicious cake.

I would highly recommend this game to anyone who likes a good challenge and doesn't mind it when a game occasionally throws them some curve balls. I can't remember the last time a game has kept me interested for 70 hours and counting.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

RNG Review, for those that are curious about how heavily the RNG affects the game.

You can die outright in the tutorial.
You can die in the first two missions because your replacement party members are useless due to RNG selected skills.

You could literally not buy this game and just roll dice on D&D tables and get the same experience of gameplay.  Just without the art.
======
TL;DR for people with reading comprehension problems:

It is a nearly finished product
It is not necessarily ready for broad consumption as an early access piece
It is worth your support if it is a game you would like see reach its full potential.
If you are going to support it, be involved with the community and developers, don't just throw money at it.

=======
AMAZING aesthetic. In its current state, it is a fully finished art piece, which will be regarded as a gem...

When the rest of it is finished.

The mechanics of the game are fully realized, the systems and etc are fleshed out, functional, and understandable (if not a little obfuscated behind menus in some cases), so that's not necessarily the issue.

The problems you will find will relate to the game design and the user experience.  Yes, the game is hard, in ways that you may even find unfair due to randomness, but that's kind of where the fun is, in this reenvisioning of the popular dungeoncrawler idea.

What you'll find is a game that, in many cases, doesn't care whether or not you're having fun, which is a real shame, because the developers clearly care about making it a good game, but in its current state you will be hit, full force, with the sense that they don't, amist an equal amount of force saying they want to make a great product.

While I am giving this a negative recommendation, I say this:

If you think you would enjoy this game, or this is a game that you would like to see succeed, do buy it.  However, don't just buy the game, but play it and provide good constructive and analytic feedback to the developers about the areas that need it.  This is an early access game, which means it is technically an unfinished product, but while early access is often a variant form of a kickstarter money grab kind of thing, this game is a near complete product, and if it's something you would like, the best thing you can do is support it not only with money, but with the intention to beta test it the way early access is somewhat meant to be for.

Do not entertain ideas of fanboy hype and vapid support of various features of the game, because that is only appeal to enthusiasm and emotion.  If you feel something is wrong with the game, take some time to analyze it and understand how it affects the game, how it fails to benefit it, or, maybe, how it actually does its job well, and use these understandings to notice the cracks that need to be filled.  And then communicate them.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAn extremely challenging and extremely addictive dungeon crawler.  Gambling on that next step in a dungeon can either leave you exhilarated with your success or crying as you leave empty handed with 4 dead adventurers that you spent hours leveling. reviewText:
Early Access Review

Too much RNG, and not enough skill based combat. Yeah, I get it, turn based RPGs do have an element of RNG to them, but mechanically this game is just bad. Enemies out hit you and out stress you. I don't mind that there isn't a good way to heal out of battle, as it makes the game feel more like a test of endurance, but it's not uncommon that I will just get to an easy fight and drag it out for an hour just to heal, because all in combat heals restor a pathetic amount of HP.

Also the Vestel feels like a necessary class due to having by FAR the strongest heals. In my opinion, having any class feel necessary is just BAD. This game really needs something of a way to heal out of combat. Add to that the fact that when you get a character to level 3 they refuse to do low level quests (apparently all the heroes in this game are just jackasses) Ugh... Lets just say this game has more going against it than for it at the moment.

Anyways, I really do want to see where this game goes in the future, but it's gonna be several patches before I look into it again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Step 1. Hire level 0 adventurers and give them no items.

Step 2. go as far into a dungeon as you can collecting loot.

Step 3. Fire all of them and hire new level 0 heros.

Repeat forever.

Darkest dungeon has no way to lose the game and most upgrades just reduce prices by a negible amount. And everything costs large amounts of money. I'd swear this was suppose to be a buy cash mobile game with how much everything costs, how grindy it is, and that is just impossible to lose.

The first thing you will want to do after your first day of playing is turn the narrator volume off. He repeats himself CONSTANTLY and just plain ticks you off stealing slots at the tavern or church. He doesn't act insane or woe is me at all, and neither would I spending all my time gambling, drinking, and sleeping with a brothel.

I'm not sure what is more annoying. The fact that after each dungeon run up to all 4 adventurers might gain a negative trait or how often enemies can dodge, especially enemies in the back that like to use sanity lowering moves.

The game does have items called trinkets, but most have negatives that rarely seem to make them worth using. You can't even sell them, yet the game will offer to sell them to you for high amounts.

Theres camping that can heal or boost your heros, but your likely to get attacked after in the dark. So the advantage camping gave might go right out the window and end your run right then and there.

The fact that heros gain zero exp from battles and only from completing a dungeon. Makes battles just feel pointless. Completely 100% pointless and worthless. The time I spent in that battle I could have found and open 4 treasures or more.

Its not a hard game, its not a fair game, its not much fun. I'm always loading it forgetting its not fun and then one dungeon later I remember and turn it off. Lots of rougelikes/lites have unfair enemies or traps, but they are usually consistant. Not miss every attack and every enemy gets a critical vs the same groups you always stomped before. Going from 22,000 to nothing because I upgraded 4 of my heros is not fun. This is the only game I can remember where after an entire day of grind my characters are level two. Making it possibly the most grindy game I've ever played, worse than silk road.

The money grind just ruins it for me. If I wanted this much money grind I'd play a ftp mmo. The money isn't even spent on fun things, its fixing negative traits that my heros will just pick right up again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As a Lovecraftian fan, this game is pure excellence. It's unbridled focus on Necromancy, Cosmic Horrors, Weird Fiction Tropes and recently on an Innsmouth-centric revolt allows an atmosphere of insidious dread to prevail through such terrible game mechanics. Yes, I said it. Reveling in the diverse rogue gallery of lore-centric enemies is awesome. You'll feel like you got lost inbetween Algernon Blackwood and Lovecraft while crawling through catacombs as Wayne June proclaims your inevitable failure, and the masked Leper leading your party suddenly cracks.

But I feel a unique, separate kind of dread when all four of my level 5's miss the basic skeletals and get wrecked. Or when Cup of Annoyance is cast 37 times in a row by their back line without giving me a turn, stressing my entire party to Hell itself. DD's combat engine is dicerolls from D&D, home brewed, without much semblance of balance.

Darkest Dungeon is a sidescrolling click-n-crawl much like Grimrock, with a tiered party of 4 classes taking different depth charts. Positioning is important, as archers can't shoot from the front, and your crusader can't swing from the back. Following? You crawl down hallways, which are littered with procedurally generated loot, into rooms, filled usually with bad guys. That's all it is, besides for a feature creep styled town where heirlooms acquired can upgrade it to provide cheaper upgrades. No town events, invasions, 1-day missions, or anything resembling variation. Objectives range from scouting all the rooms, killing all the bad guys, or collecting 3 pieces of unique loot. All 3's results do not effect your party any differently, leading me to realize DD is a monotonous descent into the uniquely terrifiyng realm of boredom, and boredom that punishes you for being alive.

reviewText:
This game gives the illusion of being hard through unforgiving RNGs.

The game has a great atmosphere and feels special in that regard, but to enjoy it to its full extent you need to be...lucky.

You can finish missions without a scratch with new characters with default equipment as easily as you can fail horribly the same missions with hard-boiled badasses armed to the teeth and trained with min-maxed abilities.

Combats are just a series of hits traded between two teams. Most will seem even untill one side misses or the other crits, and just like that your fate is sealed.

It's a shame really, there are tons of varied classes with dozens of different abilities but all of them seem so meaningless when each fight is played with the flip of a dice.

reviewText: Very compelling. Every item you find is basically junk - you can power up but only by making yourself too weak to live in another way. I've had dungeon runs where I begin and before I have a turn half the party is diseased with crippling afflictions, yes before I've clicked a single option. I've faced off against a boss with a full maxxed out level 6 group and had 4 deathblows occur in the same turn. At that point I uninstalled.\n\nThere's difficult challenges and then there's a game where you look in disbelief and say give me a break". I played for more than 100 hours so it's definitely fun but after a while you simply will be frustrated by random events that undo every bit of strategy and make the entire experience a frustrating farce."

Early Access Review

I kickstarted this game...So glad I did.

Darkest dungeon is an amazingly entertaining RPG rogue-lite dungeon crawler with a twist. The art style is amazing, the strategy elements are already well done (it's still early access). And it has amazing replay ability.

The things I was most worried about (Narration and barking) turned out very well in my opinion, Wayne June's voice is just amazing. Dude can articulate.

I've already played 30 hours and it's just been released, worth every penny.
10/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Why I like Darkest Dungeon in spite of the fact that the negative reviews for it are so accurate:

Darkest Dungeon is a game that can fist you right up your rectal chute by having enemies dominate the ever-loving ♥♥♥♥ out of your heroes.  But then, it turns around (after washing that same fist thoroughly) and gives you a hearty, friendly slap on the back by raining treasures, criticals, and dodges on your party, all in favor towards them, of course.

But that's just the kind of game it is.  Sure, it's 85% luck, but if you don't have the 10% skill necessary, as well as that all-important 5% patience, of course you're gonna feel like those people who reviewed this game badly.

And that's why I like Darkest Dungeon so much: it punishes me so hard, but then it reminds me to have the patience to ♥♥♥♥ it in the ♥♥♥ right back, and the triumph becomes 10 times sweeter.

reviewText:
Addendum: So now the game is released and many changes were made since this first hit Early Access. I am glad to say the game is still awesome. Very well polished, though some of the classes could use some balancing. The mechanics are solid and the gameplay is as addictive as ever. Corpses really make no difference to me. I find them to be pretty easy to deal with to the point that, IMO, they are inconsequential.

So my recommendation remains the same. By it, especially if you like games with brutal difficulty. It is rewarding to play and satisfying to overcome the odds.

One of the most polished Early Access games I have ever played, Darkest Dungeon is a gem that deserves your time. A wonderful mish-mash of genres with the addition of the excellent Stress mechanics make this one of the most brutal RPG/Strategy/Rouge-Lite games in recent memory as well.

The art style is beautiful as well, conveying the gothic atmosphere well. In fact, I can't find to much bad to say about this game. If you are interested in a challenging game that is only going to get better as it gets closer to its projected summer release day, you now have your game.. The addicting gameplay will bring you back for more, More of your adventurers suffering brutal deaths and mind-crushing insanities. Managing the stress that leads to insanity is one of the more gripping and complex of the mechanics in the game. In my opinion, it is one of the defining traits of this game.

Even if these types of games don't exactly appeal to you, I still recommend it. The addicting gameplay will bring you in and the amount of polish will impress. Go buy this game, it will be some of the best 20 bucks you spent on video games.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Darkest dungeon is basically Persona x crusader kings and it will become a good purchase for it's money if the additional content can turn this sidescroll dungeon explorer into something with a lot of replayability, which is kinda lacking atm becuase there is no real reason to grind most things and getting one person up to lvl 5 with less optimal parties can be really tedious, a lot of the concepts in game work until you reach lvl 5, then the game kinda fades out in challenge and fun.

but i easily spend 20 hours into this game having a blast exploring the dungeons, enjoying the ambient sounds and music as it turns dark.

som classes are kinda lacking in gameplay compared to just having grave robber+highwayman+crusader+hellion/vestal/another grave robber.


For example, Plague doctor has a good dot, but the unforgiving gameplay and rng makes the player want to end every battle ASAP, so a lot of classes that need turns to set things up are wasting time and taking risks.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hard but Fun

This is one of those games that does not hold your hand, in fact, it's a challenge but a well designed one.

The world is beautifully made and does a great job at depicting a dark and desprate land.
The combat is challenging but has a good element od strategy allowing you to get out of tight spots.

The game overall feels like a bit of a grind as you repeat a lot of the same events but the large variation of characters/items makes up for it.

It feels very rewarding seeing your troops go from lowly bums to brutal warriors.


If you like the artstile and are prepared to lose a lot, try it out.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pros: The artwork, music, sound effects, and ambiance are awesome, and make me want to play this game.

Cons: The gameplay is extessively grinding, and frankly, more annoying than fun. Your heroes will constantly be down recovering from horrors, your gold will dwindle as you end up retreating, and the RNG is merciless in battering you even in the lowest dungeons.

This is not recommended, and I'll wait to see if they either fix it, or drop it to $1 as a bargain bin.

Early Access Review

Hard but Fun

This is one of those games that does not hold your hand, in fact, it's a challenge but a well designed one.

The world is beautifully made and does a great job at depicting a dark and desprate land.
The combat is challenging but has a good element od strategy allowing you to get out of tight spots.

The game overall feels like a bit of a grind as you repeat a lot of the same events but the large variation of characters/items makes up for it.

It feels very rewarding seeing your troops go from lowly bums to brutal warriors.


If you like the artstile and are prepared to lose a lot, try it out.

reviewText:
A potentially great game stretched too thin for my tastes.

I found that there are two challenges to this game; difficulty and the time it takes to get gold.  The former was enjoyably demanding, the latter was a chore.

I enjoyed the first 30 hours but after accumulating 7 characters of final tier level I realised that in order for them to meet their full potential and have a good chance of beating the final dungeons they'd need to have afflictions removed, have good equipment and positive traits locked in.  Which takes money, LOTS of money.  Which means repeating dungeons, LOTS of dungeons, to the point of boredom.

I already felt slightly weary with the repetition when entering 30+ hour mark but carried on since I felt the end was in sight.  However, another 10 hours later, when I realised what would be required to complete the game, I felt like I was facing another 40+ hours - mainly grinding at lower level stuff.

It's a shame since there are so many cool things to do with the characters and so many classes to mess around with.   From experimenting with and increasing certain skill sets, to paying to permanently keep certain bonuses they have earned, it's an exciting prospect.  Doing this would really individualise them, add an extra layer of depth and greatly increase the RPG feel of it all but again, this costs money, TONS of money.  Cue even more grinding.

Simply put, I feel this could have been a great 40-50 hour game but the constant halt in progress to get obscene amounts of gold to heal, cure and upgrade the roster is so time consuming the game ends up artificially increasing its playtime beyond my interest and desire.  I'm guessing they made this decision in order to 'double down' on the difficulty but I find testing people's patience through grinding isn't a fun form of challenge.

Having said all that, if you pick it up cheap and get 30+ hours of enjoyment before repetition sets in then I guess that could be viewed as money well spent....just take into consideration that you won't finish the game in that time frame, beat the bosses nor see your characters and township reach their full potential.  Not even close. Whether that's a deal breaker is, of course, for you to decide.  If it isn't, then have fun :)

reviewText:
I cannot recommend this game to you unless you meet a very small criteria of type of people.

The other negative reviews hammer home the points. Certain classes are just better and the changes made over time with this game have not made it so those classes are stronger, at best, the strong classes became weaker or were changed in ways to make them weaker. When I first bought this game, I would take random parties for no light dungeon runs in order to make some quick cash for my main party to be able to afford some upgrades or be able to afford to prepare for a dungeon after buying a very good trinket.

I came back to the game just today and have played for a few hours. I attempted what I did before with a little mix and match. It did not go well and not in an RNG sort of way. The party was just not effective and I abandoned the quest and them pretty quickly. Thus I was able to get back to my good party who was getting through dungeons with only minor problems and the occasional amount of stress reaching a moderate level where I would need to go to an off team to deal with the stress. The problem here is that it creates an absolute issue with regards to the classes. There are classes that are good and there are classes that are not. If you take the wrong classes, the game is hard. If you take the right classes, the game is not hard.

Now I will say that the art, sound, and music are all top notch. They have been from the beginning. The story is Lovecraftian Horror, so think depressing. If you don't like the idea of a cosmic horror that is going to win no matter what and we are just delaying the inevitable. Do not play this game.

Personally for me, I used to have fun experimenting with different parties and seeing whether they could scrape by while doing something that no sane real adventurers would do. That's not possible anymore and the design decisions all led here. I once told myself I wouldn't buy early access games anymore and this game reinforces that decision. Until I see the final product, I do not plan on buying most games.

TL:DR This game might be for you if you like a game where there is one way to win and you like Lovecraftian Horror with a touch of RNG.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

IntroductionDarkest dungeon, is shortly saying a game that is played against you.
The game itself is a rpg- turned base stressfull game.
Its at this point it's in early acces.

Section Title*the story : The story itself is quite witty, wich makes it fun if you appriciate that kind of humor.
Your hero's mention some witty comments about themself or how they go insane.

*The graphics : A diffirent style then what you would see in most RPG games, It is quite dark
but then again the game didn't steal it's name.

*Gameplay : well... What can I honestly say?
The game is made to make you go insane with frustration and anger,
It is build to go against you, Wich makes it really addicting because you really want to beat the game.

Somehow one of your hero's gets rabbies, or gets scared and therefor moves to the last position.
You just start cursing on how they react and wish you where in the game yourself.
But the more frustrating the more you get into the game.

The longer you play the more you realise how hard it is, how hard it is to collect gold,
to delete the negative effects from your hero's. give it positive effects,and so on.

In the end you can let your hero's gamble- drink-rest. everything to make them happy right?
They can sing to eachother peacefully next to a campfire, or be selfish and take all the food for themself.

You will need some strategy tho, see what fits together. So theorycrafting is also fun in this game
with strategy I mean more : with what hero will you pick up the bookcase, Will you leave it?
or will you take the risk? It is something you will need to think about.

*Soundtrack : Just like the graphics, it isn't something you find generally in an RPG
It is quite stressfull music when everything goes dark, a little bit halloween style.

*Money-wise : Do I think the game is worth so much? Yes I do, the game is something you can play for hours non stop. You can start over or you can continue. so the time you would put into this
is for me worth the money.


Overall VerdictIf you are willing to have patience, anger, frustration, sadness (because oh no all your effort)
then this is tottaly worth it.

Do not forget this is an early acces game, things can still change.
There will still be some bugs, and changing incomming.

Overall Score: 9/10

reviewText:
I am very sad about this game. I had such high hopes for it. It is a great concept, it has great art, it has a great vibe, the voice acting is terrific so what could have gone so wrong?

The gameplay.

It all boils down to one problem. If you want to have a game about psychological damage the most important thing is that the player should care about the characters, a lot. You have to set it up to say you are stuck with this guy however insane it gets". You have to feel like you are on a minecart ride to hell where then only way out is to go all the way down.

Instead what this game does is throw hundreds of characters at you. You need 4 per week to make an adventuring squad but you can get up to 8 replacements! So yeah you end up with a massive squad of 16 adventurers whose names you don't even know. Has one of them gone insane? Chuck them out and get another to fill their place. Everyone is disposable.

Drowning in characters means it's impossible to care about any of them. It's such a shame because this game could have been a true great
date: instead it's a complete fail.\n\nIf they just made it so that you had a small squad which you needed to cherish
recommended: with maybe a replacement every once in a while. If only you had to sit in the town thinking "I really want to stay here for another week to rest but I need to keep pressing on deeper into the dungeon because I have to beat the timer" this really could have been a huge win.\n\nInstead they bungled it."

reviewText:
This game has hidden behind the Early Access shield as a means of blocking criticism. In the last month at all, they had Reddit manipulate reviews so that the 100+ negative reviews that had dominated for the last 6 months would be buried, and replaced with recent positive reviews. They have spammed everywhere about how they recieved awards for looking good, from an organization that literally only deals with indie devs who bribe them. And now, in the hours before they expose themselves, all they have done is spam Twitch streamers with custom narrator quotes for their channels and not ya know, actually fix or complete the game. Now they no longer have that shield, so I can fully blast them for their myriad failings from a design perspective, a marketing perspective, and a community management perspective. You can read all the old stuff here.[pastebin.com] Here's a TL;DR of this game's stagnation and a quick Q and A:

Has the game added content during Early Access? No, not really. There's a fourth and fifth area you grind through the same as the other 3, and there's four new classes that run off the same one dimensional game mechanics and that's about it. That's all the game has gotten in nearly 12 months, so if you think all the missing content will be added in the last month I offer great deals on bridges. Missing content such as actual Roguelike elements, proper exploration mechanics, tactical (instead of damage spam based) combat... you know, the things that would make this a game and not a walking simulator.

Has the game improved during Early Access? Nope. In Feburary the game was shallow but has the promise of potential that let people see it through and have bright hopes for the future. It's still shallow, and it's actively moved away from its own vision with every patch while the developers continually prattle about that very thing.

Has the marketing strategy improved since Early Access? No, it has also degenerated. They are even more aggressively spammy than ever, particularly regarding video content creators. What's more, the game goes on ever increasing sales every month, often more than once on the same month. Any time you see an Early Access game getting massive discounts you should smell the desperation a mile off, and it shows because sales are the only time the game gets any sales (along with large numbers of votes on the negative reviews that have wholly dominated it for the past 6 months). Curiously, despite that they had the audacity of raising the price on release.

Has the community management improved during Early Access?  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mx2V-D-Xdq8 They started merely ignoring criticisms, then became corrupt, censoring, suicidal indie devs. After attracting the ire of Jim Sterling Son they became marginally more subtle (and also already censored most of the prime targets) Mostly they stick with letting their community stalk, harass, and commit real world crimes against their critics with their unspoken permission, while spinning delusional narratives during every interview" of the past 6 months about how critics in general
date: or one specific critic in particular (me) have no valid points because their game is perfect since the only things anyone could have any problems with are optional (and that's not true either). During these mock interviews they spend more time in rampant denial their game has any problems whatsoever than they do discussing what they believe are its positive traits. Should the interviewer put on a sufficiently shillish performance they will even be hired (see: RektHookJohn).\n\nHas the community improved during Early Access? No
recommended: that's the biggest casualty. It started out about what you'd expect. Lots of challenge gamers
hoursPlayed: pretty level minded and intelligent people. Most of them left early because this game was nothing like that (and still isn't). Those that haven't have became very vindictive (see: me). And filling the gap is a lot of Johnny Come Latelies who are either unfortunately caught in the crossfire or the sorts that imploded what community that once existed in a manner of days with their raging hostility at all forms of criticism. Fun fact: No supporter has ever been banned no matter how out of line their actions were. They barely get warned
voteText: and reporting them is considered abusing the report feature.\n\nWhat else are they doing wrong? Revisionist history for one thing
helpfulPercent: where they conviently forget about things they've already done or that have already happened so they look good now and people not familiar with their past history but who are following them (most people) will be fooled. Very large amounts of tedium and grind mismarketed as difficulty - hell

reviewText: It had potential early on, but it's turned into a huge grind where way too much is left up to rng. So much of the game becomes recruiting fodder to send into the dungeons with no supplies so you can grind gold and other currency to heal your main group. Once the main group is healed you send them in to go for a boss, hoping that RNG doesn't bend you over and ♥♥♥♥ your ♥♥♥, forcing you to retreat and start the whole grind process all over again. It's fun at first, but the game becomes really tedious once you realize you're basically throwing expendable resources into a rng machine and hoping that something good comes out of it.\n\nIt's not all bad though, since I honestly love the art style and the narration is some of the best I've heard in any game. It's just an overall disappointing feeling because I'll see a snapshot of it on the store page or scroll by it in my library and say to myself  God dammit
date: I really wish I liked that game more than I do"."

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI currently can not recommend the game in its current form. I was very much enjoying it for a time and when hitting lvl 3 dungeons (not even on a boss yet) some of my main team died, the loss was unrecoverable. Stress generation is insane and needs to be lowered, just walking randomly in a hall you accumulate stress for instance. Heirlooms seem to be far too heavy on certin types, id have 3 of one and 60 of another which I couldnt use as everything takes multiple types. Debuff heaven!!! I think most of my charaters had about 5-6 negative effects each which you cant keep up with removing as there far too expensive at first and take a whole dungeon round to remove as well rendering the charater useless (and you can only do one at a time!). There are some small things I think would make the game better as well for instance a Rooms: #" on each dungeon so you can better plan for torches and food supply. Some GUI things i noticed were a little odd that could use improvement as well like when equiping items to charaters before a battle and having to close and open tons of windows to equip just 4 guys (a little popup would be cool as well if you have avalible items and one of your charaters is itemless

reviewText: With the upgrade paths in the different buildings being so linear, I feel like there's actually very little variance in this game and it's purely a matter of endurance instead of randomness: max everything out and go for the final dungeon. The problem is that this form of progression just isn't masked well enough to make the game endearing to play until the end, and being able to see what skills you'll get for each character makes it more of a chore and less of a reward.\n\nThe narration is interesting, but gets old fairly quickly. No way to turn it off either, just mute the narrator itself. The game's art style, easily being the highlight of this game, is striking and conveys a sense of dread and despair, but there's not much else propping it up in my opinion.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First the good:

The hand drawn artsyle is wonderful to look at and the chacter models are very distinguish from eachother.
Environments are nicely varied  ruins to farm to forest
The quirk system means its unlikely to get 2 chacters that fight and react the same which means sutle chances to your strategies
The narrator sounds like a combination of Morgan Freeman and David Attenborough, which is very important as he is the only means of gaing insight on why your here or what is going on in this accuresed place

Now the bad:

The tutorial doesnt explain enough of chacter stats, importance of sanity managment or the significance of the torch mechanic speaking of which
The torch mechanic is a neat idea if it was better explained and fleshed out more as it stands the difference between fully lit and pitch dark seems none existent it supposingly effects loot gaind and enemy health but i couldnt tell personly.
The torch mechanic does effect one thing in a big way the stress mechanic.
The stress mechanic is this game,s main gimmick it effects dialogue, effectiveness of heros and could ultimately turn a grave situation around or make your born to kill holy crusdaer use his allies as human shields and stick his thumb in his mouth (I wish i was joking ) the chief failing of this system is there is no way to control effectively since there are few heros that have stress reducing skills and fewer that actually make a differnce.
I saved the worse for last the rng (random number generator) this is the most annoying thing in the whole game.  I could just say this games a glorifed slot machine but that would be unfair and untrue.
The game isnt necessarily difficult, more infuriating due to the rng which means your entire team is crited to death or all your attacks are doged or do the equivalente damage of a summers kiss on the face of smiling baby under a autumn tree (sorry lost my train of thought)

As it stands the game does deserve alot of the praise it receives and this review is more of a critea of the area it falls short in.
To people wishing to buy this game wait for it to be complete (leave early access) before buying it or push youself to buy to test your own sanity and see if you yourelf will break

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Background: I supported this game on Kickstarter (liked the basic idea and the graphics) and  as I am not really interested in playing games that aren't mostly finished, I didn't bother with early access until a few weeks ago.

There really is a good game here, but it just tries too hard to be the hardest game around and the whole thing seems to be geared towards masochists. The problem is, that this game is not just hard, but that you must LOVE to lose to enjoy it. To make matters worse, you have keep a myriad little things under control to just keep going and lots of thing frustrating your efforts.
To be clear, I only lost two or three characters during my plays and didn't do too bad - so I am not rage rating. But I just realised, that I didn't have much fun. It's just not my cup of tea.

reviewText: Game starts out like a difficult RPG but quickly devolves into a resource management sim similar to a Facebook game like Farmville or Vampire Town. The reason for this is the much-too-punishing RNG over which the player has little control and there is simply no strategy to overcome. Because a single surprise attack can instantly destroy any character in your party, the only sensible way to proceed is to avoid taking any extra risks whatsoever. In the language of this game, this means sending out parties of throwaway characters and deleting them.\n\nThe game advertises itself as difficult" but a better explanation is that it is "grindy
date:
and the player forced into the role of an HR manager of a fast food restaurant where employees quit at random.

Doubling down on the resource Facebook-game aspect of DD, the game forces the player to gamble" prior to each mission and expend money on tools. This aspect of the game feels like a money trough.

Overall
recommended: game has some nice graphics and some promising features
hoursPlayed: but feels more like managing a Wendy's restaurant than a horror RPG."

reviewText:
The game mechanics suck. I don't mind playing difficult games, but when you invest hours of game play and this game just decides when you are going to lose. No matter what your numbers are, no matter how much planning went into your team, you are just going to lose because the game decides you need to lose your good squad. The gameplay is artificially being extended by creating impossible battles so you can lose your best squad and have to start over.

The game has some good ideas, it's just too bad the developers got lazy and took the easy way out by forcing your squad to get killed off artificially instead of having actual realistic game mechanics. There are instances in many games that involve good and bad luck and then there are games like Darkest Dungeon where the outcomes are predetermined. Predetermined outcomes are lazy and unenjoyable for the player. I won't play this game again and I wouldn't recoomend that anyone buy it either unless you enjoy frustration and being manipulated. Gotta go delete this garbage. Bye...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I just want to make sure that people who get into this game know what they're getting into, because there's a lot of dissapointment over that.

TL;DR This game is basically FTL meets Dark Souls meets Diablo.  None of which I've played because I don't like over powered RNGs, difficulty for the sake of difficulty, and insufferably long grinds.

I really wanted to like this game, I really did.  I love the visuals, I love the concepts, I even love some of the mechanics.  But what I love about the game doesn't override the horrible grind necessary to overcome its difficulty.  This game is about grind.  Only get this game if you have absolutely no intention of getting attached to any character ever.  The only path I have seen to success resides in the slow meat grinder approach.  If you can't accept that in any given encounter your favorite character (or any/all character(s) for that matter) might go from full health to dead then this is not the game for you.

Furthermore, one of the biggest problems I have with this game is with its community.  Anytime someone has a legitimate complaint about the game (mostly its difficulty) there is a litany of grinders that show up to scream git gud"
hoursPlayed: etc.  The problem is this game was designed for those people.  They're not sympathetic

votesHelpful: but these days I'm beginning to embrace the title

votesFunny: yet the developers opted out of this very reasonable option to cater to these "hardcore" gamers.  I think that is a huge mistake
commentsCount: and it is for that reason that I have shelved this game until it is made more playable for "casual" gamers."

reviewText:
The apparent commercial success of this title is the best example of style over substance I have ever seen in the context of PC gaming. There's a lot of style in this game and it is compellingly presented. However, the game that lies beneath the presentation layer is tedious and grindy. It's not a difficult game; it doesn't particularly challenge your intelligence, or memory, or reflexes or anything like that. What it is is a tedious and frustrating game. There is a difference.

If you are easily amused and like shiny things you may like this game. If you are easily bowled over by a slick presentation, and don't notice or care that you've been doing the same thing again and again and again - for hours - then you may like this game. A lot of people seem to. But if you are a more discerning person, well... I'll say no more. I just wish I had gotten a poster for my 20 dollars instead of what is essentially a gothic-reskinned version of Cookie Clicker.

BTW check out this critical review (it's not me, however I absolutely agree with what this person says):
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_Buwei6ZWqU

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I think at some point people just forgot what fun was.

This game is designed to be miserable. There's no payoff or any sort of interesting reward for thinking your way through missions. As you play through you'll gain more reward for finding exploits than thinking strategically.

I'd say something about the atmosphere and narration, but any game where your characters WILL die from a lucky enemy crit is anti-narrative, no story can be based around a group that will reliably cycle out (without exploiting the game) every few hours.

And no, it's not excused by being an early access.  It's literally a JRPG where your characters misery is a stat.  This could have been an interesting feature if stress was approached as a resource, used for spells, or used for the morally questionable goal of intentionally driving your characters insane. Here it's an in-game cash sink that tries to pointlessly humanize your boring dying meatsacks. This game may be popular, but it's got a long ways to go before it's good.

reviewText:
If you like games that will make you miserable.....

I have to strongly warn any and all interested that it will produce in the player massive levels of anger, frustration, and salt the likes of which you would not even find playing the likes of Dark Souls on a bad day. At least in a game like Dark Souls skill takes precedence and makes the game gradually more enjoyable. In this game, you are never not a victim to the RNG. When things go well, they go very well. But when things go bad, it honestly feels like the developers are giving you the finger and kicking you in the balls with a smug smirk for good measure.

I've pushed on through this game and managed to defeat every beginner and veteran boss with two of the intermediate bosses (the dreaded Swine God and the Hag Witch) under my belt. But I've recently thrown in the towel and decided I can't push myself any further. It isn't simply a matter of the RNG either; the intermediate dungeons are too difficult with enemies that will frequently have both high dodging AND protection stats making each battle a slow grind and a fight for your life. That there are ways to mitigate the enemies ability to survive your attacks with debuffs barely helps when the debuffs tragically miss, making that character's turn wasted, or when you simply don't have anyone on your team available to do such a thing. It doesn't help that you can't ever go anywhere without a healer, whose healing skills are so hit and miss you're constantly on the edge of your seat whenever they attempt to patch your crumbling team together.

Where the difficulty goes overboard is with an enemy called The Collector that you are guaranteed to fight at least once randomly in EVERY intermediate level dungeon. These enemies are the biggest asshats due to their ability to continually respawn allies which can either heal or protect it while it too heals itself by draining life from your team to refresh its already huge pool of helth. The reward for defeating this enemy, an item worth a lot of gold, won't even cover your losses at the end of the quest when you have to send your team to the tavern or the abbey to undo their accumulated stress (assuming you can even survive).

Where I quit was in a dungeon where I had just barely survived an encounter with this most dreaded of foes only for TWO of my high level heroes whom I had already invested much money into upgrading, BOTH died, in a game with perma death no less. That brought the toll of dead heroes to ten and caused me to delete my save file in frustration. I don't mind (too much) if a hero dies valiantly while fighting a boss which I then proceed to defeat, but when it happens randomly due to some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t RNG it brings my blood to a boil and I have to fight not to hurl my laptop across the room.

It's sad, because I like this game. I really, truly do. But it is TOO F&%#ing hard!!! Would it honestly kill them to dial down the difficulty just a bit? Even to allow you to purchase disposable healing items so you're not constantly relying on healers who can only heal during battle? When every quest becomes a desperate roll of the dice not just to progress the game but to just get yourself out of the black so you can invest in hero upgrades then it becomes more of a painful chore than a thrill. Especially when you see all that hard work go down the drain due to some random trick of the RNG. (Like missing four times in a row when trying to kill even a single enemy!)

I like hard games but I'm getting sick and tired of this meat-head git gud" mentality which is plaguing games lately and making people feel ashamed for just wanting to have fun.

This game is too hard. Not hard but rewarding kind of hard
recommended: like the worst day of your life at the worst job you've ever had and when deep in debt to boot. Would it be such a bad thing if they just make it a little more forgiving?????"

Early Access Review

Sorry but no,

I tried to like this game. I really tried. A friend of mine recommended the game and the style and scenario sounded awesome. And it really is a good game and one day I might try it again.

Bought it during mid-week sale and started playing; 4 days later on Saturday morning I was fed up with it. Most of the time you are just hoping that nothing “too” bad might happen. And most of the time things happen, which you cannot influence. A hard game is nice, but starting the game right now is just unfair. Even more experienced players might disagree, my friend also did.

Following I like to point out why I do stand by my opinion:

1. The difference between virtue und afflictions is just too much; if one reaches virtue everything is fine. If on the other side reaches one affliction like irrational the changes of success" in the expedition are very low to no existing any more. One affliction will cause another one (best were three irrational people during one fight) and heardattacks are just waiting.

2. Getting rid of stress is too hard. The enemy crits you: 10 stress for the target and some stress for the person next to him. You crit
date: maybe 3 or 5 stress relief. That's ok
recommended: but if you are a Vestal or a Plague Doctor who heals
hoursPlayed: the crits are rare. And lasts due to DOT's like blight or bleed do not grand stress relief. So no stress relief for you Plague Doctor. The worst is having a hero with a stress level of 40-50 in your town. Sending him into the tavern or the abbey costs a lot of gold (compared to your loot
voteText: I will get to that) and it might have a "nice" perk
helpfulPercent: like losing additional resources or him just leaving for a while. On the other side there might also be a disease (I love the plagues) or some negative character quirks which you was gifted during your last journey and might need treatment. I had one Level 3 hero which was then to proud to join my expeditions any more

votesTotal: torches etc. but still I was barely able to loot enough to cover the costs of the expedition and heal from afflictions
votesFunny:
sicknesses or negative character quirks. Not even speaking of healing a permanent negative character quirk or locking in positive one. That was much out of reach.

All the mentioned things were not part of the game before. From what I read they became mostly part of the game during the last bigger patches and its unfortunate I just started playing; but I seems that many players who just started faced the same troubles.

More experienced players seem to disagree. In my opinion they tend to disagree mostly due to affect that their mentions are already maxed out
commentsCount:
the higher costs did not hit them that hard. Their heroes are already high level and are able to face the fears; just coping with them became harder. So more experienced are happy with these new dangers. But starting right now with them is just too much burden. RNG just crashes your endeavors from try to try.

And to try dark runs without any equipment to gain a small amount of loot and get rid of the poor "victims" is no opinion for me; that is just stupid grinding! Furthermore it does not help the heroes you try to prepare for higher level dungeons and they might get die anyway due to RNG.

So in conclusion I cannot recommend the game right now. Even with the option to disable heart attacks or corpses (which I think is not the worst of ideas due the importance of the hero and the enemy position for some attacks) I will recommend it. I wanted a challenging game

reviewText:
It's a bit fun at first, but it gets old very quickly.

If you wanna try playing something almost identical to it, there's a way to do it for only one cent. Simply flip the coin; if it's heads, you win and everybody is happy. Tails, you lose and you can try again.

Seriously, though, 90% of the game is dictated by dice rolls. There are certainly some levels of strategy, team building, and upgrades, but overall it's just dice rolls. Unlike good RPG's, you can't do much of anything to affect those dice rolls. It's quite possible that it becomes more affected by choice later on, but certainly in the beginning, choices don't matter at all. Why play a game where your choices make no difference? You get just as much enjoyment out of watching someone else play, because choice genuinely doesn't matter.

I had really high hopes for this game, and it looks so great - both the art style, and the gameplay in general. But in practice, the game completely fails to deliver. I wish I had a game that was exactly like Darkest Dungeon in every way, just it punished you for having poor tactics instead of punishing you for simply playing the game. Every time I play, I hope I can find what others apparently see in the game, that same ideal that I had hoped for when I first bought it. Instead, I can't help but feel that the developers are laughing at me for buying their game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The opportunity to create a tactical, interesting, and rewarding game supported by great art and spot-on tone has been squandered.  Instead, you are treated to a game where RNG is king and your decisions are only as good as your ability to get lucky enough that they actually take effect.

Mechanically, the game is a complete mess.  If you take the time and effort to develop a party and learn how to leverage the systems of the game, it really does look like there is something special here, but is it worth the pain of dealing with sloppy mechanics for 15 hours so you can actually start playing a game where your decisions just start to become meaningful?  I personally do not think so.

reviewText: I wanted to like this game. I really did. I gave it a fair trial.\n\nThe central problem lies with sheer randomness. You simply cannot know when an enemy attack will inflict a massive critical hit, taking one of your heroes from full health to death's door" in a single blow. In my final attempt to send a fully-outfitted expedition to destroy the "Formless Flesh
date:
I encountered a troup of common rogues, the kind I'd fought many times before. This time, a couple of critical hits took my knight and my bounty hunter down to death's door, and a bullwhip multi-strike killed both of them before I could take meaningful action. Random chance of so wide a range is simply not fun in a game.

Mind, I like difficult games! For example, I thoroughly enjoyed Alien: Isolation. But there, one dies because one fails to understand the antagonist and anticipate its next move. In Darkest Dungeon, no amount of preparation or strategy will save you from the true enemy -- sheer dumb luck.

Additionally, while the bosses (the necromancer, the Formless Flesh, the Swine King, the Hag, and the Ghost Pirates) are all well-conceived and executed, the game demands you fight each no less than four times, making the game repetitive. The campaign long overstays its welcome.

The creators have created an involving game, with many fun elements. If they made critical hits far less frequent and less devastating, and trimmed the tedious recycling, I would try this again. But I sadly cannot recommend it in its current state.

Addendum: I have now tried many mods in an attempt to rebalance the game. Unfortunately, the latest patch appears to have rendered existing mods obsolete, as most of them now cause the game to crash or lock.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've tried to play this game with the advise given on the opening screen. I'm aware that the game is designed to involve constant meat-grinding of the characters. That is not an issue I cannot overcome. There is a lot that, with enough polish, would make for an amazing game. Even meat-grinders have their place.

So what went wrong? You know that feeling where you're telling Windows to do something but Windows is ignoring you to do something else? This game has something even worse. In this game, that frustration is an intentional feature. As you play the characters you're controlling go insane, and they have a chance of ignoring your input to perform other, deliberately inconvenient, actions. The game's designers believe they are trying to model mental illnesses, but instead all that's happening is they refuse to do what's in their own best interests.

Reviewing a game like this is particularly gut-wrenching because the developers had a really good game. The earlier sections, where the characters are still usable, have definite promise. There is a lot of nuance and a lot of interesting stuff in those sections, but the developers lost sight of what appeals to the fans of strategy games. If they had simply placed limits that were somehow understandable so that the player could work around them in-the-moment then cope with the baggage later on, the game could have been amazing. Unfortunately, what starts out as an engrossing every-move-matters strategy game quickly degenerates into something unpredictable. No more strategy. When your planning doesn't matter anymore there's just a typical par-for-the-course you have to have a healer" click-fest.

Hit points are all that matters in this game. Heal people. Damage people. Heal yourself more than they damage you. You can't account for the nuance anymore
date: so who cares about all of the flavor and the details. The game is just going to have disorganized shizophrenia anyway."

reviewText:
If i could give this game something between a thumbs up and a thumbs down i would.

It has great use of art style, narration, dungeon crawling, and the lovecraftian theme. The dark world you need to traverse affects your heroes on an emotinal and mental level. It really helps you feel the impact of the insane situation you find yourself in, watching your party slowly lose their minds from the horror they face.

Every battle and dungeon expedition is narrated by excellent voice acting, and going into dungeons forces you to think about what supplies to bring and what to throw away for space. Sometimes bandages are more valuable than gold.

I have a great deal of respect for what this game tries to do

However...

Many pivotal moments in this game come down to a throw of the dice. No matter how hard you preapre, no matter how well thought out your stratagy, everything can fall apart at a instant. A poorly timed miss, a weak heal, or a well placed crit can spell out death for the party youve spent a long time preparing, and there is nothing you can do about it. Hours of progress can be wiped in an instant.

This unfortunately can and will lead to large amounts of grinding, whether for money or levels, through the same dungeons youve been to time and time again. Progress in this game is slow, painfully so, and the final darkest dungeon requires many heroes to be max level. Fully upgraded max level heroes that can die at a moments notice.

I imagine the devolpers of this game wanted the player to feel as stressed as the party they are playing as, because every fight is a challenge, and the fear of losing it all will put you on edge, but when you lose a full team (or even a half team) of level 6 heroes, it can be depressing to the point of game quitting especially near the end game. Its like putting 50 hours into a big game youre trying to 100% only to have your file deleted.

This game absolutely has its merits and you can tell the developer put much time into it. However, the heavy focus on RNG and the repetative grind hold this game back from being something truly special.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I bought this game a few weeks ago and have been having a blast playing it, at least up until the Inhuman Bondage update. Playing after that update it has turned into nothing by a pointless meatgrinder that spams you with stress and doesn't seem like you are doing anything other than playing a slot machine. The Devs have been very clear that they only want you to play the game the way that they want and have spammed the game with ridiculous mechanics changes in order to punish players; the most prominent is the 'Stall' mechanic that punishes you for trying to heal your party in combat, the only time that you can heal them. Setting aside that they are giving the finger to people that prefer a slower, more cautious playstyle, the mechanic itself is broken it will hit you if you don't manage to kill a single remaining opponent before the round ends and you can completely sidestep it by leaving 2 weak monsters alive instead of one.

TL;DR
The Devs seem to be hellbent on taking a great game and ruining it as thoroughly as they possibly can. Don't buy unless they release the final version with all of their bad decisions undone.

reviewText:
If you are the type of gamer that is okay with leaving a game unfinished then there is 10-20 hours of great turn based dungeon crawling to be had. I had a lot of fun with this game getting my characters up through the initial stages and into medium and hard dungeons. Unfortunatly the game becomes a huge grind at this point.  Because death is permament and sudden a few bad encounters or even a couple of bad rolls within an encounter can kill a character that can take upwards of 3 hours to replace, and that is just the for the xp. Currently the best stratagy for seeing end game content in a reasonable period of time is to take a set of 4 newbies from the stagecoach (they are free and how you replenish lost heros) and tossing them into a dungeon with no supplies and getting rid of the survivors.

The RNG in this game is really heavy, and don't let people explain it away as skill. Every attack in the game can miss, can be dodged, can hit, or can crit. Dodges and Misses do no dammage while normal attacks have fairly large ranges, a level 4 hellion hit for between 9-19 dammage on normal mobs who had health in the 20-30 range. So you could concievably crit and 1 shot a guy or miss twice and have 2 low dammage rolls and have him still alive on turn 5. Even outside of combat the RNG is pretty random. The one that gets me the most is the hunger checks, before you enter a dungeon you must supply your group with food, torches, and utility items like keys and shovels.  You eat food while crawling to replenish small amouts of HP and when camping in medium and long dungeons.  You also need food randomly when moving between rooms, doesn't matter when your previously ate, or if your party was full (you get full by eating 2-3 food). I have gotten 3 hunger checks before i cleared 5 rooms and have never had one in long dungeons.  Makes everything you provision for exept torches a gamble.

But all that RNG is in the spirit of a dungeon crawler like this.  My real issue with the game is the late game grind.  In my experiance it takes 11 sucessful runs to get a hero to level 6, on top of that you will likely need to rest a hero at least once between runs to reduce stress, cure diseases, and purge negitive perks, you can only do 1 of these at a time and they all cost increasing ammonts of gold as you level up.  You also need to upgrade, linearly, a heros skills, armor, and weapons. I would love to see what ammount of money i put into my A-team members, a wild guess would put the number in the neighborhood of around 70,000 each.  And considering the most money i have ever pulled from a dungeon was around 25k means losing 1 or 2 of them like I did on a hard boss makes me quit the game because i am unwilling to grind out the multiple hours of repeditive gampleay needed to replace them.

I still play the game in short sessions now but i seriously doubt i will ever have enough time or energy to finish it.  There is a core of a good game here that is padded out unnessaraly to the point that (as of now) only 0.4% of people have finished it (according to achievments) and only 0.2% of people have completed without changing any of the settings to make the game easier.

reviewText:
The game has great atmosphere and graphics. Initially I thought it was really fun. After a few hours I realized it's not an rpg, but a hero managment game with combat.  Still allright. I leveled heores, my town, got rid of some heroes, realized you don't need them torches so much and so on. Boss fights were cool. Combat seemed varied initially, many character and skill combinations. The perk system is awesome.

After a while the combat got really boring. And then I realized that the combat was the same as you progress, only the numbers get bigger. The game punishes failed experimentation with grind. Basicaly - do something stupid, you either grind to lvl up a new hero, or to fix your mistakes. This is an okay concept - unless you start finding the combat boring.

Anyway I was playing it, went to a dungeon, and combat started. A not too hard, but boring battle. I needed resources to continue building my town. I realized I would have many more of very, very similar encounters ahead. Also, the movement started feeling ridiculous, I felt like I had to hold arrows for absolutely no reason. I started wishing for a play/pause button.

I never played again. Basically, if you don't LOVE the combat, you will grow to resent it.

Most people like this game, but it is definetly not for me.

reviewText:
How to completely ruin a perfectly good game in 5 easy steps:

1: Start a Kickstarter, gain a significant following for a unique game with all sorts of lofty promises.
2: Get your game into Early Access, Steams Sales for everyone and whatnot. Game delivers great experience while still being challenging.
3: Let it go to your head. Start adding artificial difficulty because a small minority of players decided the game wasn't hard enough.
4: Nerf the drop rates for essential items. RNG spawn rediculously difficult enemies on low level dungeons. Make the game even more grindy in order to artificially extend the game.
5: Make any party that undertakes a mission in the final dungeon unable to enter the dungeon again, essentially rendering that party, and all the time and energy put into them, completely useless, extending the grind even further.

3/10 Grind simulator 2015

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Stress management 101

Do you like to micro manage?  Then this is the game for you.  I can't even focus on enjoying the game because I'm constantly having to manage all the stress, diseases, and negative quarks the game throws at you.  95% of the books and chests result in negative stats.  The attacks miss a lot even though they should be hitting 80% of the time.

After every venture down into the depths, you have to send your warriors out for stress relief or you risk losing them to a heart attack.  Does this sound like fun?  Well it wouldn't be so bad if the damn stress meter didn't fill up like Bill Gates bank account.  I had a warrior gain 100+ stress in one random battle and die of a heart attack 5 minutes into a level.  If you manage to make it out alive, you have to send all of your warriors with high stress (so basically all of them) on to stress relief hubs, where you have to pay extremely hefty fees and lose them for the next round.  Then you run out of money and cannot buy food and torchs, so you're forced to go into the level with base stat recruits with no money, food, or torches.  Sould like fun yet?  And that is with the level being fully lit up.  Did I mention the torch mechanic?

You have to constantly use torches to light up the room or you risk packing on the stress.  How long does a torch last?  ooooh about 3 seconds.  A torch costs 75 gold too and drains your bank account.  This stress mechanic is not innovative, fun, or interesting.  I want to play a rogue-like gothic RPG, not a %%%%ing stress management simulator.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For a game in Early Access, there's a lot here that you can sink your teeth into. It makes you wonder why fully priced AAA titles can't be as polished as this game is right now, but I digress.

This is a game as much about party management as it is exploring dungeons. The more you use each member of your pary, the more stress they gain, gain enough and they're unusable until you remove it. This forces you to use a wide varity or party members, running the same random generated dungeon doing different quests to get rewards.

This is not a game for those who want something light and fun. You'll lose party members (permadeath), you constantly have to balance each members positive ance negative attributes, watch their stress and weigh weather continuing with almost no health and dying is better than escaping early and putting one or more of your party into a fully stressed state, not to mention watching your supplies.

This is not an easy game, but it is damn fun and well worth the investment if you're up to the challenge.  Seriously, even if you're against buying games in Early Access, this is one of those rare exceptions where what you're getting is already getting enough content to call this a complete game by many peoples standards.

EDIT; In the interest of fairness, there is one aspect of the game pertaining to combat that I dislike greatly. That is how your party will get rearranged if suprised. It's an annoyance since you need to spend turns getting people back into position where they're most effective.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A wonderful game with a beautiful art style.  Darkest Dungeon is one of those games that's simple to grasp the basics of but difficult to master - add in the randomly generated dungeons and you have a recipe for instant chaos for the unwary.  I hesitated when buying it at full price, but for a pre-released game it is suprisingly slick with very few bugs - running better than some fully released games!

The dark, lovecraftian story breeds an atmosphere that will get your own heart pounding as your heroes adventure deep into the dungeon.  My advice?  Read everything, upgrade as much as you can and don't forget your torches.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a really good game!

I was actually very surprised. I really like what the developers have done here and where the game has the potential to go with regards to its continued development, expansions and sequels. It's a hard dungeon-crawler, but it is not impossible to complete once you have an understanding of all the mechanics. I like the looting system. I like the tension the game builds as you become more and more attached to your characters. I like how your characters have distinct personality traits that actually impact gameplay. Basically, this game goes places that are beyond the limited brains of most committee-run, AAA game development companies.

So, Darkest Dungeon is a rogue-like (not rouge-like) dungeon crawler with great art design and excellent immersion. It is definitely worth the money. In actual fact, it is the best purchase I have made in a while. Bravo! Seriously, this game is worth it for $20! It would be worth it for $40!
