reviewText:
Early Access Review

Probably one of the best Early Access games out right now. That said, there are still some things I dislike about the game.

1. The RNG can feel a little TOO RNG and doesn't feel like you can manipulate it enough in your favor early on.

2. Buffs besides the Jester's Battle Ballad seem extremely underwhelming as you could just as easily deal more damage or keep yourself from taking more damage by attacking instead.

3. The lock on lower level quests when a character hits level 3 kind of sucks. It makes sense that they did this since it keeps on from power leveling characters, but since there is no middle point between dungeon lvls 3 and 1 (i.e. lvl 2) it is a huge spike in difficulty especially if one does not yet have the money/resources to unlock and upgrade their skills, armor, and weapons to a high enough level. On the topic of powerleveling lower levels, it is an even bigger slap in the face since Dungeons get harder the more they are beaten. In turn, it is harder to level up new recruits and becomes almost impossible. While this is somewhat interesting and gives a psuedo time limit on how quickly you need to beat the game, it is also extremely annoying and makes you want to almost start all over again and just say ♥♥♥♥ IT to your current save file.

Solution to 3: If they want to keep this kind of setup it would be nice if they had dungeons set up so that even though they do increase in difficulty, there will always be one apprentice mission available for lower level characters. This will allow new characters to be recruited and allow people to play with party compositions more without hurting the increasing difficulty of the game's dungeons overall.

These are my major gripes with the game. The rest of the game I find quite great besides a few minor things that will most likely either be tweaked or added to in the future.

TL;DR This game is great besides a few things that will make you wanna flip a table.


I will most likely update this review as the game gets updated and as I progress further in the game. I do enjoy this game deeply and have been looking for a turn based rpg like this for a while. Hope this was helpful. <3

reviewText:
Early Access Review

On my first play through of this game, I thought it was brilliant. I got to week 19 before I ran out of cash after a couple of bad runs. I thoroughly enjoyed the games setting, mood, and mechanics.

I eagerly started a 2nd run, and that's where things just went bad. I found myself failing on the first quest I set out on, before I had to restart a new game, and this happened at least 8 times before I packed it in. The game is HUGELY unbalanced at the moment, and is very reliant on luck.

The first quest you go on should ease you into the game. Now, while I understand this is an unforgiving roguelike, you need to at least be able to get your foot in the door before your good or bad decisions in the hamlet start affecting your survivability. On the first quest, you have no options, no chance to improve your party, you just get 4 guys and off you go.

Literally every first quest I've restarted since my first playthrough has been littered with misses, enemies dodging, whilst they constantly crit crit crit. At the end of the first quest, if I even made it that far, they were all maxed on stress and bleeding out. Back at the hamlet, you spend all your gold treating them, only able to take 2/3 people with you next run due to stress, and then die.

Also, why would it recommend on the provisions screen to take just food and torches, when on the first screen...the FIRST screen, I'm faced with 2 piles of rubble. No shovels! Great! That's 50% stress on all characters just after getting in to the dungeon!

Eventually I gave up. Today I tried another 2 playthroughs, but each time on the first mission, as badly as it went, I now started getting a crash error when walking near a lootable object which prevented me from proceeding. So never mind the RNG royally screwing you over constantly, now there's game ending bugs in it.

The game needs rebalancing hugely. I must have been very lucky my first playthrough, but since then, just extremely unlucky. There doesn't seem to be a middle ground. When these game breaking bugs are fixed and the game actually gets balanced, it would be a very very enjoyable game indeed, but until then, based on how random the game is, it doesn't even allow you to play it, and cannot be recommended.

Immensely disappointed.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

WHY THIS GAME IS UNIQUE:

I recently picked up Darkest Dungeon because it appealed to my inner masochist and fascination with the whole medieval/gothic atmosphere thing. As an avid veteran of Demon's Souls/Dark Souls series, I came into this game literally prepared to die, but mostly aware of the challenges I would probably face. I also knew that being in early access development, some mechanics may be a little off or missing altogether. That is why I was so surprised only a couple hours in by how engrossing and complete this dark world felt. Immediately, the narrator steals the scene, reminding me of something akin to running commentary in Bastion. This constant audio companion (voiced by Wayne June) comments on your adventure at nearly every turn, whether in town to tell you a random tidbit of lore, or in battle to convey the sense of the turning of the tide. It is exciting and easily the most unique aspect of this game. Honestly, this man was nearly enough to keep the whole game going on his own.

Eventually, though, the glaring problems arise, and they had me scratching my head as to why. The biggest enemy in Darkest Dungeon is not the end boss, the unpredictable fights and traps along the way, or the growing list of mental problems besieging your heroes. The biggest issue is gameplay balance during what you do most - fights. It is curious because these mathematical equations that they have in place are possibly the easiest thing about the game to fix because they are not design hurdles, but rather poor ratios and percentages that might be fixed in a patch. As a veteran of XCOM, I was prepared for the occasional how is it possible to miss a shot at 97% three times in row?" However
recommended: so much so that it actively forced me out of my initial fascination and into realizing that this is poor design by choice. You stop believing or even caring about this difficult world to live in because it turns into a Game of Thrones on steroids - a punishment just for punishment sake. You may realize this when you are fully prepared for an "easy" dungeon

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIt has been one year and ten weeks now since I returned home to claim my birthright. The hamlet has grown under my good management, but grown into what? The sanitarium dominates the skyline beside the church. The wails of the sick and the insane join the chanting of the faithful, echoing throughout the night. The tavern has become a sprawling facility where debauchery attempts to hold madness at bay. The arrival of the stage coaches is a constant cycle, fresh blood to feed the unshakeable thirst of these corrupted lands my ancestor bequeathed to me. Many have fallen. The markers of heroes crowd the graveyard, many standing over empty earth, in memorial for champions left in the field. A few familiar faces remain. Brinon, a Hellion who has served me for almost a full year, as fierce as she is resolute in the face of madness. Papelion, a Crusader stricken by his trauma, yet still a mighty sword arm. They make their home in the guild house, become now an imposing keep, the hamlet's only bulwark against predation. The blacksmith is their armory, ringing day and night with the industry of our crusade. Even now, a party patrols the ruins, risking all to end the devilry of a Necromancer lurking there. The odds are dire. Many have sacrificed life or soul to aid me in my quest to cleanse my ancestral home. And while I do not take the field, sometimes I wonder... What has it cost me to send so many to their deaths?

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I recommend this game with some strong qualifiers; The first being, don't share this game with anyone much younger than 18 years old. Many of the themes are very mature, to the point of being off-putting. (We're talking about blood, torture, prostitution, alcohol, gambling, etc.) While the way each of these is used adds to the overall atmosphere of degradation and mortality that really makes this game come alive, the disappointing thing is that this game plays so well and is so well put together that you would love to share it with everyone you know that likes videogames in your family. Be forewarned: This is not a family title, and you won't be able to play it in front of younger kids.

Personally, I myself find this game a little too graphic as an adult. And I'm not a huge fan of rogue-likes either. But as I stated a little while ago, this game uses these themes to make something that is unique and interesting. Besides these two complaints, I really can't find anything to dislike about the game. The artwork, sound, mechanics, the pace of the game, the goals, the obstacles and solutions, are all reminiscent of tabletop horror classics like Call of Cthulu, Werewolf: The Apocalypse and Vampire: The Masquerade. None of the negative mechanics feel fair or surmountable at first, but that's not the point; You're supposed to feel hopeless, fragile and overwhelmed in games like this. It makes you care about the outcome more knowing you can lose and that the consequences of your poor decisions are irreversible.

The game is centered around the idea that you're hiring mercenaries to dive dungeons in a doomed town where a prominent family is in need of them to reclaim their heirlooms. In exchange for cash and loot, the heroes agree to help recover the family valuables. You use these items to improve the services to and quality of the heroes that come there from abroad. While you can lose allies forever, you can easily replace them, and that makes these losses acceptable. Moreover, every character and class has things they're good and bad at even down to which of the class' abilities they start with, which makes you want to see more new heroes and take advantage of the ones you like once you can afford to equip them more thoroughly.

All in all, from the excellence of the plot, the depth of the combat and the beautiful presentation, Darkest Dungeon is undeniably a 10 out of 10 game. Nobody would expect to get an experience this complete with visuals and sound this spot-on from a team this small and underfunded. On top of all that, the price is fantastic. There's a ton of content here for $20. They did an excellent job, but just... This game just isn't my cup of tea. xD;

Update: Did I mention this game is *hard*? This game is really really hard. If you like difficult games, saddle up. This is for you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Usually I try to avoid early access. Mostly it is just rubbish that just gets tossed out in an attempt to make lots of money. But this is one of my favourite games already. I've got to say if it hadn't said early access, I wouldn't have noticed. The game feels well thought out, solidly coded and bug free so far.

I truely enjoy the gameplay and the difficulty. If you like turn based strategy combat, this game will be a great addition to your library. Having to juggle so many unavoidable things, such as resources, sanity and health. It is almost impossible to keep everyone in your party in the best conditions.

Controlling a ragtag group of adventurers through a dark and dangerous ruin is far from easy, but it is fun. Be warned, this game is not for the faint-hearted. The environment is against you, enemies are against you, and sometimes even your party is against you.

Heartily recommend.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is something I have been waiting for in turn-based RPG Horror. It reminds me of the good days of my youth with a traditional turn based game. I've spent many an hour playing and building my favorite party and I get to relive that in Darkest Dungeon. Im a Lovecraft fan to, so the backstory and mythos of this game really draws me in as it is, not to mention the customization for each class/character and party combinations. The survival/camping section is great idea because it lets groups with less healing to recover a bit of health and stress but each member could possibly gain/grant a buff to someone. There are a variety of enemies as well with different strengths and weaknesses that keeps you minding party composition and abilities. If there ever was a turn based Dark Souls game, this is what i would picture it as.
One thing i would like to see different is a little bit deeper of item customization but in this type of game i do not know how the coding would work, but thats fine, its great as it is.

Overall this is an amazing game and I would highly recomend it to any one who loves turn based horror and/or Lovecraftian games.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If final fantasy and XCOM had a baby, and that baby was posessed by unspeakable eldritch horrors, it would be this game.

Darkest Dungeon is a hallmark example of what a kickstarter and early access title should be. Superbly polished, innovative, and complete enough to provide a real picture of a final product.

As of this writing the game is in a complete and playable state, but missing a few planned character classes, and two of the five dungeons.

It is relentless, unforgiving, and gripping. The game does not lie to you when it tells you that Darkest Dungeon is a game about making the best of a bad situation. There are no save points. Your best adventurers will abandon you, or crack under pressure at the worst possible time. People will die. Just when you think you've got it all figured out, with an entire roster of skilled and meticulously set up adventurers you'll discover that your seasoned veterans are either too broken by the horrors they've seen, or too filled with pride to continue to casually stroll through the ease from whence they came.

There is a light at the end of the tunnel. It is within your power to leave those fetid halls at any time, forfeiting the rewards intended for the completion of your quest, but allowing you to keep what you've found during its execution. Should your army fall to darkness and madness, there is always a fresh supply of the wide eyed and eager arriving by coach to replenish your ranks at no cost but your own guilt.

You could have saved them. Most of them anyway. But you thought you could finish one more room. You thought it would all work out. You thought that a few thousand gold and a shiny trinket was worth the risk.

You were wrong. Those that you sacrificed on the altar of avarice and pride are commended to eternal sleep in your graveyard, and those that remain are broken by what they've seen.

So you send them to pray, or to drink, or you strap them down and attempt to stem the tide of insanity within the walls of your sanitarium. You replace the fallen and send them all further and deeper.

There is no game over. No real defeat. Not for you. You're simply the puppet master, and by the end you'll still be there, behind the stage, collecting the fee for this macabre theatre of the damned.

And you'll do it from atop a pile of broken, warped, and unrecognizable puppets.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Darkest Dungeon is one of the best games I've played in recent memory. It's hard to believe the early access tag.

This game aims to keep the player in a perpetual state of discomfort. If you're looking to play an indestructible badass then stay away. Your party of heroes will be fighting in the dark, often bleeding and slowly losing their minds. As the game puts it It's about making the best of a bad situation".

The classes feel unique and combat flows well. There's just enough numbers to give the system depth while trying to keep things simple. Debuffs are easy to understand and the importance of positioning quickly becomes apparent.

The game's not perfect by any means. The characters talk often and it wouldn't be so bad if the game didn't stop you from doing anything every time a dialog bubble pops up. My only other gripe is being subject to the randomness of available missions. Since specific mission rewards are needed for upgrades
date: not having any control is frustrating.\n\nThen again
recommended: the game is about making the best of bad situations.\n\nTL:DR Buy this game. It's maddeningly good."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW:

I normally urge you to err on the side of caution with Early Access titles, but this is Early Access done right. It is a relatively stable, solid experience that is pretty much feature complete, rather then being an idea for a game with graphics added to it. Red Hook Studios are communicative and are squashing bugs pretty quickly.

Every decision in this game has consequences, even the equipment you use has both positive and negative effects. The theme, art-style and mechanics of Darkest Dungeon combine to make something truly magnificent. This is an intelligent, unforgiving and brutally brilliant game. If you are remotely interested in RPGs you really should buy it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ok first and foremost, im not particualarly a fan of Roguelikes. I love to be able to start from where i left off. I get emotionally attached to my characters and i like being the savior of the universe, with no help from some stinkin friends!!

That said, i love this game. Bought it yesterday and played it,non stop, for about 10 hours afterwards.

The only bug i have had so far is i got shorted on one trip into the dungeons and somehow only 3 characters showed up on a trip to kill one of the bosses or mini bosses. I thought after reading all the comments on the game that id be meat. Turns out  i  must have had a killer 3 party members(one lvl 1 2 lvl 2, unsure of the exact party makeup but def had a vestal for healing 2 of the 3 were def maxed on armor and 2nd lvl spells) I believe the boss was the necromancer. But with stuns, which i expected to fail half of the time, it was a pretty easy beatdown. (one hit would stun first 2 combatants) Im sure it was also combined with the luck i had in finding the boss in one of the fist 5 rooms.

and so far, i am loving the gameplay, style, music, voiceovers and yes even the banter amuses me wholeheartedly.

Sure its rough at the start, but shouldnt all games be? Yes you have to run from battles and possibly give up on quests before your done with them and either retrain or party up your toons to get rid of stress/personality disorders you can accrue, and you WILL accrue A LOT of them if your not careful.

Someone likened it to an adventuerer simulator? Not a bad analogy. You can expand your roster(so far i have a pool of 13, 3 to choose from at any given time, but also can be expanded), build your city up to be able to get rid of personality traits that can cripple you in battles, releive stress after a dungeon crawl and build your abilities.

I reccomend getting all the different classes and having fun with each, as they all have differing enough abilities that they all have SOME use, albeit, not all are as fun to use. (and im sure everyone has a favorite/least favorite class, which is what every game SHOULD have!)

At this point ive only lost" 1 starting character and 1 character from stupidity of not running. Any other than the ones ive re-named for myself have been "let go" by me because of the playstyle or just not wanting to relieve their stress. ;)

Ive found if you have a deep roster of characters you like and some throwaways
date:
you can run dungeons to stock up on cash and prizes while using said cash and prizes to upgrade your "mains".

Do be aware once your mains hit a certain level they will not go back into beginner dungeons. (veteran 3 was when i found out that they refuse to go back into lvl 2 and 1 type dungeons) So if youll probably end up not using your mains when you hit up some of the bosses for the first few levels.

I also realize im just scratching the surface of the game even after 10 hours of romping around dungeons
recommended: sometimes barely making it out alive
hoursPlayed:
and sometimes..well not everyone makes it out.

Do you have to pay attention? HELL YES.  Can it be frustrating? also HELL YES. Is it SUPER HARD? I wouldnt say so.

Its a CHALLENGE

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Great game! I have a lot more hours in cause it won't open inside of Steam. Check troubleshooting" in forum if you're having problems. The difficulty is there ... but not unfair or punishing. Here are some tips:

“Overconfidence is a slow and insidious killer” – Don’t jump levels.
-	Bring enough torches to keep light levels above %75 – Surprise enemies – Use light-based trinkets
-	Keep mental track of which enemies have already attacked
-	Scouting is good – Torch up before room battles.
-	Always pack shovels and enough food to avoid going hungry
-	Type “Darkest Dungeon Curio” into google
-	Name characters after quirks to be removed and locations they are weak and strong in
-	Always correct your character order after battles
-	Experiment with push/pull tactics .. some enemies have nothing in certain positions.
-	Always bring a Vestal – Healing saves lives
-	Develop character’s guild skills so they have positional flexibility – Enemies will scramble you.
-	(not all but) The majority of trinkets are garbage  – Drop them and keep better loot
-	Accuracy is winning – Enemy dodge increases in later levels
-	Criticals are winning - Flip the script on tough battles and reverse stress
-	Dodge is winning - Reduce damage and stress taken
-	Avoid trinkets that lower accuracy
recommended:
and dodge (unless counterbalanced by other trinkets)
-	Unequip core trinkets after battles – Give them to the next team going out.
-	Always scroll over enemies to see their “stun-bleed-blight” susceptibility before attacking
-	Stun is clutch – Stun enemies with the highest speed so their first hit is compromised
-	Prioritize enemies that use stress attacks
-	Kill weak enemies first so they can’t continue attacking
-	Be selective about which quirks to remove
-	Throw young recruits in the fire … if they live … Nice! … If they died … mehhh.
-	Dismiss characters that are stressed out and saddled with negative quirks.
-	A lot of Blight in the Weald – Plague Doctors Battle Medicine helps
-	Bleed skills aren’t great in the Ruins – Too many skeletons
"

-	Scouting is good – Torch up before room battles.
-	Always pack shovels and enough food to avoid going hungry
-	Type “Darkest Dungeon Curio” into google
-	Name characters after quirks to be removed and locations they are weak and strong in
-	Always correct your character order after battles
-	Experiment with push/pull tactics .. some enemies have nothing in certain positions.
-	Always bring a Vestal – Healing saves lives
-	Develop character’s guild skills so they have positional flexibility – Enemies will scramble you.
-	(not all but) The majority of trinkets are garbage  – Drop them and keep better loot
-	Accuracy is winning – Enemy dodge increases in later levels
-	Criticals are winning - Flip the script on tough battles and reverse stress
-	Dodge is winning - Reduce damage and stress taken
-	Avoid trinkets that lower accuracy
recommended:
and dodge (unless counterbalanced by other trinkets)
-	Unequip core trinkets after battles – Give them to the next team going out.
-	Always scroll over enemies to see their “stun-bleed-blight” susceptibility before attacking
-	Stun is clutch – Stun enemies with the highest speed so their first hit is compromised
-	Prioritize enemies that use stress attacks
-	Kill weak enemies first so they can’t continue attacking
-	Be selective about which quirks to remove
-	Throw young recruits in the fire … if they live … Nice! … If they died … mehhh.
-	Dismiss characters that are stressed out and saddled with negative quirks.
-	A lot of Blight in the Weald – Plague Doctors Battle Medicine helps
-	Bleed skills aren’t great in the Ruins – Too many skeletons
"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Probally one of the funnest burst enjoyment I have had in a game for awhile now. I have not played the game heavily as of yet but definitely plan too in the future. This game allows you to actually show sympathy towards your heros, actually caring when your favourite character is on deaths door. Or when they cheer up the whole team with their amazing bard skills. Regardless this game made a brilliant first impression with its amazing looking hand-drawn art style and the narrations is top notch!

The game always keeps you on your feet and requires you to carefully think about your actions instead of mindlessly trying to take on bosses without carefully considering there move set and positioning. From personal experience I can say this game is both unforgiving and so rewarding at the same time. There have few occasions when my characters have died, but theese were to silly mistakes or being too confident and forgetting to bring a bandage.

Overall, this game is outstanding for early acces and cant wait to play when fully released. The combat feels great and works well with the dark atmosphere of the game. But most of the time I have to admit you rely on the RNGesus for quite alot of deaths making some really unique and funny moments. :)

reviewText:
Updated review after launch.

First of all, let's just enjoy and celebrate a company who have actually come through on all of their Kickstarter promises, that does not happen often! Well done Red Hook Studios!

The game is just what they said it would be; it's a game about doing the best you can, in a pissy situation. It's not going to be a perfect journey from start to finish, you will lose some of your most valued adventurers and you will be frustrated and angry. You will consider sacrificing a family member to RNGesus. But, if you're a masochist like me, you will press on... and on... and on.

It's a damn hard game. Some will argue that it's too random, and I can see their point. You will lose some battles because of bad RNG, that's the way it is. You will get some characters who are just better than the others because of RNG. RNG will screw you.

But to me, it's not unfair. It's part of what I signed up for. I personally like the feeling of not being in total control, not being able to predict just what will happen all the time. It's part of the theme of desperation, at least for me. Even though it feels personal, a lot of the times.

The game is absolutely beautiful, it has an atmosphere that few other games have ever matched. You are there, in the deep, dark and dangerous dungeons with your desperate adventurers, trying to stay alive. It's one of the few games where I still have the sound on, listening to the music and the narrator's voice as he tells me that I have once again lost an adventurer to madness...

The game does, however, come with a price, and that price is grinding. The game requires a lot of repetition to get anywhere, there's no denying that. And when the party you have invested the most in dies because of bad RNG or some other mistake, well, then you are punished twice: first by losing the party and then by realizing that you will need to grind your way back up again.

This can, and has, made me lose heart a couple of times.

I've put the game on the shelf, only to pick it up a month or so later.

But I still love it though, and I can't wait what Red Hook Studios are gonna do next!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Can't stop... playing... this game.

One of my first ever experiences delving into a Roguelike game. It was brutal at first, even daunting and futile until you get your ♥♥♥ whipped enough to realize it's not just the game being complex and difficult - it's you failing to learn and pay attention to the finer mechanics involved. From the specific text dialog in interactive prompts that give you a hint, to the varying degrees of provisions, management, and enemies you may encounter. Monsters and bosses scale and change with dungeon progression, as do the workings that govern and inhabit each of these places.

If there is ONE game that has done replayability correctly, it's this one. There are so many variables to take into account at every turn of this game that it's never the same, and there is always something new to experience and learn.

I will say that there is A LOT of management involved if you are going to play this game 'correctly'. Every aspect of this game has things you may CHOOSE to manage and take into account. You can do the basic necissities, but you're going to feel the burn when you took your Plague Doctor with 4 bad quirks related to the dungeon you just entered, and you didn't have enough money for a satisfying quantity of both torches and shovels. Or completely forgetting that you can change  skills while you camp, and abilities when you're out of combat before a crucial fight. There is much to cover if you want to consistently maximize your effectiveness at every stage; alot but never too much. An important and well struck balance in roguelikes.

This game will test your wits, and challenge your attentiveness with: money, hero, and ability managamenet, limited inventory space, hero stress and health, trinkets, virtues and quirks which effect stats positively and negatively respectively. The list goes on and on. The more you play, the more you learn to manage if you want to stay one small step ahead of the challenges in this game.

It's exhilerating. When you do things right and keep up with the learning curve it's a great feeling of triumph and understanding. You take that with you far enough until you foolishly bring two level 1's on a rank 3 dungeon and get your Legend Crusader sent to graveyard because you thought the game got easy all of a sudden.

I could go on about this, but instead you should probably just buy and play this game and save me the time.

Currently this game in my mind stands as 9.5/10 and this is still early access, with 2 major content areas still to be added along with loads more features, and improvements. The art is great, the narrator is awesome and even though you hear him a lot it really never gets old. There are times in the game I swear the developer put in small hidden scripts that respond to certain optional choices you make.

This game is a ravenous evolving beast that wants you dead.

Dismas was the first to die. His boned shattered like so many dreams upon the club of a Pig man.

Next was Raynauld. In his time praying at the Abbey, he had witnessed true horrors, and refused to return. His own mind betrayed him in the bowels of the Weald.

Next up was a Leper that went by the name of DuFrask. Dufrask was everything anyone could want in a leader, save for his nasty habit of cheating while Gambling. He was Sturdy, and a seasoned Weald Explorer. In stressful situations, he would bend like the willow but cut deep like the bramble. He lead multiple fools through the depths of the abyssal caverns beneath the estate, many died, but many rose to glory.

In my hubris, I told DuFrask that he would be taking a regiment of men to face off against the Wizened Hag who'd taken up residence there. Much like the fools who still came to this town thinking they'd find anything but despair and death, I allowed myself a small portion of Hope. I see now that this was a mistake.

DuFrask was accompanied by two other veterans of the caverns; Laci the Jester and Millith, a Vestal, as well as a newer edition to my regiment of explorers, Holland, a Bounty Hunter of few words.

To make a long story short; it was a nightmare.

Millith was killed almost as soon as we'd stepped foot in the dungeon. Like the fool I was, blinded by my own pride in my best warrior, I pushed on, ignoring the warning Millith had given us with her death, We are all doomed!" Without healing

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For the little time that I've spent on this game, there's always a little part of me that was wishing it was playing something else. Something easier. Something less depressing. Something that didn't get my nymphomaniac hero stuck in a brothel for more than two weeks... and didn't even relieve him of all his stress.
Honestly, this game is hard. Dark Souls hard. It wears on your resolve and eats at your patience like cancer. The reason you come back, though, is cause you know it can be beaten. The stress system develops characters' traits in a way I've never seen before, and you start to weave stories in your head about how and why the character ends up with those traits through the sparsely animated combat scenes. On top of the gorgeous artwork and ominous narration, this game provides a lot of atmospheric pleasure and just the right amount of difficult to keep you coming back for more. 8.9/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A good old dungeon-crawling romp through 'Ye Olde Eldritch Nightmareland'. Purge the realm of undead, tentacle monsters, spiders, bloodthirsty brigands, and cultists, or just go insane.

Can be more unforgiving than Hand of Fate. Where that was a game about building up your singular hero in a relaxing, tavern-esque adventuring tale, Darkest Dungeons is more about resisting entropy--knowing to recognize when your group is headed the way of a complete nervous breakdown, while facing a dungeon's monstrosities.

The combat is Turn-based, but with a unique system of class and position management, and a stress system that will utterly destroy the cohesion of your group if you're not wary. This would almost make for a horror game, if it weren't mildly humorous, and tactically-minded. Each of the different class characters will eventually go paranoid, steal from the party, become masochistic pain-freaks (the plague doctors in particular remind me of the TF2 medic, if they take enough physical abuse), or start hallucinating calls to action from their God, that make your entire party come alive in a random, somewhat prefab, but nonetheless characteristic way.

Of particular note, I enjoyed the resting mechanic, which basically lets you pick a good time to rally the party with food and firelight, and offers a number of abilities each class can use to maintain the party's cohesion. For instance, if you're carrying a leper, you can have him considerately confine himself from the rest of the group, at his own expense, to help reduce the team's stress. Or, you could just have him lift his mask and get some physical relief, putting everyone off. The crusader gives pious rants, the barbarian can curse and swear for personal relief at other's expense, the rogue can scout for monsters, the priest can say a prayer for everyone or put up a protective ward around the camp.

Resting almost becomes like its own recovery-based combat round, and the varied options for each class felt fresh and neat. It puts cRPGs to absolute shame, with their rest-spamming cutscene to forget all the party's wear and tear in one instance. (Obsidian and Bioware could take a page from these devs.)

The soundtrack isn't anything unforgettable, but like Monaco, the music conjures elements of tension, fitting your gamestate. Unlike that game's ragtime jingles though, in Darkest Dungeon, when you're on a mission, you get tense metal, percussion, and ambient noise that intensifies the closer your torch comes to sputtering into total darkness. Of especially horrific note, is a sewer/catacombs themed level, filled with emaciated pigmen to put Amnesia to shame. When things go pitch black, the soundtrack fills with the echo of their distant squeals. It's a fantastically chilling touch. Meanwhile, your narrator, in the spirit of Cthuulhu callback games like Eternal Darkness--is a dead ancestor with an ominous voice like an evil Don LaFontaine, egging you on with encouragements, and grimly announcing your stumbles into starvation or  mortal injury.

The game has a nagging issue with difficulty, in a similar sense to X-Com: Enemy Unknown, in that you'll be dealt a starting tutorial prefab that gets you utterly ♥♥♥♥ed the first few times you play. In particular, your starting crusader always has Kleptomania, and will often deprive you of loot you try to scavenge, until you take him to the Sanitarium--a facility that doesn't unlock for you for a few adventures.

Additionally, you do not gain access to a balanced assortment of classes all the time, and there's definitely an ongoing resource-climb that you can fail, if you spend too much on the wrong things. I would compare it to luck rolling underground steam vents and UFOs in the resource-management portion of Enemy Unknown--a bit of a merciless crapshoot that might demand you scum the whole game.

All in all, Darkest Dungeons captures the bleakness of Lovecraftian horror in a fun little procedurally generated, resource-gathering dungeon crawl. The kind that takes breaks in the style of X-Com or Patapon, but reminds you that starvation or defeat is only a few bad moves away, nonetheless. Enjoy it if you like that kind of thing. I did.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Definitely a solid EA purchase.  This game is what I wanted Rogue Legacy to be.  The RNG can be brutal, but if you put lots of your focus into upgrading your town, if you wipe you always have the option of raising up new heroes, now with a bit easier time of it.  For my run, it never felt TOO hard, though things can turn on a dime in battle.

Lots of variety baked in:  each character class has enough skills to let you play them at least 2-3 different ways.  Items which will up one stat while reducing another.  The various advantages and disadvantages can lead to a sort of grooming game with your characters:  which disadvantages are relatively harmless and which ones do you really need to spend time/money to get rid of?  Armor and weapons are a straight upgrade system, and you can upgrade skills as well.  That said, don't get attached to any characters.

Great visuals, great sound effects.  Great game.  Can't wait to see the final product but there's more than enough here to obsessively play it right now.

This game is great.  The atmosphere and narration really do a great job at bringing you into the world. One thing I would like to see is the ability to throw out members that losing their mind. reviewText:
Early Access Review

Fantastic game

-Very difficult and frustrating. You will fail frequently.
-Highly replayable, with varied mission types and enemies
-Lot's of different character classes to experiment with
-A great sense of accomplishment with each survived mission
-Very engaging art and music sets quite a mood

The turn-based combat is a very entertaining balancing act.  Just when you think you've got the enemy on their heels, they throw something new at you.  Getting unlocks is truly rewarding because you have to work hard for them and frequently lose heroes doing so.  Team management requires timing (who rests for how long and where) and attention to resources, as well as a fine awareness of each character's perks and disabilities (which evolve over the course of the game).  The Lovecraftian dungeon exploration theme is wrapped in Mignola-esque, heavily inked art and set to a dark, oppressive soundtrack.  I'm really excited to see where the developers go from here, which is rare for early access.  I can't recommend it enough.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Even though I adore this game on several fronts (the art style is amazing and efficient, the atmosphere at the start is great, the turn-based combat is better than most games of this type (but could be more refined)), i still have to give this game a massive thumbs down summed up in one word: Treadmill.

This game is a massive treadmill, it almost feels like playing a mobile game. Putting your adventurers into the brothel to recover stress is amusing, leveling up that same brothel to level 10 is NOT fun or enjoyable in ANY way. You have to level up EVERYTHING in this game. The town buildings, the skills, weapons and armor of your adventurers. And all of those upgrades are just small improvements of basic numbers. After the initial phase of the game, which is very enjoyable, these treadmill mechanics kick in, and advancing in the game just feels like a hassle.

It saddens me that would these mechanics be stripped out, the game would probably be amazing. The treadmill adds nothing to the gameplay and atmosphere, it undermines these at several fronts. While fighting for the life of your adventures can be tense and fun if you're into this sort of gameplay, losing leveled up characters to RNG is NOT fun. Because this event again demands more farming of you to level up a new character... ugh. No respect for a player's time.

To further illustriate my point, let us compare to another roguelike-like game beloved by me and many - FTL: Faster than Light. In FTL the game is structured in 'runs' which last up to an hour at the most. Each of these runs is unique, and nothing is carried over into the next game (except unlocking new ships). This means that the gameplay is intense and it is all about about achieving things within THIS run. Nothing is there to be farmed. There is no grind.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Not sure where this game is going but it does not feel like an RPG to me. It feels more like an acrade fightin game with a little story. Basicallly do not get attached to any of your characters beasue they will most likely die.

Positives
Art work is awesome.
The narration is  well done

The stress and affliction stuff is genius, more games should pull this mechanic.
Great light mechnaic, it adds a lot to the game

Negatives
The lack of havng one main character really hampers the story. Basically you throw adventurers at dungeons until you are done. Lots and lots of them...
The lack of consistency in monsters and dungeons is extreme. It is a crap shoot every time.
The lack of a persistant inventory is annoying, not sure what they were going for but all the stuff you buy magially disappears after a dungeon run.
The rehab is crazy costly, it seems that they were trying to balane out the large amounts of money I think.

All is all it is more of a dungeon fighting arcade game them an RPG. If you want one of those here is a good one....as for RPG not so much.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI see a lot of people comparing this to Dark Souls, but in truth the only thing the two have in comon is their difficulty. Though this game isn't exactly difficult, unfair would be a better word. When you die in Dark Souls it's entirely your fault, but when you die in Darkest Dungeon chances are pretty good that there's nothing you could have done. I like the concept, I like the premise, I love the art, I like a lot of the gameplay, but I really can't reconcile with how heavily RNG factors in. I've lost characters because they refused to be healed while they were on death's door. That's a special kind of unfairness that you have to be actively searching for in a game to find enjoyable. It's a niche game for a niche audience made up of a combination of masochists and people with unfaltering resolve. It's not a bad game by any means and I've had some great fun with it, but it just doesn't appeal to me. But if you're the kind of person who finds enjoyment in having the odds stacked completely and totally against you then by all means go ahead. If nothing else this game mirrors its story perfectly, I can't play it for more than a few hours without going completely ♥♥♥♥ing mad.

reviewText:
This game had so much potential.  Interesting dynamics and a game that finally presented a real challenge.

Unfortunately, the game mechanics in this game are just stupid.  Death is permanent, and your heroes can die from a couple of really unlucky rolls, without you being able to do anything about it.  It takes hours to train a hero up just a few levels.

This is easily the most frustrating game I've ever played, and I'm normally someone who loves difficult games.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I absolutely cannot recommend this game to anyone. A videogame is meant to be enjoyable and fun, but apparently nobody at Red Hook Studios was informed of ths. Every design decision seems to have been purposefully made to irritate, annoy and take the fun out of playing it. There is absolutely no enjoyment whatsoever to be had in this game, and this comes down to every element of the game being either mostly or entirely outside of your control.  Almost everything in this game is arbitrary. Random dice rolls are quite clearly rigged to favour good results for the enemy and bad results for you, and systems that supposedly work on fixed numbers cheat to produce unfavourable outcomes seemingly on a whim.

The money spent to keep party members alive and sane outside of missions is inexpicably subtracted from the same pool from which you need to purchase supplies to keep them alive and sane during missions, and money, supplies and upgrade resources are never numerous enough to allow you to make any real progress except by sheer, blind luck (and don't expect that to ever come at a time when it might genuinely help you). Stress accumulates extremely quickly and can instantly kill your heroes even if you keep their health topped up. Enemy dodge rolls seem insanely slanted as compared to how often your own characters are able to do it. The items required to cure damage-over-time effects are insanely expensive compared to the average income of a mission and the maintenance costs of your characters.

The game also crashes randomly with little explanation.

Every single one of these issues confront you within the first twenty minutes of the game. You will not complete this game. You will not enjoy a single moment of playing it. Spend your money somewher else. If you have under 120 minutes of play, demand the refund that Steam promises you. This game does not deserve your custom.

reviewText: It was enjoyable in the beginning but the game has become too difficult to enjoy. With some games, the added difficulty makes the overall experience more enjoyable and makes victory feel rewarding. This game however, is difficult just to be difficult. It doesn't matter how well you prepare, your team could get wiped out in battles you should have won handidly because the enemy managed to crit your healer three times in a row. Speaking of RNG, the RNG in this game is bull****. Attacks that have a 100% accuracy rating miss fairly frequently, it's like the actual accuracy rating is 30% less than what they tell you it is. I know this happens a lot with other games that have RNG (Hello X-COM) but no other game has infuriated me quite like Darkest Dungeon has. The purpose of video games is to bring enjoyment or satisfaction to the player, not bring up repressed anger management issues.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Darkest Dungeon is a treat. The game itself is great, but the developers are rockstars. Frequent updates, problems quickly addressed, community input is considered but doesn't stop them realizing their vision. So what is that vision?

Darkest Dungeon is a game about stress, glory, and adventure. Your goal is to reclaim this manor from the horrors discovered below it. And you will do so with pure management, dungeon diving, and perhaps a few trips to the brothel, pub, church, and asylum. You will care about your adventurers, because only so many will consistently gain good traits. You will care more becasue any worth keeping will need care to have bad traits removed and stress reduced. You will still care about losing bad adventurers because you need every one in a run to have a shot at getting the loot at the end.

The game is RNG heavy, and it gets some bad press for it, but don't listen to the whiners, just do your research beforehand to see if it is for you. Any game with rogue-like or rogue-lite elements has RNG elements, and any game with RNG elements is about overcoming adversity. Just keep in mind this isn't a linear game with a carved out path and progression curve. This is a game that will try to kill you(r adventurers,) and you will try to conquer it. Sometimes this can result in a bit of tedium or grind, so don't be afraid to mix up your playstyle.

The enemies are varied and fun to deal with. Some are very stressful as they are currently, but again, that's a PART of the fun of a game like this. You will still see the same mobs a lot, but it's like meeting an old friend, the fun sticks because of having to deal with them in different combinations and formations. Also, you can be surprised and have your party shuffled about, and they could be surprised and you get a free turn. So this game likes to encourage mixing things up, experimenting, and at its core, is very much a management game, but still seamlessly blends in dungeon crawling, and rather beautifully at that.

The art style is refreshing and fun, for me. I love the aesthetic, and between it and the sounds, it sets the tone well. It's not lavish, it's not hyper-detailed, and it isn't supposed to be. It's supposed to be vague and dark. One thing I can say though, is if the screenshots don't impress you, there's a chance the art will still work its magic on you while playing. The little bit of motion, the way everything ties together, and the feelings associated with trudging through the dungeons personally can add a lot of impact.

This game has depth, accessibility, polish, great devs, good art, and great sound. It's a wonderful offering, even with a few shortcomings or the stress of RNG, and I wouldn't be surprised if the devs address that, too.

The best part is, while what's there is so well put together, there's still more to come!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI feel it calling to me as I write this.  Once, I was as you are now.  Pondering the purchase of this game.  I saw the screenshots.  I read the reviews.  I thought I knew what I was getting myself into.  This hubris would be my undoing.  I believed myself above the other gamers who had gone before me, that this game had chewed and spat out raving mad.  Seconds become minutes becomes hours become days.  Still this game won't let me be.  One more mission.  One more attempt to carve order out of chaos.  It is always one more something.  I wish I could warn you away.  If you could see my bloodshot eyes, my pale countenance...maybe that would be enough to convince you to pass this game by.  But hah, you have my same arrogance, don't you?  You believe that you can conquer this game that has conquered me.  You've been warned.  Always remember that you were given that, at least.  When you've been driven to my neighborhood of crazy, I will be glad to give you the tour.  We are always looking new faces here...

reviewText: While gameplay seems to be appealing from the beginning, the scaling to the later stages of the game is poorly designed. I'd even say it is simply abysmal: every lvl5+ battle turns into RNG fiesta with little to no ability to mitigate or prevent randomness on a side of the player. For example, a group of ~6 SPD monsters all went before any of my 7+ SPD party and killed my lvl6 position 3 hero. Just like that. I was unlucky. But the main problem is that the every high level unfortunate event" of that type has the only consequence - more boring repetitive grind in leveling up another hero from 1 to 6. If you're in highschool maybe you have the insane amount of time you need to progress reasonably fast in this game, but i'd rather not get stressed out about losing 4 chars i spent several hours building in one turn of a fight.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A unique dungeon crawl experience with exceptional atmosphere and brutal, roguelike mechanics to ensure that every encounter is dangerous and meaningful.  The stress mechanics alone are enough to make the game stand out from its predecessors, but the game goes a step further with interesting line combat mechanics and customization options which serve to distinguish the game from any others like it.  The game drips with atmosphere from the outstanding artwork to the enriching, if at times sesquipedalian, narration.

I feel the game stands out for its emphasis on resourcefulness.  Due to the randomness of recruitment, character trait assignment and dungeon generation, it's extraordinarily rare to put together an optimal party for all situations.  There are times where your primary healer will be nursing her paranoia in a tavern, or you'll design a team to defeat a boss only to have it ripped apart by an unfortunate monster spawn.  Each class has 8 active abilities and 6 camping abilities, of which you can only take 4 and 3 with you respectively.  As a result, you often find yourself assembling teams and kits which aren't great for any situation, but are good enough for every situation, and therein lies the beauty as you tend to scrape by tough encounters more often than dominate them, making those encounters memorable and engaging.

My critique in its current form are tied with the volume of information you must keep track of.  Each character in your group may possess as many as 10 traits, both positive and negative (and might have some diseases on top of that) which can have various impacts on their abilities.  These traits will also change over time after each successful dungeon run.  Add onto that having to manage equipment, skill and camping skill layouts for numerous party members and it can be a bit daunting to remember what role each character plays in your group and which dungeons they would best serve in.  Consequently, at least for me, most of this information ends up being ignored.

There is some commotion over the new mechanics introduced by Red Hook, but I personally feel the game has continuously improved over the course of its time since its beta release.  To cover some of the more recent changes, corpses present another opportunity cost question to your party (should I scrap a more general purpose ability for one that's not as useful, but clears corpses) while heart attacks further test your risk/reward assessment abilities.  Increased PROT for monsters adds value to blight/bleed effects, which themselves require planning around as enemies might be more resistant to one or the other.  I do not endorse early access games by in large, but I will endorse this game.  If you are looking for a dark, unforgiving game that tests your resourcefulness and willingness to take dangerous risks for the promise of substancial rewards, purchase this game immediately.  For $19.99, you are getting an exceptional bargain for the entertainment you'll get with this title.

As a bonus, the game's narrator will also likely improve your vocabulary.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Alrighty, adding my opinion to the many already here!

DD does a great job of taking a classic set-up and giving it a good spin! You and your characters travel through an atmospheric world that perfectly captures the feeling of despondence felt by the towns folk and your long suffering party members. The upgrade system in the game is scaled very well and the enemies are also well suited to keep you and your characters in check as you go up in level. Balancing stress and health, especially when camping, is an important part of the game and really gets you invested as some enemies attack physically and others make your characters really feel the psychological strain of the quest. The enemy types are also quite varied so each new attack feels interesting as you plunge through the depressing landscapes.

On the other end of the spectrum it is sometimes hard to keep track of your characters. There were several times in the game where I tossed high stress individuals into my party because I didn't notice they were already at 100 but I do blame that more on my own inattention than the game itself. I also find myself getting angry at the characters when they fail a saving throw, again, it's an important part of the game and it does really well in making you think about human nature and all but the 3rd time your Hound Master becomes Selfish and steals 2500 worth of loot you're going to wish you could order your highwayman to shoot him. There are also a few bugs for me but it is in early access so I'm not worried, they go away when I restart the game(which takes about 1.5 minutes).

All in all I thought it was a great game! Sorry for my disjointed ramble, hope it helps you decide if you want to buy the game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

7/10 Fantastic for what it is trying to do
This game is fantastic and terrible all at the same time. I adore turn based rpgs like this one and darkest dungeon does everything right when it comes to the cobat and the insanity system. The attacks and the limited position for attacks and hits give this game a great deal of stratagy. The hamlet is another strong point in the game the variety of skills and upgrades that can be unlocked, and the sanitarium, tavern, and chaple give a indepth feel to the game and the insanity system. You can choose what type of attacks and abilites that you want your team of four to have and customize them to fit together. However there are a few misteps that have to be disscused. The leveling system is frustragting at best  but more often it is a detrement to the game. It is not frustrating because the game is hard or that you will often lose characters, this is part of the fun and challange of the game. The problem is that at level 3 and level 5 your character will be locked of from doing other low level quests. My evample of this was i was training my team to be able to fight the Necromancers apprentice  boss, after finishing the last dungeon my crusader and bounty hunter leveled up to level 3 and thus refused to fight the boss. It does not seem fair that the game wants you to become good with your stratagy to keep people alive and sain but then they will take them away. Clearly this was to keep grinding with a good team to a minimum but since the rewards for the quest are quite small and the levels only unlock more expencive upgrades it seems like this is a mistep. This is one of the only major problems for a game that is still only in early access which is quite a possitive statment given how poor more early access games are. It is hard for me to rate this game  I personaly would give this game a 9 out of 10 but i think that a more realistic score would be 7 out of ten. If you like rpgs you will love this game, if you like a challange you will love this game, if you like stagigic planning for battles you will love this game. if not you will find the game a frustrating grind that then punishes you for succeding. All and all i would highly recomend this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game will probably be fun for you for the first 40 or so hours, but after that, it just gets very repetitive.

Effective strategies that clever players devise for success are ultimately nerfed in the patches.  To me, the pleasure of a game is figuring out strategies to overcome challenging situations, rather than relying on luck from a random number generator.

Even with the nerfs to your characters and the power boosts to the enemies, the game is still manageable and is not nearly as difficult as you might be lead to believe based on the reviews of other gamers on here.

However, the game gets boring because of the lack of customization for the characters.  There aren't any special armors or weapons to find.  You simply have generic upgrades, so when going on your quests/missions, there isn't really anything too exciting that you will ever find.  It just the the same old gold, and items that help you unlock generic upgrades.  There are trinkets
date:
but these are nothing to write home about, and are also generic.  You will get multiple copies of the same useless trinkets.

The bosses can be cool, but it seems like the developers got lazy.  Rather than making new bosses, they just re-used the old bosses, but made them tougher.  So you have to fight necromancer level 1, level 2, and level 3.  This just adds to the lack of excitement.

I guess I get a certain level of satisfaction successfully going through this game while having only minimal causalties when I read how so many others are frustrated and can't seem to figure how to achieve consistent success.  However, this minor joy is not enough to keep me coming back for more.

In summary, the game a lot more content (far more than it will ever have) in order for this game to be noteworthy.  Will you enjoy the game for the first 40 hours or so?  Probably.  Then you will realize that you are tired of going through the same process over and over again without any hope of a unique reward.  I am hopeful that someone out there will create a mod which makes the game a lot better.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was recluctant to buy this game at first, swayed by some negative reviews on Steam.
I'm glad I decided to buy it anyway, because not only the game is amazing, but the most controversial features that enraged many players can now be toggled off.

The gameplay is smooth, the Lovecraftian art style is fascinating and the challenge keeps you engaged and anxious.
There are no save points, but a constant autosaving, therefore any choice, any event and especially any death (including your favorite party's or character's) is permanent!

In the end, this is a fantastic and unforgiving game at the same time, with a dark, thrilling and captivating atmosphere.
The narrator is a big plus!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI don't write many reviews but I really feel I need to warn people off this game. Look, I like a challenge as much as the next gamer but this game is just ridiculous. Here is the first thing. You actually might lose one of your starting characters in the tutorial. Let that sink in. You can lose a character in the tutorial (which, by the way, you cannot skip). I’ve never played a game so unbalanced. As you read further review or look in the forums, you’ll see many saying “These people are whiners, it’s not that hard.” I don’t know what game these people are talking about but it’s not this one. After several attempts at playing, it’s mostly an exercise in frustration. Your enemies will rarely miss you but you’ll miss them often. They will get several critical hits, you’ll get very few. The vast majority of “treasure” you find will be trapped and your party will only get wounded and stressed with nothing to show for it. When your characters become stressed to the breaking point (this will happen often) they’ll come down with some sort of affliction. This will slow the game quite a bit because every turn the afflicted characters must say something about it. I could go into a lot more but I just wanted to shoot this review off before I uninstall the game. This might be a good game sometime in the future but I regret having bought it at this point.

reviewText:
Darkest Dungeon is the best real life simulation I've seen in gaming!
Everything constantly goes not as planned, the odds are oftimes against you, your team often has to run without completing the quest, even when the goal is nearly reached; game punishes you for being rash and greedy...
I understand that the devs' goal was to deconstruct dungeon crawling RPGs with unbreakable fearless heroes who constantly walking from one hell to another without even breaking a sweat. Well done on that! Game absolutely destroys many a videogame cliche.
It's one of the most depressing games I've played, in a good sense! I feel very very bad for my heroes and their constant sad talk is not making things any easier.
And I get infinetely butthurt by the whining of some players 'meehh, my heroes are always stressed', 'meeh, game is too RNG'. Son, your life is RNG as hell. And trying to accomplish something is stressful. Especially in the ♥♥♥♥ing Lovecraftian hell with living skeleton jelly and human-pig hybrids. Deal with it. Or go back to your games about mighty heroes who kill armies singlehandedly. This is not a game for you. This is not 'Press X to win' title.
This is more than a game. This is a whole new look at dungeon crawling genre. Definetely recommend, even Early Access. The game has some flaws, but overall awesomeness negates that.
10/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I do not recomend this game mostly because its not much of a game, you dont really manage your heros that much, every building has a very linear upgrade system, actually everuthing is very very linear, and the battles are just super boring, the vast majority of battles consist of you wait and watching the enemy attacking you, again and again, and then you can use 1 or 2 of your party members before the enemy party gets another full cycle, and you have no input during their attacks, no precise quick times to either maybe give slightly reduced dmg or possible dodges. No you just wait and wait watching the enemy attack while your party members freak out and skip their turns because they dont like scurry monsters. I would think a Crusading Knight or a Murderous Highwayman wouldnt be affraid of little slug things or skeltons.

How ever beautful and interesting it is i just dont find it a fun game. Its more like a sim of watching fail adventurers suck at DnD.

UPDATE- Spent over 3 more hours, had lots of fun building a strong team of a healer, 2 gunmen and a crusader, fought through 3-4 dungeons using good tactics and won each battle, had a few close calls but i was ok, made it to the first boss and it ruined the game.

The Wizened Hag, first turn she put my knight into a boiling pot instantly, the pot damages the hero inside every turn, not round, after each unit move, and she gets a turn after every pot breaks and after each of your turns, she spams area attacks that never miss, and 9/10 my attacks missed, also causes over 20-30 stress per attack, when a hero is not in the pot it is indestrucible and makes melee attacks vs her blocked.

She killed one of my guys after haver 4 attacks in a row against me, i quit the fight finally after 3 failed attempts and i quit the game period, until they nerf the AI in many ways and make the fighting fair i cannot recommend this game, it is annoying, unfair, and overall very boring once you get spammed by enemies.

Update: Nothing much has changed in the last week, still gameplay that is completely random and unfair, you still spend 80% of the game watching the enemy attack you and spam area attacks, still needs loads of balance work and refinement of the gameplay.

Add- 8/15/2015
New updates, same errors, just fought the wizened hag again, fight went well got her down to 20 health out of 66 with 2 highway men, 1 arbelest and 1 hellion when she dumped the hellion out of the pot at deathsdoor then istantly put 1 highwayman into the pot THEN Seasoned the hellion and instantly killed her,  then spew the highwayman out to deaths door, then took the other highwayman into the pot, THEN i got to attack, but none of the 2 could hit her, expect the highwaymans tracking shot for 3 dmg, then she AoE attacked and killed those 2 and i lost just like that.

In summary the game has such amazing art, sound and setting but it suffers from boring and repetitive fighting, horrible RNG , unfair inbalances, and tedious and time wasting animations and dialauges that interupt the flow of the game and literally prevent player actions. I do not recomend this game to anyone until it gets a major gameplay overhaul.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Since my unpolished rushed review was actually getting some attention i've decided to go and write a proper review this game deserves so those who did'nt find it useful can maybe change their mind a bit n so enough of that off to the review:
The game is from my expiriences one of the best dungeon crawling rogue likes i've played in quite sometime. This game in my short time I had with it had me wanting to come back for more. The game is quite creative with it's combat system in the way that after so many times your party comes close to death their mind is tested in which their mind will either snap or they will be heroic and reward your roster with buffs; or if their mind snaps it will cause some debuff to that character such as paranoia or selfishness. That system alone had this game sticking as unique in my mind. As for the rest i'm just going to do a quick Pros/Cons list.
Pros:
1-Creative Combat System
2-Unique Art Style
3-Great Environments and Ambience
4-Good Voice acting
5-Creative foes and Quests.
6-Great Balance Combat and Exploration.
7-Adds in Realistic Hunger elements to the Chaos
Cons:
1- Game is buggy and tends to crash but fixes can be found, i personally had a glitch where it'd freeze at the hamlet screen n i'd have to wait for it to load and not respond then begin responding.
2- hard for players new to rpgs or dont have previous expirience
3- some deciscions you make due to the Randomness screw you over in ways you cant manage no matter what ^.^
Verdict:
9/10 - Amazing game but due to the bugs I had to lower it a notch however for an Early Access game it is superbly done and I would recommend this game to any of my friends. This is a great game and deserves the support.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nFrom the journal of Dismas the Highwayman, week 11: Into the mouth of madness we march. Our food rations and torches are running low. The gurgling of our stomachs is only offset by the oppressive darkness surrounding us. Every step is another step towards either  death or hard fought victory. The Crusader has become abusive towards the rest of us and the Vestal has started stealing from the loot piles. The Crusader is beginning to wear on my patience and puts all of us on edge with his incessant insults and ridiculing.  I fear will we not even reach the wisened Hag at this rate. The Bounty Hunter has managed to keep his wits about him so far
date: though. We trudge from room to room battling all foes that appear in front of us. I have been poisoned by those damnable spitting spiders and we have no antivenom left. I manage to overcome the poison's effects by the time we reach the entrance to the Hag's room. We enter the room and the Hag immediately throws the Crusader in her stewpot. She then proceeds to bludgeon me with a meat tenderizer. I contemplate letting the Crusader die
recommended: but he is too valuable against tough and unholy foes.The hag throws frogs and eyeballs at the Vestal and calls it "seasoning the food". The Vestal is terribly unhappy about being pummeled by eyballs and dead frogs and finally cracks. She sobs
hoursPlayed: calling out to her god
voteText: begging him to save her from death. The Bounty Hunter marks the hag for death while I take aim and shoot her in the face. The Vestal tries to knock the stew pot over to save the Crusader and is eventually successful. The Crusader suffers some burns from the boiling stew but is otherwise intact. The Hag keeps bludgeoning us with that bloody tenderizing hammer. The Vestal is barely surviving and only because the Crusader keeps healing her. The Bounty hunter hacks at her with his axe dealing critical damage. I blast the hag in the face once more and the Crusader charges forward ramming his blade into her bloated body. She screams her death knell and we are showered in blood and riches. We make our way back to town laden with treasure and horror-filled minds.We were lucky to survive those infernal ruins. I spend the next week drinking to decompress while the Crusader buys hookers and the Vestal prays in the cathedral. The Bounty Hunter gets banned from both the brothel (for having...curious tastes) and the bar so we let him gamble to blow off steam. After the Vestal finishes her praying we send her to the sanitarium to be cured of her kleptomania. It's quite hard to steal loot when you're strapped to a bed

reviewText:
I'm not gonna deny, I am a massive fan of this game. Come to think of it, it would certainly be in my top 15 games of all time. But, before I sing this game any praises, I want to share my thoughts on some criticisms people bring up when talking about Darkest Dungeon and how I feel about gameplay in general. This is going to be a long one, but I just feel the need to talk about this in detail.

Many people like to compare Darkest Dungeon to Dark Souls. And I think it is fair to a degree - both games have dark, brooding aesthetics and pose a significant challenge to the player, while having a steep learning curve. But I don't think the core principles of these games are alike. In Dark Souls, the player is in control all the time, the game will not offer you help, nor will it deliberately undermine your progress and make your life harder. There are no unknown variables either, as soon as you are comfortable with your character and know all the patterns, that's it, you will never lose if your mechanical execution is perfect.

It is not the case with Darkest Dungeon however. There is only so much you can do to succeed, but it is not entirely up to you. This is why a major component of the game is risk management. Since you can't outskill your enemies with perfect tactics when your party is at the brink of death, sometimes you just have to cut your losses and escape. This is a big part of getting good at Darkest Dungeon, learning when you should and, more importantly, shouldn't press on. To be fair, if you get good at this game, you will succeed at the overwhelming majority of your quests, but sometimes the game will destroy you. This is why I think an apt comparison would be online poker (an important distinction, because in ordinary poker there is a whole another level of mind games). You have to play smart and hedge your bets, if the odds are not in your favour, it isn't worth committing in many cases. Of course, there are times, when you have full house, but the game has straight flush. The thing about Darkest Dungeon however, it lets you stack the deck" in your favor by effectively utilizing party combinations
recommended: and using tactics to your advantage.\n\nWhy am I telling you this and why is it important? I feel like a lot of people go into game with false expectations
hoursPlayed: feeling that it's gonna be a Dark Souls experience to the letter and end up being disappointed or thinking they were misled. Which is often followed by criticizing the game for not being what it never supposed to be. The game does well what it was created to do and it never pretended it is something more than it is. So before you post an angry review

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Obviously this game has some flaws. And it's nowhere near done yet.
That being said, what is out so far is amazing and unique. It's remniscent of old fashioned D&D, with a ton of horror thrown into the mix. This is my go to game whenever my net is down. I've actually got closer to 100 hours on this baby. Granted, I still suck at it. But the most fun I have is getting attatched to my characters, naming them, and then focusing my entire experience around keeping them alive. Believe me, it's a thrilling experience. The difficulty of this game is way up there with Dark Souls, but it's rougelike and if your people die they die for good, so in my opinion it's even harder. I doubt many people who weren't at one time old school gamers like me will be able to get far in this game. It requires tons of strategy, tactics, gambling on outcomes, and judgement calls.

Truly a unique experience and I can't wait for more content to be added!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I wish I could recommend this game. The core concept is solid and the story and atomosphere is great. But the implementation is deeply flawed.

The developers clearly wanted to create a challenging game but their idea of challenging" was simply to add a bunch of random bad things that can happen. These things can't be planned for or mitigated and occur with incredible frequency.

Combat itself is actually pretty good and is another reason I wish I could recommend it. But here again the strategy of the game is short circuited by the extremely random nature of things.

To sum up where this game went wrong they confused randomness with challenging and tainted a decent core system."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The problem with this game is that it relies too heavily on the RNG, and especially with the permadeath/stress mechanics you get in these wacky positive feedback loops where every character feels like skipping their turn because reasons and the whole party wipes through no fault of the PLAYER.

If you are going to make a game like this, there needs to be certainty that the player is punished for his/her mistakes alone, and not random chance. Also, the balance is godawful.

I really wanted to like this game, and certainly the core is there. The art style is pretty rad, music is nice. But it simply doesn't play well at this moment.

on edit: After playing a bit longer, I wish I could change to double downvote. Characters refusing heals from party members, damaging themselves because they are too stressed"... ugh"
