reviewText:
Heavily RNG based game.  It's not a roguelike and it's more frustrating than fun.  There is very little editability to heroes, you can upgrade their abilities but all this does is lower the RNG essentially--they hit more frequently and do more damage or heal more/apply an effect more often.  Because of this, there is a massive illusion of customizibility but it's guised in the idea that a level 0 hero is different than a level 1 hero.

The really not fun part about this game is that skillful play is not rewarded and the signal to the player that what they're doing is effective or not is clouded by a serious roll of the dice in every fight.  Every fight you risk 1 member in your party screwing over everyone else, in every fight if the AI all decide to screw over 1 key person they die.

And that's the real problem--anytime someone dies you're punished for it.  It costs around 5-6 missions in gold rewards just to fully upgrade / unlock the key things you want a hero to have.  So 1 small error, possibly one you have absolutely no idea exists yet, is punished to the maximum.  I find this incredibly poor game design.  The game would be signfiicantly more fun if characters were injured.

Even more troubling is that killing hours of your time in a hero, how about those trinkets you equip that are vital as you move onward through the game?  Well if you get wiped or have to run from combat--you lose everything that was dropped as people die or you simply don't have inventory space to hold.

I really want to like this game, but I'm a stickler for good game design.  I am a huge fan of zangband/angband and actual roguelike titles.  It irritates me when developers slap the 'roguelike' title on firstly a game that is not actually a roguelike and then use permadeath as a means to feign difficulty when the difficulty is that all of the game's mechanics remove skill and your only real strategy is to move the goalposts of high/low RNG far enough away from people dying so you can progress--but there's always a chance of just losing everything.  It's bad design and shouldn't be given the acclaim it is getting.

I greatly enjoy massively difficult games--xcom is a difficult game (both the new and old), you can wipe and lose in a fight but there is a wide variety of what skillful play can achieve over non-skillful play and that is what Darkest Dungeon massively lacks.  Grinding back for hours to retry the dungeon boss that has a mechanic you simply must bring certain protection/strategy/units for...that's just idiotic, manufactured difficulty.

If you play this game I highly recommend save scumming--if you could restart your hour long dungeon that ends in failure, I'd take away my negative review.  I really like the idea of permadeath though, just the execution of it is flawed.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Another game that would be great, but they forget you are relaxing and want to have some fun.

Difficulty is not created through random destruction and tilted odds. You can't apply skill, practice, or even time; to simply randomly losing hours of work.

The game has many ways in which it randomly screws you, I think it is supposed to be difficulty. However, on a regular basis they combine to simply mean 'instant game over'.  Why is there an escape button if it never lets you? And if you can't escape, why not at least turn the button off? There is no way to tell the difficulty of a level besides, do you get to camp". I loved camping and failing every single players skill attempt at healing. Every time I camped.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI started playing Darkest Dungeon about a month ago, soon after the Houndmaster update.  The gameplay and narration are excellent and I think the graphics/battle animations are superb, as well.  The storyline reminds me of H.P. Lovecraft's The Rats In The Walls" and that's a great thing!  Kudos to Red Hook on capturing the same dark
date: dreary feel.\n\nI found the game to be very difficult early on because I was trying to save all of the party members after each mission and didn't have enough gold to fix all of their problems.  Once I accepted that the level 0-1 characters were simply cannon fodder to use for the greater good of the Hamlet (sending out on no provision runs to gather gold/resources and then dismissing the entire party afterwards)
recommended: the game became easier.  Using the gold to fund real mission and item/ability upgrades for my main characters
hoursPlayed: I slowly built up my roster and continued doing no provision runs when my core teams required rest.\n\nNow
voteText: I have a full roster of upgraded (though not max level) characters.  The days of no provision runs with new recruits is over but they served their purpose.  My "A-Team" (Grave Robber/Vestal/Crusader/Man-at-Arms) is level 5 and has completed several Champion runs; the remaining heroes are level 3-4 and are capable of completing the Veteran runs in various party combinations.\n\nIn my opinion
helpfulPercent: the best classes are the Man-at-Arms and the Vestal; I haven't had any success with the Occultist or the Plague Doctor.  It seems like the Occultist's heal fails at a critical time and isn't worth the risk
votesHelpful: the Vestal has proven to be a more reliable healer.  The Plague Doctor hasn't been a strong enough healer or damage dealer in my expeience; I'd take the Vestal/Crusader for healing or just about anything else (Arbalest/Bountry Hunter/Grave Robber/Highway Man) for damage dealing
votesTotal: over the Plague Doctor.\n\nWould I recommend this game to others?  Absolutely!  For only $20 (about the same price as a movie or two at the theater)
votesFunny: I've had over 70 hours of enjoyment and I am looking forward to the next 70+ hours of gameplay."

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI realize this is early access, but I would not recommend this game at this time.  There is a fun game in there; the concepts are brilliant but the frustration is huge.  The spread in outcomes of the various RNG rolls results in unavoidable failure spirals where things will be going along brilliantly and then suddenly all of your heros are fully stressed, you are out of money, and no easy quests are available to attempt a recovery.  The overall balance seems extremely poor; some dungeons you will receive 50% the number of enemies, and they will all be of an easy type and other dugeons will have twice as many enemies and each fight will decimate your party.  Add in the unavoidable RNG (you can be unlucky with what hero types are available, giving you an unfeasable party configuration leading to certain failure) and this game is just not worth the price of admission.  I hope they refine it, because I feel like this could be a really good game.  One last thing; many people are saying the root problem is that you have to learn the game.  Some of my favorite games are the Souls games which are difficult, but once your endure and learn the mechanics you become powerful.  This is not that scenario; the Souls games are tough but fair.  This game's reliance on RNG outcomes yields and experience which just is not fair.

reviewText:
Everything is great about the game except the RNG based difficulty. Minor enemies can devastate your party, you can die, lose everything and would have done nothing wrong except being unlucky.
The gameplay gets repetitive AND stressful and unrewarding at the same time.

I feel as if the Stress and Crit system were reworked and the items better balanced to have less of a negative impact the gameplay would be a lot less punishing and enjoyable.

My favorite hero was the Abomination and he's essentially unusable unless I bring a specific party, but, guess what? 3 Heroes refuse to group with him. Why did you even bring that character into the game?
voteText: 15 of 28 people (54%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Its disappointing that after re-visiting this game after so long it has only been patched and updated with more non-sensical and RNG based punishments for players. The classes are still largely unbalanced, even more time and money is now required to purge the endless stream of new diseases and debuffs, and trinkets are either net positive or net negative making only a select few worth anything. Near constant attacks to your moral and severe and often permanent punishments for looting anything in the level put me off experimenting in the game extremely quickely, including trying the new classes. The investment of time to train new units up from 0-2 is boring and unrewarding, and it's often easier to simply dismiss new units and recruit fresh untainted ones. To succeed I had to run the same team, use the same ability combinations and ignore as many RNG based elements as possible to avoid a majority of the games 'difficulty'. Even for a roguelike Darket Dungeon likes taking control away from the player way too often.

I'd hoped more skill and squad composition mechanics would be explored as the game progressed, maybe even some relief from the frustrating requirment of destressing and purging abilities after almost every single run. While I understand this title is invested in being as crushingly hard as possible, many of the mechanics come across as merely stalling for time and forcing players to repeat low level areas.

reviewText:
Any time I wish to feel ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off, angry, or at least just generally dissatisfied all I have to do is play this game. If you slip up just once you pay for it dearly.

If you're like me and even slightly human and make mistakes once in a while you shouldn't buy this game. Example of a critical mistake? I forgot to buy *food*(!) and torches, not doing a dark run, and combined with the expenses of what I bought dropped me down to less than 5k gold. I could've re-equipped and gone on another run but a mistake this early into the campaign is too hard to recover from in my opinion. Experience from other campaign attempts has taught me that it's just a downward spiral.

Seriously, why does this game allow you to go in without food? I would understand if you didn't have gold but if you're out of gold and can't afford food then you should, unless it's the last quest, probably throw in the towel. The programmers could easily add in a confirmation check at least for food if not torches.

I'm terrible. I'm stupid. I get that but I can't be bothered with playing this game as I have more important and rewarding things to do in my life. I'm just not enough of a masochist.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Darkest dungeoon is

- Ironman mode without healing potions
- Drawn out battles where u spend or waste alot of time using skills to heal your party members instead of getting on with the game
- A game where u invest hours on your main heros, and CAN see them die because of no saves and no healing potions. if you are really not sure of winning, its better to fail the quest or try running away in combat, which can fail to run away, in which case all your hours of investment is going to be wasted

Suggestion
- whats the point of having items if the items have much more negative effect then positive.

-when heros go crazy and mutter crazy stuff, let the gameplay continue. instead of pausing the game/combat for every single crazy speech bubble. i got a party of 4 crazies and gameplay is just 1 big pause.

This game does have 1 fatal flaw
- Too little variety in skills. heros become boring. monsters become boring. after playing for afew hours i could not bring myself to continue anymore. pls learn from other successful RPGs and how they allow players to spend dayyyys just working to make their hero stronger

having 5 fixed levels per skill, increasing attack and crit chance by 1% each level,  is called seriously boring. at the very least you need to add new abilities that might trigger when using the skill, and this must be done early on, otherwise players will be toooo bored to play on !


There are good things going on for this game, and the basic gameplay has also been built up nicely from the starting zero to the present fully fledged game. however there has been too little focus on the heros.

also if the player is really supposed to throw away his heros, then pls make it so that all dungeons are the same level and all heros cannot level up. did u really expect players to spend hours investing in a group of heros....only to throw away those heros ... and to repeat this process ??

reviewText:
Early Access Review

There's a few things you don't do in game design. A pretty important one is that you shouldn't take the players' hours of work and investment and then roll the dice to see if he or she keeps it.

In this game I designed a fun, powerful composition and was having a lot of success with it. It took me somewhere around 10 hours to feel confident and prepared, and the team was blazing through dungeons. Seeing my team was now far over-levelled and overgeared I decided it was time to take on the second boss. I entered, went through the dungeon unscathed and finally reached the boss. Then he immediately hit my entire team with a massive critical hit, permanently killing two of them and essentially erasing hours of work with no warning or counterplay.

The best example I can think of the compare how that feels is to suggest how one would feel after 10 hours of adventuring on skyrim, only to have the game say Woops! We decided to delete your save file to keep you on your toes!"

Artificial difficulty is thrown around a lot these days
date: but this is a perfect example. It's poor game design that punishes the player for doing everything right. In what way does this kind of thing inscentivize the player to continiue playing?\n\nOne could argue that events like this add to the overall horrific feel of the game
recommended: to which I respond that events like that add to the overall feel of me wishing I had spent my money on something that didn't make me feel like I wasted the last 10 hours of my life.\n\nThe game has a lot of possitive qualities
hoursPlayed: but I can't recommend it currently."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

DD is silly.  You play it.  You lose.  You learn to make it work.  Then you lose again.  You learn again.  That's all good and healthy in a game.

BUT, the problem is you have to read about the major boss fights before you fight them or you will inevitably die (if it's a non-ideal group for the fight).  That's bad design.  In a game where losing is losing (fine), you can't make a fight that is SPECIFIC TO AN IDEAL GROUP.  That is BAD DESIGN.  Sorry, I really don't mean to be mean here, but their lack of understanding in an otherwise excellent game makes me want to design a game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Played it for 16hrs but then decided it was not worth the effort and the grind. Mostly because it's too hard in a random kind of way. There are to many random stats that affect gameplay and keeping track of all your heroes afflictions and bonuses is more of a chore than fun. Especially since after basically every mission your heroes get new afflictions and become gradually more unstable, you can't heal them at the same speed or they'd never go on missions.

Even after a successful dungeon raid you'll have to set up a new team of heroes as your old team needs to stay in town and drink or heal diseases.

The game does not really help you grasp the basics all that well, it took me some time to get into the correct" way of thinking but at that time I had already gotten bored with getting all my heroes killed by random things.

I really wanted to like this game but right now it's not fun. The art-style and the narrator make it an interesting experience
date: but once you get to your first boss fight you'll be bored with it unfortunately."

reviewText:
Three major problems exist in this game that are highly frustrating and ruin what is otherwise an enjoyable and interesting game.

1) The costs for removing afflictions and reducing stress are FAR too high. No one enjoys throwing 50-75% of their earnings into a gold-sink mechanic after every dungeon.
2) Battles and game mechanics in general are too reliant on RNG. No matter how well made your decisions are in battle, you are regularly put to your knees by crits/dodges/resists and other such nonsense. RNG is fine, but it needs to be used in moderation if the player wishes to maintain some sense of control.
3) If you level a character quicker than  you complete dungeons, he becomes useless as he refuses to enter a dungeon that is a level below him. There are several mechanics that the devs could have implemented to stop high level characters farming dungeons. Simply making a character unusable and forcing you to draft a newbie is frustrating as hell.

Good things to be found here, but not enough. Bought it on sale, still regret it.

reviewText:
I'm conflicted about the game.

Everything screams for me to like it. The graphics look great, voice acting is incredible, the theme is foreboding and thick, animations crisp, and on and on and on.

But really, this isn't a game. It's an RNG simulator. It's a horror story spectator mode. You don't git gud at the game and overcome (like in dark souls) but rather you exploit certain aspects of the game to progress.

Ultimately I found no reward in this game, which is sad cuz I wanted to like it so damn much. Like I said, it feels like I'm just watching a story I have little control over in which you always die or go insane in the end.

reviewText:
< 1% of people who play this game complete it. To give this some context over 10% of players who play Dark Souls finish it.

reviewText:
I guess the dev's needed to add a bit of 'excitement' to this game.

Just started playing it again after a long break.

In the first 30 minutes of playing, my party went on 4 different 'bad luck streaks'.

During these streaks, your entire party will be 'crit' nearly every hit. Your party's attacks and cc will 'miss' or be 'dodged'.

As soon as one of you characters 'break', suddenly, magically you will do nothing but crit.

It's as if the Devs said, wouldn't it be cool if their party got broken down but then they started kicking ♥♥♥!!!

If this didn't happen four different times in a short period of time, I'd write it off to varience.  (The chances to crit and dodge are like 5 percent).  But I think they do it on purpose.

It feels fake cheap and stupid. If you like being manipulated by cheap game mechanics pick this game up, otherwise don't bother.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Everyone seems to be complaining about this game being too hard as of around Dec 1st, 2015.  I got the game late December and have been having a great time.

RNG seems plenty fair to me.

Just when I think I'm doing well, the enemy crits me and I almost lose a character.

Just when I think I'm gonna have to abandon a quest, a character goes virtuous and turns the mission around.

I think the majority of these bad reviews came from players who got attached to characters that existed in a game that was easier than the developers wanted it to be.  The game got harder, some characters permadied, and everyone ran to the reviews to cry about it.

Nothing in this game is permanent.

You're eventually going to have to pick who to heal knowing that the other is going to die.

A time will come when you'll need to sell a good trinket to have enough supplies for the next mission because you had to bail on your last mission and didn't recoup the losses.

Sometimes you don't bring enough shovels and have to tear down several stone walls with your hands so your favorite team spends a week or two on vacation and you're stuck leveling scrub recruits while passing on the higher level mission that had a sweet trinket reward.

Preparedness goes a long way.

reviewText:
Darkest Dungeon is a glorified slot machine disguised with a bloody, wild, dark-fantasy theme. Everything is RNG dependant, as well as being designed to work against you. Your healers barely heal even with trinkets and buffs, your sluggers often miss regardless of traits and buffs, and taking on the actual, literal 'Darkest Dungeon' portion of the game is simply an exercise in sadomasochism.

Many are quick to defend the 'difficulty' of this game because of the current trend in video games (difficult games, ala Dark Souls, Binding of Isaac, etc.), however, the simple fact is that Darkest Dungeon isn't as tough as it is dependant on sheer luck. Crits, dodges, empty rooms and hallways, the discovery of treasure and trinkets that aren't totally useless and the like. Player skill is much less important than simply scoring a critical hit on a cultist with your Crusader or Leper.

Until you struggle through the game and become rich, many of the upgrades to both buildings and equipment are simply too expensive to afford. The hero roster is pitifully small despite how easy it is for them to die, training heroes to their max level takes too long given how tiny said roster is and how quickly they can be killed, trinkets are often as needlessly debilitating as they are helpful, heroes become too stressed too easily (especially in the final dungeon).

The game simply isn't fun to play...but at the same time, the gambling nature of DD makes it addicting. After 100+ hours I've come to realize that I've only been playing this game for those sporadic moments of utter joy that follow criting a tough enemy party three to four times in a row. Those times are wonderful, but they're also far and few between. More often than not, the enemy will be punishing YOU relentlessly, not the other way around.

In summation: buy this game if you like to gamble. It's good for that. The art is fun to look at for a while as well and the narrator is a nice touch...at first. After completing your 20th quest, though, his repeated quips become reminiscent of nails on a chalkboard. The mechanics, however - the actual meat of the game, are rather unenjoyable.
voteText: 32 of 62 people (52%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
The concept seems interesting and thoughtful, but it's not. The Cthulhu-based story drew me in. The terrible design drove me away. Challenge comes only through non-sensical design choices and the intense over-use of RNG.

Want to do something? RNG will stop you. Want to heal out of combat? You can't, even though you are a healer. Want to kill monsters? Well, you may get an occasional kill, but bodies just pile up, even though you are killing less than 3 at a time. Said bodies will block you from attacking. Everything is range based, and the game keeps finding ways to randomly change your positioning. The monsters can get though the piled up bodies just fine though, for some reason. If this were an action game, zombies and skeletons would be more nimble than humans. All of this doesn't entirely matter though, because your party usually dies from massive amounts of stress damage, which can't be mitigated much, in a handful of fights. It can be mitigated, sure, but you take about 500 damage in a dungeon, and you can mitigate about 20.

Party members are essentially canon fodder, and your goal is to build up your estate as they all die from horrible deaths. Yet, you will not be interested in doing so, because it's an excessive RNG-based grind fest where you see the same tiles and the same monsters over and over and over again....

I tried to return the game, but they won't let me. Maybe there's $2 worth of original ideas in this game, not $10 or $20+, not nearly so.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nBeautiful art reminiscent of Mike Mignola, excellent sound design, and the appeals of a very articulate narrator who has completely lost his damn mind accompany this trip into the dark beneath the world where horrible things dwell. It's exciting, difficult enough to be interesting, and very polished. This would rank high on my list of the best things I've played in 2015.

This game had me absurdly on-edge and deeply invested in every character, even my poor Simnir who died on his first quest. Managing resources is tense and extraordinarily well-handled, but keeping track of your characters mental states adds a powerful level of difficulty that makes not just every encounter but every step a carefully considered action. reviewText:
Early Access Review

I love this game. So far it's the best one I've played in 2015, and I can't wait to see what they add.

Unlike many other early access games, this one feels complete at its foundation. Core gameplay is very much there, and more importantly it's fun. It seems like anything they add now will just be extra content and balance passes, the latter of which could admittedly throw things into disarray.

This game is punishing, and sometimes it can seem unfairly so. But a bad roll of the dice usually serves to compound existing problems and flaws in strategy rather than turning an absolute win into an absolute failure. Bad luck can definitely ruin your day, but preparedness is key and the game's system for this feels innovative if a bit samey after a while.

If you're on the fence about this one, just get it. You won't be disappointed, and even months out from final release you'll have a great game to play.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Bite the pillow, the horrors' going in dry.

That's the best way to describe this delightfully difficult game. Your heroes are essentially like the nameless low-levels that you always hear about dying at the start of any D&D adventure. They're nobodies. It's the player's job to bring them up into a somebody, either by sheer dumb luck in dungeons, right choices in tactics, and perhaps running away. A lot.

Darkest Dungeon's quirks system adds a new, well-needed flavor to the roleplaying genre. For those that go in-depth, it can give new life to a character and turn a blank slate into a flavorful portrait. For those who simply run at it as a roguelike, the quirks system gives new variables that can spice up the game.  As heroes survive dungeon after terrifying dungeon, they grow in their quirks and their prowess, eventually becoming champions in their own right.

That doesn't make them any less mortal, however. A big component of Darkest Dungeon's, well, darkness, is the fact that any character can be susceptible to the perils and sometimes fatal clutches of the terrors beneath the estate, regardless of level. For some, this might be a turnoff. For others, it's a welcome challenge. I know most players complain when their characters get too powerful and can one-shot" everything. Well

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So far, I am extremely impressed by this game. The artstyle and atmosphere is grittty yet gorgeous. The combat system is standard for most turn-based strategy RPGs, but it's visceral enough to make every turn tense. Upgrading your town and adventurers is done smooth with enough depth to give you plenty of choices for your party structure. Overall, the game has just about everything a good rogue-like RPG would need.

But it doesn't stop there. The sanity and stress mechanics are what make the game different from anything else. Not only does it make the game more difficult, but it will completely change how you play the game from any other. There is a lot more micro-management along with trial-and-error when your adventurers start taking turns for the worst.

I can only imagine just how much more they could add to this game considering it's still in Early Access. At it's current state, it's definitely a must-buy for anyone who likes dark fantasy RPGs.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I followed DD since early kickstarter reveals, and hoh boy. As a forward, I absolutely LOVE difficulty in gaming. I have way too many hours logged onto DotA 2, Dark Souls 1 & 2, XCOM, etc. because I look for that punishment in my gaming. That being said, Darkest Dungeon lived up EXACTLY to the absurdly high standard its hype set for me. I was glued to my computer for hours and hours, praying that the hag's cleave wouldn't snuff out my party at death's door, hoping to land that fateful crit or stun, and damn if I haven't lost a lot of dudes. But I knew exactly what I was getting in to (thanks to the folks at Red Hook being very open throughout development) and damn if I didn't get exactly what I wanted.

Now, of course the game isn't perfect. There are a few typos, a couple issues, and ♥♥♥♥ Lockjaw. The divine wrath of RNGsus can, at times, be absolutely heartbreaking. But is that a bad thing? In this case, no. The game marketed itself on its punishing, brutal style. On its hopelessness, and on its faint glimmers of heroism. And they are all very, very real.

And that's to say nothing of any of DD's qualities other than its fantastic gameplay; I'm not sure if anyone has had an issue with the art style, or the narration, but they're both spot on for the game's atmosphere. The chilling voice of the narrator can praise your heroes for crits and kills, or comdemn them for their failures and disappointments. One issue that was more annoying than invasive was that if a cleave attack (Breakthru, Grapeshot, etc) crits, especially if the crit kills, the narrator states his lines on cue, over and over per crit/kill long after the moment had passed, and sometimes after combat had ended. But more of that ghastly voice filling the halls? Not too bad an issue at all.

All this said, and the game's just released on early access. JUST RELEASED. Early access has, as a concept, been plagued by the lack of developer care (abandoned titles, quick cash outs, AAA devs using it as an excuse, you name it) but this title is very clearly polished, and cherished by its creators. The folks at Red Hook took a lot of time, and a lot of effort, into making a product that would be adored by their followers, and by those just finding out about the title. And it really shows. I'm looking forward to everything they add, the heroic and the tragic, and I'd recommend this wonderful buy to anyone who loves difficulty, darkness, and tragedy.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Who is it for?

People who love Lovecraftian horror; people who dig dark 2D graphics with flair; anyone who has chugged dice while pretending to be an adventurer in a dungeon; players who like to see their characters go nuts; people who like having to option to send a character at the brothel for some reprieve; people who can live with not winning all the time; players who want to tackle on hopeless odds; people a dig an atmospheric narration to their gameplay.

Who is it not for?

People with issues pertaining to attachment and loss; players who dislike failing; anyone with a phobia of tentacles; players who need their games to be bright and cheerful; people who like fast-paced games.

Is it worth getting in early access?

Absolutely. There are some bugs pertaining to launching the game that require a workaround (I had to disable the Steam overlay to run it), but the game otherwise runs fine for the most part. There is a lot of content to keep players busy, and more to come. It feels quite polished despite being in early access. There might be balance issues, but players argue a lot over whether this is the case or not. Also, there are multiple updates each week that make it feel like the project is constantly progressing, and this puts some other Early Access titles in my library to shame.

Is this a rogue-like?

I personally don't think so. Yes, there are randomly generated dungeons and adventurers. Yes, death of an adventurer is permanent. But even a total party kill doesn't force you to restart the game; your hamlet remains upgraded, you retain the rest of the adventurers in your roster, and you can easily get new recruits. Adventurers are a (very expendable and replaceable) resource.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is one of those games that has sucked me in immediately, and keeps me coming back for more. I wish every game I bought had a fraction of the replay appeal.

The concept of the game is pretty straightforward. You create your party, and you choose four to go adventuring. Every dungeon is different, and every character will react slightly differently.

Without getting into a lot of detail (I'll leave that for the more capable reviewers) I'll simply hit some of the highs and lows for me.

Turn based combat - I have always preferred this formula.
Art - The art is pretty damn fantastic, as is the voiceover. It's a wonderful touch!
Challenge - There are a lot of factors to consider in this game. You will develop a party that will have more characters than you can take into a dungeon. While in there, they suffer stress and injuries. By managing your trips right, you can collect gold and loot, helping them heal from their injuries and reduce their stress. Too much stress will kill them, which is sometimes funny, and sometimes maddening.
Concept - For me, this is an original and engaging concept, and I've only just begun. Adventurers are somewhat disposable. Be prepared for many deaths. The trip you had planned will be called off. You'll either leave to heal, or you will lose every one you have fighting for you.

No matter what happens, you will probably do what I do. Go back to town, hire a few new bodies, and jump right back in.

There really aren't many low points. It would be nice if the purchased items were kept if you left a dungeon alive and they were unused.

This is probably the best early access game I've played.. Loving it!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Gripping
This game had me absurdly on-edge and deeply invested in every character, even my poor Simnir who died on his first quest. Managing resources is tense and extraordinarily well-handled, but keeping track of your characters mental states adds a powerful level of difficulty that makes not just every encounter but every step a carefully considered action. It's hard, but not impossible, and every once in a while you'll find that perfect combination of characters that just plows through dungeons. Y'know, until one goes insane and you have to craft and balance a new party while he's in the sanitarium recovering.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It was a stormy night that I and Dismas came to this camp; a blood streaked letter clamped in my hand told me my dead uncle had left his estate to me. I remember it from my childhood; a beautiful land full of colour, surrounded by warm fields and swaying trees...

Now I stood, letter in one hand and gore soaked sword in the other as I looked upon what had happened to this land. I found the caretaker buttoning up his trousers as he left a ♥♥♥♥♥ to greet me in the centre of village. Welcome, he rasped, to the Darkest Estate. With that greeting, he began to fill me in on my new duties as Lord of the Estate. I suppose that made me Lord Darkest. This grim sense of humour would become commonplace in my world soon enough.

The forest had become a land of bandits and mutant swine, their Prince and King strutting and rutting and ruining the land, poisoning all they touched. What had once been a place of beautiful harvest had become nothing more than a land of danger; food supplies could no longer get through and what few rangers he had sent to scout didn't return.

He discussed the old estate, filled with monstrous creatures and the undead, led by a Necromancer and his kin. The caretaker dared to imply a connection between these and my late Uncle, but a quick look put that line of reasoning to its end. These would have to be taken care of, as well.

And to the ruins in the south, a coven of witches (hags, he muttered between swigs of whisky) had taken over and what few survivors returned spoke of great, sweaty and cackling loonies who ate those who dared to confront them. Their cannibalism had long since driven them insane. He began muttering about how they had come to my Uncle in a guise of beauty, but soon began to splutter and rant without reason or even words. I left him to his ramblings, and his mind.

When the latest camp arrived, three nervous individuals had come. One, a woman with a similar faith to myself, a large mace, and a dour grimace. Another women, wrapped mostly in bandages and utterly unrecognisable without her phlaegm coated voice laughing at some joke no one told, echoing inside the bird mask of a Plague Doctor. Lastly, a Bounty Hunter, who simply handed me a picture of a large man in red. When I inquired further, he said he'd help me take his head with the non-expression of a sociopath. I stopped inquiring.

We began on this estate, exploring the ruins. We packed food and torches, but little else. Our goal was revenge, although the bounty hunter said it left our pockets empty for recovering assets. The Sister frowned at him, and said donations to the church. The Plague Doctor kept laughing to herself, but I noticed she would pick up whatever diamonds we found.

The torch began sputtering immediately, as it fought to hold back the darkness. I held it ahead of me, as much as weapon as the sword I held in my hand. I tried to sheave it, but the idea of not having it ready terrifed me more. The flickering firelight gave movement to every shadow, and every shadow an evil eye glaring at me. It was with a shove that the Bounty Hunter pushed me aside, an arrow flying past me and burying itself in the meat of the Sister's thigh. As we looked ahead, I saw skeletons charged at us down the corridor.

No, this is true. Actual skeletons, like inside of you or I, but these moved with a foul purpose, carrying swords, armour and even one in robes with a staff. As he raised it, a dark light surrounded our Plague Doctor, and she began to laugh a little more maniacally. Stuffing her hand in her pocket and shouting about traps, she threw a glittering powder over the the skeletons, which exploded in pops of light. The Bounty Hunter charged ahead, using the dazedness of the skeletons to take the head of the first. Feeling heartened, I picked up my sword and purpose and smashed the largest one in the face with my hilt. It seemed they still felt pain. As he reeled, I pulled a scroll from my belt and banished whatever foul magicks animated him back to hell.

The Sister prayed to her god, and a green grow began to close our wounds. However, the damage to our minds remained fresh, and for the Plague Doctor, lethal. We just didn't know it yet.

At least, after a night in this place, we found the Necromancer. Foul smelling thing, with a rusty red robe and its face hidden in shadow except for a malign glint, he brought up the bodies of fellow fighters to face us. The Bounty Hunter shouted that the Necromancer was his; poor fool. As I and the Sister contended with the skeletons, the Necromancer surrounded the Bounty Hunter with darkness. As his mind broke, the Necromancer then began to break his body.

The Plague Doctor used this time to surround the Necromancer with a special poison gas, and the Sister tried to heal the rest of us, as we watched the Bounty Hunter die. It took an agonisingly long time, and when he was done, all that was left of him that I could recognise was his dying screams in my ears. The Plague Doctor continued laughing. The Sister started praying. All I remember is screaming. Mine or someone else, I don't know.

The torch went out. We fought in the dark.

A few days, we three came out. The caretaker threw me into the temple, a run down thing, to begin prayer. The Plague Doctor apparently shut herself up in the brothel for days at a time, only leaving for more beer or meat. The Sister whipped herself bloody; I could hear her moans of pleasure echoing through the walls.

After several days, they let me out to greet the new arrivals. More had come, apparently word has spread of adventure. I smiled. Welcome to the Darkest Estate. I promise you, there is gold enough for everyone who is brave enough to fight.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Darkest Dungeon blew all my expectations away. Here is a quick summary to why I love playing it:

+ This game oozes theme and style. The aesthetic look and music really matches the gothic dungeon crawler nature.
+ Gameplay mechanics that fit with the game's theme. Relating to the point above, but this game has great smaller mechanics that fit very well together like the stress system of seeing the horrors of the night. The torch mechanic, allowing you to burn up your torches to make things easier or let them burn down for a tougher challenge but greater rewards is great. But what if you run out of torches? Well then you are definitely in for a tough time.
+ Varied characters and classes. Loads of variety here in both combat and camping skills that create charaters with purpose.
+ Loads of content for an early access release. This is what early access should be: I've played 4 hours and I've only defeated the first boss out of nine. There is three areas to explore with two more on the way (I presume for the full release). I've only seen one bug, which was incorrect text and it wasn't gamebreaking at all, and has already been patched.
+ Lots of player choice. This game is tough, everything goes wrong, but is still a lot of choice available to the player as they explore.

This game is exactly my type of game: A game where there is tough choices (like XCOM), short rougelike missions (like Rouge Legacy/Binding of Issac), but have lasting effects and purpose over a longer campaign (like XCOM and Rouge Legacy again).

One point to note:
- This is not a negative, but there is a lot of random generation involved for if you hit or miss, if you do 4 or 7 damage, etc. Some players may not enjoy that aspect, I love it as it creates unique experience and amusing moments when my
occultist healer does more bleeding damage than he healed.

From the start you can see that this game has a lot of love and polish put into it. Every day over the past week, I have always been excited to return to Darkest Dungeon. Highly recommended by me, I'll keep updating the review if something comes up, and when it is fully released.

If you wish to see dungeon gameplay, here is an episode part way through my Darkest Dungeon series that starts with dungeon crawling: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jFWyMhQYjeM

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you enjoy turn based and fairly in-depth RPGs then this is for you. Great art style, balanced and exciting combat.
The narrarator speaks throughout the game at certain periods, but they did this well. He speaks just enough to add the narrative element to the game but without being annoying. Definitely worth the money!

This game is challenging, at least for me. You may have to abandon some battles or even the whole quest at times. When a hero dies, he or she is gone for good!

Do yourself a favor and add this to your library!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After only playing for about 8 hours total, I've really come to like this game. It reminds me of the frustration/reward feeling of Dark Souls. It's by no means anything like Dark Souls, but that same kind of harshness is there, and it's extremely frustrating, but feels great when you recover some of the crazy odds against you.

The heroes you can recruit and level, then have them die to recruit them again is interesting, and I like that you yourself are none of them in the game technically. The skill upgrade and equipment upgrade system is great. I wish the items would change a little more in appearance as you upgrade them, but I've only upgraded to level 3 weapons so maybe it does at the end rank?

The trinkets are odd. I haven't found too many yet that I really want to use with the strong negatives they can possess, but there are a few that are crazy good when their class specific.

I think the stress system and test of resolve with the afflications is fantastic as well. Similar to Rogue Legacy with descendants having these afflications, but your heroes will be recruited with them or attain them as you progress through the story. It's funny to have an abusive character tell a crusader that just crit for 28 say, Not bad
date: but aim next time" or something that like haha.\n\nI do think the enemies that can just inflict stress with minor damage are a little overpowered
